Presentation Title: Greenhouse Gas Inventory of the University of Pittsburgh
Description or Abstract: As greenhouse gases continue to accumulate in the atmosphere and have an impact on climate, identifying and monitoring the sources of these emissions becomes increasingly important. Because residential and commercial buildings account for 40% of total US energy consumption [1], analyzing structures within this building stock and thereby identifying areas for improvement has the potential to significantly decrease greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Additionally, the University is a member of the Architecture 2030 Pittsburgh District, thereby committing to reducing energy use, water use, and transportation emissions by 50% by the year 2030. [2] In order to monitor any progress being made towards these goals, the University of Pittsburgh has conducted a campus-wide greenhouse gas inventory for Fiscal Years (FY) 2008, 2011, 2014, and is in the progress of updating the inventory for FY17. Data on energy consumption, transportation, and waste was collected from various departments across campus. After the data was collected, it was entered into a tool called the Campus Carbon Calculator, which was published by The Sustainability Institute at the University of New Hampshire. [3] This tool is an Excel-based spreadsheet that is designed specifically for the assessment of greenhouse gas emissions of institutions; it combines various emissions factors and other standard practices in order to calculate GHG emissions. Although FY17 data is still being analyzed, the FY14 inventory showed that a shift away from coal, while increasing nuclear powered electricity, resulted in a drop in CO2e by 15,000 metric tons. Because there are annual changes in the campus building stock, energy mix, as well as various other factors, the inventories may not show an overall clear decrease in greenhouse gas emissions; however, decreases in any given sector represent progress. This inventory will continue to identify large potential reduction areas in order to help achieve city goals by 2030.

Presentation Title: Campus & Community Resilience: Experiences from Community College & University Partnerships
Description or Abstract: Campuses in Portland, Los Angeles, and Phoenix were involved in the Climate Resilience in Urban Campuses + Communities (CRUX) project to support the implementation of resilience-related elements of the colleges and universities Climate Commitment. Since the winter of 2017 these campuses - located in dense urban areas with various at-risk populations - worked collaboratively to develop their own campus-community resilience assessments and begin the planning stages for campus resilience strategies. Through this process, each cluster has developed innovative resilience assessment tools and have completed resilience demonstration projects useful for the entire higher ed. community. Campus demonstration projects include; resilience curriculum, heat mapping, future visioning exercises, resilience building workshops, tree planting, water cisterns, stormwater retrofits and other green infrastructure initiatives. Community projects included; partnerships and mapping applications at the municipal level, integration with existing emergency response planning teams, community tree plantings, community workshops and information sessions (NOAA) regarding climate resilience and preparedness. Participants in this session will learn about the progress of the CRUX project over the last year (since the last AASHE conference) and gain insights into the lessons learned from the campuses involved. We will discuss partnerships between the institutions and increased cohesion between campuses and their communities.
PositionTitle_5: Interim Director, Institute for Sustainability; Professor

Presentation Title: Advancing Carbon Pricing at Your Institution
Description or Abstract: Carbon pricing is a fair, feasible, and powerful solution to accelerate a transition to a clean energy economy. With a growing number of carbon pricing policies around the world and building momentum in the US, higher education (HE) has an opportunity to advance an important national dialog. We will explore how schools can engage with carbon pricing: internal carbon fees on departments; proxy carbon prices for capital decision making; direct endorsement of legislative solutions; and student and community engagement in carbon pricing work. Internal carbon pricing models provide a framework for integrating climate in cost benefit analysis, financing for sustainability work, and can create a platform for engaging the campus community on climate solutions. We will share models of both internal prices levied on departments and offices within a school, and proxy pricing tools that are used in cost/benefit analysis in institutional decision making. As thought leaders, HE institutions have a responsibility to bring attention to strategic, effective solutions to challenging problems. Finally, HE works to educate and prepare our students and communities to engage with and solve big problems. We'll share strategies for educating and engaging the campus about climate policy, and empowering students to take action in their communities to advance climate solutions on the national stage.

Presentation Title: The Role of Campuses in Driving Climate Resilience Planning
Description or Abstract: As impacts from climate change intensify, a growing number of initiatives are emerging to increase resilience locally and globally. Campuses across the US are stepping up to prepare for climate change and serve as leaders in their communities. This session explores the roles that three schools are playing in driving climate resilience, both on campus and in the surrounding community. Presenters will discuss how their schools are serving as models of climate resilience planning and developing relationships with the community, particularly in the context of global initiatives such as 100 Resilient Cities and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The presentations and discussion will address questions about how higher education institutions can align their teaching, research, campus operations and cross-sector collaborations in support of SDGs for sustainable cities and communities, climate action and partnerships for sustainable development. University of Illinois at Chicago and University of California Los Angeles, both signatories of the Climate Commitment, will share experiences assessing resilience on campus and collaborating with city partners to plan for increased climate resilience. Dickinson College, the first to use the City Resilience Index tool outside of 100 Resilient Cities, will share its experience assessing resilience for the town of Carlisle, PA. This moderated panel will be followed by Q&A and interactive discussion with the audience.

Presentation Title: Putting A Price On Carbon: Fighting for Strong Climate Policy on the Campus, State and Federal Level
Description or Abstract: We already face the disastrous impacts of climate change: unprecedented droughts and heatwaves, stronger hurricanes, ocean acidification, sea level rise, the spread of infectious disease. The cost of these changes is born by everyone, especially communities of color, low-income households, and future generations. Or rather, almost everyone. The multi-trillion-dollar industry that sells fossil fuels and the consumers that burn them currently do so for free. Carbon pricing policy is a powerful way to make polluters rather than people pay for the true cost of burning fossil fuels. This market-based approach has conservative as well as liberal support in the US. Many governments around the world that price carbon have already begun to reduce emissions while making a just transition to clean and renewable energy. But to get across the finish line, this policy needs a champion. As the generation with the most to lose, young people are uniquely persuasive advocates for climate solutions. Decision-makers respond to young people in a way they don't to other groups, especially when we call for fair, science-based, economically sound policies like this. That is why Our Climate, a Seattle-based nonprofit founded and run by millennials, trains and supports student leaders across the country to deliver our generation's most critical ask--to #PutAPriceOnIt now before we end up paying a much larger price later.

Presentation Title: Assessing Campus and Community Resilience in Rural America
Description or Abstract: Rural colleges and universities face unique considerations when assessing campus and community climate resilience. While there are common elements to resilience at any institution, the political and economic landscape for campuses in rural regions of the US is often very different from that of urban or coastal areas. Join this session to hear from rural schools that recently completed climate resilience assessments. Each school will discuss how they identified assets, vulnerabilities, and initial indicators of resilience both on campus and in the surrounding communities. Presenters will focus especially on opportunities and challenges unique to rural areas, however the process will be relevant for all schools addressing resilience. Green Mountain College will describe their experience working the Community Resilience Organizations (CROs) Assessment tool and how they used the resilience assessment and the creation of a resilience plan to provide student learning opportunities. Central Community College will share how they assessed resilience at campuses in four different communities and combined the results into a final comprehensive assessment.

Presentation Title: Creating Positive Impact and Achieving Sustainability Goals through Custom Carbon Reduction Projects
Description or Abstract: How can your institution achieve more through your climate goals? Carbon offsets and RECs have long been an effective way of addressing the environmental impacts of running an academic institution or business. However, these strategies leave many organizations desiring more from their carbon offset or REC purchase. In this session, NativeEnergy will provide case study examples of how organizations have achieved their climate goals and created more value for their stakeholders and institutions by creating custom carbon reduction projects that are aligned with their mission and core activity areas. Whether it is projects located in study abroad locations, carbon reduction projects with specific academic curriculum integrated into them and more. Join us to explore how your academic institution can achieve its climate goals while creating a deeper level of value and positive impact!

Presentation Title: Leverage Your Renewable Energy Impact Through Emerging Avoided Emissions PPA Strategies
Description or Abstract: Renewable energy procurement is a critical strategy for reducing an institution's greenhouse gas emissions. However, not all renewable energy projects avoid the same amount of GHG emissions per kWh. The 20+ electrical grids and subregions of the US vary widely in their carbon intensity, from over 1,700 lbs CO2e/MWh in the mid-west to ~650 lbs CO2e/MWh in New England and CA. Choosing a project in a more carbon intensive grid rather than your potentially less intense local grid can therefore dramatically increase the actual GHG emissions avoided by your renewable energy choice. This workshop brings together the researchers developing these techniques with the practitioners employing them. We will provide a case study of how Boston University successfully worked with both private and academic partners to choose the renewable energy project that was best for both the University and the planet. This workshop will: Provide a process for campuses to identify renewable energy project selection criteria Share analytical tools to align GHG reduction efforts with energy and financial needs Review carbon emission accounting practices including traditional and marginal emission approaches using data synthesized by researchers at Carnegie Mellon Univ., Examine renewable energy project electricity production profiles to understand how to predict a project's future electricity production.

Presentation Title: From Incremental to Transformative Climate Action: Lessons Learned From Addressing Barriers
Description or Abstract: What are the most fundamental and challenging barriers to achieving carbon neutrality at a large research university? The first University of California campus to publish a climate action plan (CAP) did so more than 10 years ago. All 10 UC chancellors signed the ACUPCC in 2007 and completed a CAP by 2009. Each campus updated their CAP in 2016 to map out the path to achieve carbon neutrality by 2025. However, in retrospect, it is not clear that the previous CAPs resulted in anything beyond incremental actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. As a result, in 2016 the UC system established a high-level Task Force on Carbon Neutrality Management to identify the most significant barriers to achieving the 2025 goal and to develop recommendations for overcoming those barriers. The Task Force published its report in fall 2017 with a list of recommendations developed through extensive consultations with over 200 stakeholders. Those recommendations were approved by UC President Janet Napolitano and presented to the 10 campus chancellors and Board of Regents. In parallel, UC researchers received a grant from the TomKat Foundation to launch two year-long applied research projects: (1) a natural gas exit strategy; and, (2) a change management and communications strategy to get support for the necessary transformative changes. This panel will share the insights gleaned from trying to move beyond incremental climate action to transformative change.
PositionTitle_2: Associate Vice President of Energy and Sustainability

Presentation Title: Boston University's Climate Action Plan and The Public Process
Description or Abstract: Boston University's Climate Action Plan provides a roadmap to address energy use and sourcing, resiliency and climate preparedness, transportation, supply chain, and waste. Moreover it recommends the creation of an academic initiative that will catalyze climate change-related research and the Plan's integration into BU's Strategic Plan. The task force engaged the BU community in the development of the Plan and provided a strategy to convey individual ownership of and responsibility for the actions required to realize the Plan. They also engaged the City, state, and neighboring institutions to explore shared solutions that benefit the broader community. The Climate Action Plan was developed in 2017 following two years of divestment advocacy by students and faculty, a review of the divestment issue by the Advisory Committee for Socially Responsible Investing (a committee of the Board of Trustees), and finally a charge from the President. A faculty-led task force, including some staff and students, developed the Plan's recommendations. Under the Plan, the University is committed to achieve zero net emissions to operate its facilities and fleet by 2040. Part of this effort will be to reduce energy use 31% by 2032, upgrading equipment and infrastructure. Additionally, the University will negotiate a power purchase agreement for 100% of its load to support the construction of a new renewable energy project. The Plan includes recommendations to prepare the campuses for the impacts for the change that can't be avoided from rising seas, storm flooding, heat waves, and wind by addressing new planning and construction standards and the relocation of critical functions. Recommendations regarding indirect emissions include: build capacity to more accurately measure scope 3 emissions, work with vendors to promote the sourcing of sustainable products and services and pilot a Zero Waste program.

Presentation Title: Approaches to Carbon Offset Procurement
Description or Abstract: This presentation will feature a diversity of institutions and their approaches to carbon offset procurement in pursuit of carbon reduction goals. The institutions represented on this panel share the perspective that similar to recycling's reduce, reuse, recycle mantra, carbon neutrality goals should follow a reduce, renew, offset prioritization. Internal reductions and the adoption of renewable energy sources are pursued before carbon offset procurement. Still, for institutions with fast-approaching carbon neutrality deadlines, carbon offsets can be an impactful instrument in the climate change toolkit. Offsets, like other investments in emissions reduction, can offer many beneficial outcomes beyond their primary goal of achieving a reduction; distinguishing between offset projects can be a time-consuming process that requires analysis and judgment. Institutions need to apply values and principles to guide investments in offset credit purchases in order to maximize ROI (in tonnes CO2e), and weigh additional value like positive PR, possible student research opportunities, the location of projects, and health, lifestyle, and aesthetic benefits. This panel will begin with Ruby Woodside from Second Nature who will cover the context of carbon offsets within higher education climate commitments, and then discuss the values and missions that guide carbon offset purchase decisions within the University of California system, at Duke University, and at Colgate University.
PositionTitle_4: Program Manager, Duke Carbon Offsets Initiative

Presentation Title: OffsetNetwork.org: Higher Ed's Hub for Self-Generated Offset Projects and Peer Verification
Description or Abstract: The Offset Network is an online platform for colleges and universities to share experience, lessons learned and tell the stories behind developing their own carbon offset projects. The site provides guidance for schools considering developing their own emission reduction projects. Self-generated offsets offer greater flexibility than market-purchased credits, opening the door to added value through connection to academic mission and impacting nearby communities through project co-benefits. This presentation will provide the offset market context, self-generated projects fill, and how these credits can be applied towards carbon neutrality commitments. Offsetnetwork.org is the hub for these projects within higher-ed and is expanding to pilot a Peer Verification structure that will validate and verify self-generated projects by having a peer institution act as the verifier. These credits qualify for Second Nature's Carbon Commitment and AASHE Stars 'Institution Catalyzed Offsets' in addition to qualifying as a Stars reporting 'Exemplary Practice Credit'. The Peer Verification process was piloted in the Spring of 2018 when American University acted as the project verifier for Duke University's urban forestry offset projects in North Carolina. Both American University and Duke will be presenting the findings from the verification report and the experience of working through the Peer Verification structure.
PositionTitle_1: Program Coordinator, Duke Carbon Offsets Initiative

Presentation Title: NE Drawdown: A Multi-College Effort to Adapt & Implement Impactful Regional Climate Change Solutions
Description or Abstract: This past summer, students from Amherst, Smith, and Williams colleges investigated the global Drawdown methodology, compiled regional climate data to determine the top priorities for the area, and conducted a gap analysis to determine where the Northeast has overlap with global Drawdown and where regional strategies differ. They created a roadmap to determine where the drawdown approach aligns with or complements the work already being done in the region and how college campuses can use that research to most effectively address campus efforts. In this session, staff members from the various sustainability offices will discuss lessons learned, their next steps - both as a collaborative and on a campus-level - and how this model could be adapted for other regions. So what is 'Drawdown' itself? As the book and website state: 'The 100 most substantive solutions to reverse global warming, based on meticulous research by leading scientists and policymakers around the world. Drawdown is that point in time when the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere begins to decline on a year-to-year basis'.
PositionTitle_1: Assistant Director, Zilkha Center for Environmental Initiatives
PositionTitle_2: Director of Sustainability and Campus Planning
PositionTitle_4: Director, Zilkha Center for Environmental Initiatives

Presentation Title: Climate Resiliency Planning: What We're Learning
Description or Abstract: Black Hills State University is in the process of creating a Climate Resiliency Plan in partnership with city and county partners and facilitated by Verdis Group. The planning process will engage regional partners in the South Dakota Black Hills region to assess strengths and vulnerabilities in terms of projected climate change impacts and will allow partners to jointly develop strategies to build resilience to those impacts. Come join the conversation to find out how we are following Second Nature's recommendations to create a Resilience Assessment-what we've learned so far, and what we can recommend to you as you begin your own Climate Resiliency Planning.

Presentation Title: Examining Data from Across Higher Ed: Does a Commitment Drive More Progress?
Description or Abstract: In November 2017, the University of New Hampshire (UNH) launched the Sustainability Indicator Management and Analysis Platform (SIMAP™), a new inventory tool replacing the Campus Carbon Calculator and the CarbonMAP tools. Second Nature and UNH have a partnership that is focused on ensuring alignment between SIMAP and Second Nature's reporting platform for signatories of the Climate Leadership Commitments, and on jointly supporting users/signatories in accurately tracking and reporting their carbon and nitrogen footprints. The goal is to provide the following benefits: - Improved efficiency and ease for SIMAP users and Second Nature signatories - The potential to improve data quality for all users and for the sector as a whole - The ability to attract a large and sustained user base, which will in turn allow for a rich repository of campus energy and operational data than can be aggregated and analyzed to elucidate significant trends and opportunities for the sector With SIMAP storing greenhouse gas data from both signatories of the President's Climate Leadership Commitments and non-signatories, it provides an opportunity analyze progress across both groups. Previous data analysis released in 'The State of Sustainability in Higher Education' reports from UNH and Sightlines has provided some insights; this session will build on these insights by offering the first snapshot of aggregated SIMAP data analysis since the launch of the tool. It will also offer a case study of the challenging process of sharing data between tools and platforms aimed at a higher education sustainability audience; a process that many agree they would like to see happen more frequently, but that is often stymied by a host of barriers.

Presentation Title: Profitable Carbon Capture Technology for Campus Power Plants
Description or Abstract: The University of Maryland is pursuing a partnership with technology firm, HY-TEK Bio, to install an algae based carbon capture system to mitigate emissions from UMD's combined heat and power plant. This project involves minimal CAPEX and OPEX for the university since HY-TEK Bio will build, own, and operate the carbon capture system in space leased from the university. HY-TEK Bio can divert flue emissions from a power plant and inject those emissions into closed photobioreactors where they grow a valuable strain of algae patented as HTB-1. Algae is harvested, dried, and sold to companies that process it into products for nutraceutical and food industries. Through profit-sharing with HY-TEK Bio, the university receives payments while sequestering GHG emissions. This project creates a profitable pathway to achieving carbon neutrality.

Presentation Title: Understanding the Entire Campus Carbon Footprint: How and Why to do Comprehensive Scope 3 Reporting
Description or Abstract: Scope 3' emissions (i.e., those from upstream and downstream activities, such as producing the goods purchased by a campus, extracting and refining fuels, or commuting/business travel) are notoriously difficult to measure, and reduce. Scope 3 reporting requires a strategic approach, realistic expectations and a long-term outlook. It's also clear that there is an opportunity for the higher education sector to do this better. Traditionally, most Scope 3 emissions have been considered 'optional' categories for GHG reporting, and campuses have taken an ad hoc approach to what they do or do not include-with commuting and business travel being the most common. However, the handful of campuses that have attempted to do more comprehensive Scope 3 accounting have found that this can increase their reported impact by as much as 50%. SIMAP™, the UNH-supported, web-based carbon and nitrogen tool that is used by many colleges and universities, will soon feature a new module that facilitates comprehensive Scope 3 reporting. The module is being developed by working closely with pilot campuses, including the University of Texas Austin, that have already taken steps to better understand their complete institutional carbon footprints (including the impact of institutional purchasing.) Hear about how UT, UNH, and other SIMAP pilot campuses have approached their Scope 3 reporting, what they learned in the process, and how they are using the data strategically to advance campus sustainability.

Presentation Title: Creative Approaches for Engaging People in Climate Action
Description or Abstract: During this workshop participants will discuss innovative ways to engage both their campus population and general public in climate action initiatives. These approaches may include incentivizing people to take responsible actions, or to hosting fun new events that engage new audiences. Participants share approaches that have worked in their communities and on their campuses; as well as thinking through new opportunities to improve the effectiveness of their initiatives. An intersectional approach will be explored to connect climate action to other global goals.

Presentation Title: Beyond Offsetting: Onsetting Scope 3 Emissions and Supporting Innovative Local Projects
Description or Abstract: Universities struggle to find meaningful ways to address their Scope 3 emissions, especially with regard to staff travel and study abroad. This session will explain carbon 'onsetting' as a positive alternative to carbon offsetting and how schools can use this system to support local, innovative projects within Second Nature's Climate and Resilience Commitments. While carbon offsetting can help students understand their emissions, it is an inefficient and non-transparent system with the implicit message that it is possible to 'buy a clean conscience while delaying meaningful action.' Carbon onsetting resolves these challenges by 1) pricing emissions based on the best scientific evidence of the Social Cost of Carbon; 2) dropping the controversial concept of carbon neutrality in order to broaden how we perceive and respond to climate change; and 3) moving beyond individual actions and focusing on systemic and collective change. Onsetting helps schools address their unavoidable emissions while focusing on what they do best -- educating the next generation of leaders for a better world.

Presentation Title: GHG Accounting in Higher Education - The Case for Forging Our Own Path
Description or Abstract: Quantifying Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emission inventories and setting reduction goals started at the national level in the 1990's with the formation of UNFCCC and the first guidelines for inventory development by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in 1996 . Corporate entities followed suit, calling for their own standard for accounting and reporting GHG emissions in the late 90's . In 2006 twelve college and university presidents were 'motivated by their conviction that higher education had the capacity and responsibility to lead on climate and sustainability action for the sake of their students and society' to form the American College & University Presidents' Climate Commitment. Over the next eleven years, more than 600 institutes have joined to commit themselves to a goal of carbon neutrality. This time period saw the formation of many higher education sustainability offices and the development of many climate action plans. These numbers are impressive and our actions should be commended. However, by following in the footsteps of National and Corporate GHG accounting and not stepping back to consider our own drivers for action, we may have missed an opportunity to more fully engage the mission of our institutions into our GHG reduction strategies. We have an opportunity now - with many of us looking to expand our scope 3 categories, use or campuses as living labs, and better track and quantify the more 'unquantifiable' work our offices do.

Presentation Title: Do It Yourself Green Challenge - Cost Effective Way to Improve Health, Environment, & Climate Change
Description or Abstract: 87% of all human produced CO2 emissions comes from burning fossil fuel for electricity/heat, transportation, and industry. The transportation sector is the second largest source of CO2 emission. The Green Challenge is a tool to create competition to combat climate change by reducing carbon emission using My Open Road FREE App to encourage participants to take sustainable transportation -- biking, walking, running, skating, carpooling, taking the bus, and driving electric or energy efficient cars and telework. The app uses GPS technology to record distances, speeds, and points of origin and destination of travel logged by users and CO2 saved. My Open Road rewards commuters for using eco-friendly transportation that produces low or zero carbon emissions and promotes a healthier lifestyle for participants. When displayed on their app's home screen, the number pounds of CO2 saved from being emitted into the atmosphere serves as measurable progress that participants find encouraging; It's a reminder of how important individual action is in improving the environment. In these challenges/competitions, participants compete to see who can save the most pounds of carbon dioxide by taking sustainable/active transportation. Contests run for two (2) weeks or more and the top three winners of each category are awarded prizes. The Green Challenge goals are not only encouraging new riders but also inspiring new and existing riders to have fun, and to realize changes in behavior have a great impact on their quality of life, health and the planet. The Do It Yourself (DIY) Green Challenge offers a much more efficient and cost effective way to create your own challenge to invite your friends, groups, employees to reduce carbon footprint together to improve health, environment, commute and to combat climate change.

Presentation Title: Carbon Pricing on Campus: Four Models for Higher Ed Engagement on a Climate Solution
Description or Abstract: To combat climate change, schools are using carbon pricing as a powerful tool for reducing campus emissions and advancing national policy solutions. Pricing has been used by both governments and corporations, but is nascent in the higher education sector. Following background and context about carbon pricing as a policy solution to climate change, we'll learn from panelists with experience advancing carbon pricing at their schools. Alex Barron, Breanna Parker and Dano Weisbord: Proxy pricing at Smith - We summarize tradeoffs and benefits of carbon fees and proxy prices, and how your institutional constraints may shape your choices, illustrated with case studies from Smith. Casey Pickett: Internal Carbon Charge at Yale - We describe how Yale charges its administrative units for building-related carbon emissions, how the charge was created, the challenges overcome in implementation, and the results from the first year of operation. Aurora Winslade and Nathan Graf: Campus engagement at Swarthmore - Swarthmore aims to use our Carbon Charge Program as a platform for community education and engagement about carbon pricing solutions. We'll discuss our work to engage the campus community and empower students to work with local government. Steve Mital and Ryan Walch: Willingness to pay at University of Oregon - The University of Oregon has researched variation in stakeholder willingness to pay different carbon prices with under different policy structures.
PositionTitle_5: Director of Sustainability and Campus Planning

Presentation Title: Achieving Large-Scale Campus Emissions Reductions: The Plan, Team, & Relationships Required
Description or Abstract: After President Trump announced plans to withdraw the United States from the Paris Climate Accord, numerous Institutions indicated they would rise to the challenge by signing the 'We Are Still In' pledge. While this pledge has potential to create momentum and accountability at Universities to make real change, many are still struggling to put a dent in their campus emissions. In order to ensure the University of Dayton's signature was more than symbolic, UD's Hanley Sustainability Institute created a student led Campus Energy Team with a goal to reduce relative scope 1 and 2 emissions by 26% by 2025 - in line with the United States' original INDC to Paris. Our Campus Energy Team would like to share the most important takeaways from our first year in action, primarily the plan, team, and relationships required for significant progress. First, a graduate student will present on the process he took in identifying an achievable, quantitative goal and developing a clear plan to achieve that goal while including all relevant stakeholders in the process. Second, our students are excited to share the top cost-effective and innovative clean energy recommendations we have implemented, such as lighting and HVAC controls, in order for other institutions to replicate projects back at their campus. Lastly, a Facilities Management staff member will discuss the lessons learned from his unique experience in transitioning from a graduate student to a full-time Facilities Management staff member. In addition, he will discuss the importance of fostering strong relationships to ensure that the cost-effective clean energy projects recommendations are fully supported for implementation. Developing this effective and diverse team of undergraduate and graduate students, faculty, and facilities management staff has been important in not only reducing emissions, but also serving as a hands on educational experience for students interested in a career in energy management.

Presentation Title: Nailing Net Zero, From Design to Certification
Description or Abstract: More than 400 firms have signed onto the American Institute of Architects' (AIA) 2030 Commitment, targeting 70%+ EUI savings; however a 2016 AIA survey of participating firms revealed the portfolios of only six firms reached the 70% target. Why have so many fallen short, and how can schools better plan to meet net zero targets? The U.S. Department of Energy will deliver a primer of net zero energy buildings, including their technical definition, historical challenges, and trends. Community College of Allegheny County (CCAC) will discuss planning for their new, net zero energy 90,000-square-foot Workforce Development and Training Center, which will feature smart classrooms, laboratories, and multi-use spaces. They recently issued a request for qualifications (RFQ) that includes a number of specifications for constructing the center as a Net Zero Energy (NZE) facility, including a detailed breakdown of when and how energy modeling should take place. CCAC received 21 responses to the RFQ, all but one of which adhered to net zero energy. Learn how CCAC is carefully planning for this project to not just meet, but exceed its net zero energy goals. Lastly, Allegheny College will present on their recently constructed renewable energy greenhouse, which aims to operate as a net zero energy facility, while extending the growing season into the winter. The structure features a rooftop of luminescent solar concentrator (LSC) panels.

Presentation Title: Creating an Ecologically Restorative, Socially Just, and Culturally Rich Campus
Description or Abstract: The higher education campus, what better place to implement the most innovative & forward-thinking design frameworks? As HEIs support the next generation's transition into the workforce, it's time to design & construct exemplary places that support a future that is socially just, culturally rich & ecologically restorative. The Living Building Challenge imagines buildings that are resilient & healthy. The Living Community Challenge imagines campuses full of such buildings working together as an ecosystem to generate energy with renewable resources, capture & treat water on site & operate free of toxins while maximizing beauty & equity. This workshop will describe how the programs create a comprehensive living laboratory approach to facility & campus planning while supporting AASHE STARS & UN SDGs. Using these systems together creates a roadmap for designing, constructing & operating a healthy & sustainable campus that supports the mission of the institution, values of the campus community & education of the next generation of leaders. Lessons learned from registered & certified campuses & campus buildings highlight how the entire campus community can be engaged in planning, curriculum & ongoing operations.

Presentation Title: Evolving Pennsylvania State University's Sustainability Policy Within a Regenerative Paradigm
Description or Abstract: Penn State University (PSU) is a public research university serving Pennsylvania and the global community with a vision to integrate sustainability throughout its campuses and to prepare students to be sustainability leaders. At PSU the Office of Physical Plant (OPP) stewards approximately 32 million square feet of buildings providing facility services and safety programs in support of the university's threefold mission of teaching, research and services. OPP, in collaboration with PSU's Department of Architectural Engineering, has realized the potential of influencing and evolving the sustainability culture among students at PSU by shifting OPP's sustainability thinking from the paradigm of looking at buildings as a product into a more regenerative dynamic approach that recognizes buildings as systems. By encouraging and initiating reciprocity and mutually beneficial interaction among stakeholders throughout the different stages of the lifecycle of the building, OPP hopes to develop more sustainable campuses. OPP and the AE department are aiming to lead the transformation of the built environment at PSU while providing engaged scholarship opportunities for the students. As a first step towards this vision an AE graduate student, sponsored by OPP, is working to evolve PSU's LEED Policy to reflect a dynamic based process that encourages the engagement of OPP teams in the earliest stages of a project.
PositionTitle_2: Assistant Director, Design and Construction Division

Presentation Title: Rising to the Challenge of Creating and Maintaining Living Buildings and a Living Campus Community
Description or Abstract: Campuses have been early adopters of livability, equity, and climate commitments. This session takes a deep look at how campuses can and are taking action to achieve these commitments and lead the way on important collective targets such as the UN Sustainable Development Goals? The Living Building Challenge imagines a campus building that is resilient, healthy, ecologically restorative and educates as a living laboratory. The Living Community Challenge imagines a campus full of such buildings working together as an ecosystem of buildings, infrastructure, and open spaces that together generate all of the energy needed with renewable resources, capture and treat all water on-site, are free of toxins and operate efficiently while maximizing beauty and interaction and addressing equity. Higher education institutions play a critical role in shaping the future through their physical infrastructure, through their leadership in the community, through research, and through the education of future leaders. The Living Building Challenge and Living Community Challenge provide clear frameworks for achieving sustainability and climate commitments including many aspects of the UN Sustainable Development Goals. This session will highlight leading higher education campuses that have taken on a holistic multi-generational approach to resiliency, health, innovation, and equity by using the Living Building Challenge and Living Community Challenge as frameworks for action. Join this session to learn more about how the Living Building Challenge and the Living Community Challenge, along with STARS, can work together to create vibrant campuses that meet the UN Sustainable Design Goals and are ecologically restorative, socially just, and culturally rich.

Presentation Title: The Trials and Tribulations of Building a Living-Learning Sustainable Campus
Description or Abstract: What does it truly mean to be a living-learning sustainable campus? Eden Hall, just outside Pittsburgh, is a new 388 campus site, encompassing farmland, forests and two head-water catchments. Acquired by Chatham University in 2008 and opening for business in 2015, the campus features sustainable energy systems, onsite water treatment, LEED platinum buildings, an organic farm and green infrastructure for water management. It is home to the newly created Falk School of Sustainability and Environment, which presently has 150 graduate and undergraduate students, some residing on the campus, most commuting. This presentation will take the audience through our journey in building a school of sustainability, a sustainable campus and a sustainable community. We will focus on the successes and failures and the pragmatic lessons we have learned over the past few years in moving from ideals to practice. The presentation will end with a discussion of what we see as the ongoing and future challenges that any university will face in seeking to tread the academic and infrastructure path of sustainability.

Presentation Title: Hampshire College's R.W. Kern Center- A Living & Learning Building
Description or Abstract: Located at the heart of Hampshire College campus, the R.W. Kern Center is a certified Living Building: generating its own energy, capturing and treating its own water, and processing and recycling its waste. But the building's impact is far greater than it's small (carbon) footprint. In this session, we'll share how the project has transformed sustainability at Hampshire, creating a rallying point for positive change on campus and beyond. We'll talk creative course integrations, engaging community events, and student and faculty research, which anchor the Kern Center in the Hampshire educational experience. On a larger scale, we'll share how the project has allowed the Hampshire community to demonstrate leadership in sustainable design and create connections across academia, environmental advocacy, design and engineering, municipalities, and businesses. Join us to learn more about this transformational building, and how to leverage your own projects to support your institution's institutional goals and values.
PositionTitle_1: R.W. Kern Center Director of Educational Program and Outreach

Presentation Title: Earning AASHE STARS credits via the ENERGY STAR Buildings program
Description or Abstract: Colleges and universities can use ENERGY STAR's free tools and resources to earn credits in all four categories of AASHE STARS v2.1 -- Academics; Engagement; Operations; and Planning & Administration. This session will use the AASHE STARS v.2.1 rating system as a springboard to explore opportunities for earning credits towards it via the ENERGY STAR Buildings program. Prior to the conference, a resource will be published that maps free ENERGY STAR tools and resources onto the AASHE STARS rating system, specifying opportunities for earning credits. Examples include integrating ENERGY STAR's updated, three-unit module on assessing building energy use into semester-length courses across campus in order to earn credits in the Academics category, using Portfolio Manager to benchmark and even earn ENERGY STAR certification for campus buildings, capturing Operations credits, and leveraging ENERGY STAR's significant public recognition by co-branding an efficiency competition run between campus buildings, earning credits towards Engagement. This session will review ENERGY STAR's freshest tools and resources for the higher education community in the context of AASHE STARS. Attendees will receive a copy of the resource outlining opportunities for credits.

Presentation Title: Biophilic Design Principles and Green Infrastructure: Forging New Possibilities for Nature, Harmony and Resiliency in Urban Environments
Description or Abstract: Green Infrastructure practices are being mandated and implemented in urban communities for multiple beneficial outcomes. Often referred to as grey infrastructure alternatives, these practices include the design, installation, and maintenance of on-structure vegetation, bioswales, urban forests, green streets and pervious pavements. All of these practices serve to emulate nature and provide the same benefits: rainwater absorption and disbursement, cooler air, carbon sequestration and lowered water management infrastructure costs. There is a more desirable benefit to consider when contemplating the design implications of these urban stormwater management projects. That benefit is the 'biophilic effect.' This psychological phenomenon was first described by E.O. Wilson in his thesis, 'Biophilia.' Simply stated, humans cannot develop as well-formed individuals in the absence of nature. In the late 80's architect, Stephen Kellert, recognized Wilson's work as a solution he had long been seeking. Together, they authored 'The Biophilia Hypothesis' and Kellert continued to pioneer the research through 'Biophilic Design' (2008). This presentation, which includes a 'flash' charette, will inform and apply the essential prinicples of biophilic design to modern green infrastructure projects in the campus and urban environment.

Presentation Title: US Department of Energy Funding to Simplify Sustainable Campus Design
Description or Abstract: Campuses that use fewer natural resources and buoy health, learning and happiness are increasingly vital for educational institutions, as students and faculty voice demand for it. To deliver a sustainable building, institutional leaders must get consensus among siloed stakeholders PRIOR to engaging a design / construction team. If this large task is under-resourced, well intentioned building projects underachieve. To address, the University of Chicago partnered w/ sustainability firm Seventhwave, to improve the University's internal pre-project process when a new building or major renovation is contemplated. Partnership goals were to define clear pre-project process that: - Facilitates internal goal and stakeholders consensus; - Clarifies process / structure to reduce risk and budget uncertainty; - Enables high-performance beautiful design to meet demanding expectations; - Drives competition for bidding project teams to deliver deeper sustainability for same budget / schedule As UChicago buildings, such as Campus North Residential Commons, provided evidence this process delivered results, the US Department of Energy funded Seventhwave to create the Accelerate Performance (AP) program, to scale innovation nationally thru utility partnerships, financial incentives and consulting services to institutions: - Rebates for energy use reduction; - No-cost advising, facilitation, Request for Proposal writing, energy models, cost-benefit analysis for new building development.

Presentation Title: Becoming BREEAM: How UC Davis Achieved the First Institutional BREEAM In-Use Certification in the US
Description or Abstract: In November 2017, University of California at Davis became the first academic institution in the country to achieve BREEAM In-Use (BIU) Certification for a building on their campus. BREEAM stands for Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method, a program that has existed as part of the UK based Building Research Establishment for over 28 years. BREEAM is the predominant global green building certification program with over 562,250+ buildings certified worldwide. BREEAM In-Use was launched in the United States by BRE America in 2016. Since then, a growing number of properties have chosen to become BIU Certified as a means to benchmark and improve the environmental performance of their assets. The BIU program touches all aspects of sustainability, including: Health & Wellness, Transportation, Water, Energy, Pollution, Materials, Land Use & Ecology, Waste, and Management This session will use the UC Davis Plant & Environmental Sciences (PES) Building as a case study to demonstrate how the BIU Standard can be applied at academic institutions around the country as an affordable, internationally tried-and-true program for assessing and managing the environmental performance of campus assets. UC Davis' Green Building Coordinator will speak to the unique challenges and benefits of implementing BREEAM In-Use within academic institutions.

Presentation Title: Computer Networks Doing Their Part to be Sustainable - New Industry Standards
Description or Abstract: College and University planners are challenged by the exploding demand for data services, as more and more devices are added to campuses. Administrators and students are asking whether this trend is sustainable, and how it can be responsibly embraced. As very few people understand the behind-the-scenes infrastructure, there is little visibility or awareness of the great impact this trend has. Besides the obvious expansion of bandwidth demand from social media, streaming video, and Wi-Fi phone calls, there are many new devices and applications being added to the mix. Wearable technologies such as smart watches and biometric-enabled clothing and footwear, wireless group collaboration technologies, and GPS-enabled social media run silently in the background of the fabric of the campus. Networks are integral to all academics and campus life, and as a utility are a foundational tool to implementing the Sustainable Development Goals of the United Nations. How can higher education professionals adopt new ideas from the ICT (Information Communications Technology) industry, and adopt responsible technology sustainability plans that are not 'greenwash?' To this end, the ICT Industry, through professional associations, have been developing Standards in the area of technology sustainability for several years now. New and emerging standards build on existing guidelines such as LEED, and include standards for data centers, networks, audiovisual systems, and smart buildings. These standards are from reputable industry trade associations such as TIA, BICSI, AVIXA, etc., and carry designations such as ANSI and ISO. This session will introduce how Higher Education planners can specify these standards when developing new and renovated building plans. Continuing operations and occupant engagement standards will also be explored. This technical topic will unfold with understandable and relatable concepts to encourage student engagement.

Presentation Title: New Best Practices for Resilient Design: From Theory to Application
Description or Abstract: Taking resilient design beyond theory, speakers will illustrate how new tools and resources can inform design, including developing and piloting resilient design guidelines for university campuses. When clients, designers, engineers, and planners are interested in incorporating resilience into their projects, where can they begin? This session will outline a path to resilience, from foundational considerations to application in design. The AEC industry has begun to incorporate resilience into the design process, with leaders from cities, higher education institutions, and NGOs. Yet resilience is most often not a part of the standard of care. While codes and references are not yet requiring resilient design thinking, emerging best practices and resources, from future climate data to resilience frameworks, are becoming more readily available to inform the process. Participants will learn about these tools, what questions to ask, who they should collaborate with to help them understand the inputs, and how others are approaching this topic, in order to develop an expertise in resilient design.

Presentation Title: Performing at a Higher Level - Healthy Buildings for Your Campus
Description or Abstract: University campuses offer a unique opportunity to drive progress at the intersection of sustainability, education, public health, and the built environment. This session will explore how one institution is leveraging new tools, resources and partnerships to prioritize health and wellness on the campus. Director of Sustainability at Agnes Scott College, Susan Kidd will share the success of a practical application on their campus. Sustainability Manager and WELL Building Expert at JLL Kat West will discuss two tools gaining traction as viable solutions to high performance and healthy building initiatives: the WELL Building Standard and ASHRAE Standard 189.1. Kat will provide a brief overview of these solutions and highlight how they are valuable for connecting building design and construction, facilities operations, and campus via an integrative design process to help bridge the gap between our built environment and students' well-being for years to come. Jaime Van Mourik, Vice President of Education Solutions at USGBC, will round out the session by linking learning to action and discussing what USGBC is providing to higher ed faculty for curriculum integration efforts and professionals to advance knowledge to create a holistic approach to sustainable campuses.

Presentation Title: Green Revolving Reserve and LEED Platinum buildings at the U
Description or Abstract: Poster will explain: - The mechanisms of the U Green revolving Reserve that has been financing close to $1 million in energy efficiency retrofit. - Highlight of the sustainable features of a recently inaugurated LEED platinum building.

Presentation Title: Evolving Building Sustainability: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe Framework Principles
Description or Abstract: Buildings consume 40% of energy globally. As buildings are continuously enhanced to be more sustainable and healthy, a number of strategies have been employed to achieve energy reduction targets. This proposal provides insight into a program developed to engage a globally diverse cohort of next generation professionals in collaborative, immersive, experiential learning dedicated to the advancement of sustainability in the built environment. The program was conducted in a way that builds the capability of participants as agents of evolution with the confidence and direction to make tangible contributions. The goal was to align and expand a community of practitioners while using the built environment as a nodal intervention to develop the capacity of ecological, social, and economic systems that grow the vitality of each place indefinitely. The program involved a cohort of 17 participants from 11 different countries who convened for 6 weeks from July to mid-August 2017. Other elements included research to reveal the unique challenges shared by global communities, hands-on experience with technological interventions and place-based solutions, a critical review of existing policies, and recommendations to enhance sustainability in buildings. The UNECE principles served as an instrument to test place-based solutions. Ireland was selected a case study due to its demonstrated leadership in sustainability for buildings through passive house standards. The program culminated in a meeting with representatives from the UN, Ireland, and other stakeholders in the built environment. Reflection questions, group discussions, and interactive sessions with faculty and industry professionals were used as tools to facilitate participation. Continuous engagement is maintained with the cohort though periodic web-conferences to share ideas and discuss progress on related projects. The program design will be presented including lessons learned and recommendations for future offerings.

Presentation Title: Green Globes Certification: A Practical Approach for Sustainable Campuses
Description or Abstract: Green Globes is an affordable and practical, yet comprehensive nationally recognized sustainability certification for commercial and multifamily buildings. The Green Globes platform was modified and developed through the public, collaborative, consensus-based process guided by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). This presentation will demonstrate how Green Globes serves as a road map for leadership in sustainability for higher education and the ease of use to help create a stronger, more inclusive sustainable campus community. Participants will learn how to empower their project and student representative teams in the pursuit of sustainability for dorms, classroom, and other campus buildings with the comprehensive questionnaires and roadmaps that Green Globes offers. An online evaluation, benchmarking requirements and recertification options hold project teams accountable and support sustainability reporting contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals. Third-party assessors verify each criteria through both paper-based on in-person site visit to confirm compliance and provide value-added recommendations that validate your team's accomplishments. See how Green Globes has been applied and used on university and community college campuses across the United States and Canada. This program maximizes sustainability through a variety of environmental assessment areas, heavily weighting more impactful initiatives leading to lower energy and water bills and increased recycling. Additionally, sustainable buildings provide improved air quality, use fewer chemicals and encourage a healthy indoor environment. Third-party certification of sustainability achievements can be affordable and hassle-free. This presentation will demonstrate through case studies of various college campuses how Green Globes can be used by attendees to implement create interactive on-campus sustainability initiatives confirmed by third-party certification.

Presentation Title: Transforming Existing, Iconic, Landmark Buildings Into Modern, High-Performance Buildings
Description or Abstract: The challenge most universities face today is modernizing building performance (high indoor environmental quality and low energy consumption) cost effectively, while preserving the image of iconic structures dedicated to learning. Rockwell Hall, built in 1957, is a steel-framed building with light-colored stone exterior--similar to what you might see on most college campuses. Dr. Robert Sroufe and Craig Stevenson developed a novel approach to transforming old buildings into high-performance buildings using technology. By combining IES VE whole-building performance modeling, a sustainability master plan and an integrated dashboard, owners can simulate building performance and create an investment plan that reduces risk and maximizes return of a portfolio of buildings. Rockwell Hall shows how early planning and modest investment makes otherwise impossible sustainability goals achievable for any institution. The demonstrations of Passive House EnerPhit for existing buildings, along with RESET standardization for indoor air quality strategies provide a foundation for learning best practices. Various techniques from LEED, Living Building Challenge, The 2030 Challenge and WELL Building Institute add insight and context. For buildings like Rockwell Hall, the most economical and scalable strategies come from utilizing a myriad of attributes from these proven standards. This session is essential for inquisitive and committed leaders responsible for building performance.

Presentation Title: State of Sustainability in Higher Education: Charting a Course for Continued Success
Description or Abstract: Facilities leaders have invested a great deal of effort and financial resources towards pursuing the ideals enumerated in the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals 11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities), 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production), and 13 (Climate Change). In the third annual State of Sustainability Report from Sightlines and University of New Hampshire Sustainability Institute, we highlight sector-wide successes, including improved energy efficiency (at the campus-level) and widespread switching to lower-emissions fuels. We also emphasize some troubling trends related to campus space growth and increased complexity of systems in new construction & renovations. We will begin this presentation with an overview of these sector-wide findings, then shift the focus to a Texas A&M University (TAMU) case study. TAMU has managed to stabilize energy consumption despite significant campus growth. The University has, for many years, reaped the financial rewards of investing in campus infrastructure overhauls and mechanical upgrades. More recently, TAMU began a targeted, engagement-focused project called the Energy Performance Improvement Program (EPI). The goal: to generate energy savings, to mitigate the environmental impacts of complex, new-construction buildings, and to work to generate building occupant enthusiasm. Through EPI, TAMU avoided $450k in annual costs across just 6 buildings. From our State of Sustainability findings and this instructive case study, we will provide a series of recommendations for how institutions can improve sustainability performance of their existing buildings while reducing risk and operating costs on campus.
PositionTitle_1: Associate Vice President for Facilities & Operations

Presentation Title: Optimizing Sustainability Over a Building's Lifecycle
Description or Abstract: From the U.S. Department of Energy Website: 'The higher education sector spends over $6 billion on annual energy costs and totals about 5 billion square feet of floor space.' Higher education buildings have a significant impact on our environment and optimizing buildings' sustainability over their lifecycles can pay dividends. This poster will describe strategies and tools to optimize sustainability through design, construction, occupancy and post-occupancy and present case studies as examples.

Presentation Title: Green Nerds in FM: Building Automation Strategies to Support Sustainability Goals
Description or Abstract: Efficient use of energy is an important part of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 7 of affordable and clean energy. While many building systems efficiency improvements require a capital investment in equipment, there are ways to increase efficiency through programming with little or no additional equipment. We will explore a few programming changes that we have made at Eastern Mennonite University. - Automated HVAC scheduling from the University's room scheduling system - Heating and cooling set points changed based on outdoor air temperature - Water source heat pump loop temperature reset on outdoor air enthalpy.

Presentation Title: Making Positive Impacts With Zero Energy Buildings
Description or Abstract: Zero Energy buildings generate all the energy that they need onsite from renewable sources. Getting there requires significant energy efficiency, onsite renewable energy generation, ongoing occupant engagement, and performance-based energy management. It's also no guarantee. According to a recent New Buildings Institute report, there are currently 67 buildings in North America that have achieved zero energy certification, while an additional 415 buildings are pursuing the certification. This presentation will include discussion and insights from architects and owners of two zero energy buildings-California State University, Northridge's LEED Platinum Sustainability Center and Millersville University's Lombardo Welcome Center-considering everything from design and construction to occupant and student engagement to ongoing performance management. Along the way each building has incorporated other sustainable features, including xeriscaping, gray-water irrigation, onsite stormwater management, and composting toilets, among others.

Presentation Title: Phase Change Materials
Description or Abstract: The phase change material is an easy solution to temperature fluctuations from the weather outside. These materials are a new way to insulate a building. The materials go into the ceiling or wall, trap the heat by turning into a gaseous state, then at night the heat is released and the materials turn into a solid again. The need to use electricity to heat and cool the building is reduced. Northern Arizona University won the Arizona Forwards Innovator Award for their use of the phase change materials. These materials allow buildings to be retrofitted for a low cost.

Presentation Title: The Fossil Fuel Divestment Movement and Student Activism at Syracuse University and SUNY-ESF
Description or Abstract: On April 1, 2015, Syracuse University announced that it would divest its $1.18 billion endowment from fossil fuels. Shortly thereafter, its partner institution, SUNY-ESF, made the same commitment. These moves were immediately praised in global media outlets, with major stories featured prominently in The New York Times and The Guardian (UK). A year later, Syracuse University announced that its fossil-fuel-free endowment was actually exceeding performance expectations. On the surface, this policy move appears to be a rare 'win-win.' Beneath the surface, however, lies a more complex story. Although university administration announced fossil-fuel divestment to the press as a policy decision, it was in fact the result of a sustained three-year campaign of student activism, culminating in an 18-day occupation of Syracuse University's administration building. Analysis of this story, not told in press releases and news outlets, provides us with a richer account of student and administrative environmental decision-making. This presentation is an analysis of in-depth interviews with key actors surrounding the fossil-fuel divestment movement at Syracuse University and SUNY-ESF-students, faculty, staff, and administrators. In this session, we will explain how the fossil-fuel divestment and climate activism movement emerged in this case, analyze its successes and failures from the perspectives of diverse stakeholders, & examine key takeaways with participants.

Presentation Title: Breaking Down 'Drawdown' - Explaining Global Sustainability Solutions at the Community Level
Description or Abstract: There's a new framework for climate action in town - Project Drawdown is self-described as a comprehensive efforts to 'identify, research, and model the 100 most substantive, existing solutions to address climate change.' The Drawdown project team asked what we could achieve if we scaled up existing tools already at hand. They found that by putting the top 100 solutions into practice worldwide, we DO have the power to reverse global warming. Keeping morale high when talking to the average person about climate change is no easy task. Even once people come to terms with the fact that climate change is real and requires urgent action, many still have little confidence in the role, if any, they or their communities can play in reversing global warming. To help connect global solutions to a personal level, the University of Virginia is hosting an event during Earth Week 2018 that brings together UVA leaders doing work around the top 100 Drawdown solutions. These local climate warriors will share with attendees the many ways we are already prepared to reverse climate change, here and now! The really unique thing about the Drawdown framework is that some of the top solutions are quite different than one might expect. Expanding our idea of climate solutions beyond just large-scale renewable energy, allows people working on educating girls (the #6 solution), family planning (#7), reducing food waste (#3), and more to see themselves as change agents for a more resilient planet.

Presentation Title: If I Can Market Manure, You Can Market Anything
Description or Abstract: Practical problem solving with marketing involves more than just visualization or applying the latest techniqual skills. Intuition, domain knowledge, and reasonable approximations can mean the difference between a successful model and a catastrophic failure. We'll dive into some best practices I've extracted from solving marketing problems like design work, the use of social media, trending topics, crowdfunding, and promoting sustainability. computing trending topics, finding related searches, cleaning election data, and ranking experts on social networks.

Presentation Title: Sustainability in Corl Street Elementary School
Description or Abstract: Corl Street Elementary is undergoing a renovation to meet the gold standard LEED Certification. The certification is more likely to be awarded if the school building serves as a teaching tool to communicate ecological, economic, and social aspects of sustainability. We set out to identify which features of the building can fulfill this teaching obligation and how students might encounter the learning opportunities inside and outside the classroom in a non invasive way. We researched Sustainability Theory through the works of David Orr and Wendell Berry, and successful case studies promoted by the Center of Ecological Literacy. We interviewed stakeholders, from parents, to school board members, to administrators, to teachers, in order to understand the curriculum standards and expectations. Embedding sustainability concepts in physical space and curriculum starting in elementary education has a considerable impact on the student attitudes towards environmental concepts, awareness of sustainability problems and possibilities, and evokes a lifelong emotional responsiveness for change.

Presentation Title: How Knowledge Can Create a Culture of Sustainability
Description or Abstract: In the United States, buildings account for nearly 70 percent of electricity consumption. According to the EPA, up to 30 percent of electricity is inefficiently or unnecessarily used. In light of SDGs 11 and 13 this should be considered a great opportunity. Buildings contain a massive amount of data which can be critical to supporting energy efficiency and other sustainability goals. Unfortunately, this data is difficult to access because building technologies are typically complex, siloed and available to a small number of users. Expanding access to this data can have far-reaching benefits to spreading critical knowledge to stakeholders across an organization from sustainability and facilities staff to students, faculty and more. Here from Gonzaga and Northwestern on tactics for creating a culture of sustainability.

Presentation Title: Selling Sustainability: 5 Principles of Persuasion
Description or Abstract: In today's political and social climate, an understanding of the science of persuasion is the most important tool for any environmentalist. Led by two Texas-based sustainability consultants and green building advocates, this presentation will cover five principals of persuasion that merge classical theories of rhetoric with the latest findings in social psychology and neuroscience. Concepts will be explained through hand-drawn illustrations and discussions of success stories and failures drawn from the history of the environmental movement and from presenters' careers as green building advocates in a region that is traditionally hostile towards environmental causes (Texas). The presenters will also introduce attendees to the Reddit forum 'Change My View,' a structured online opportunity to post a view and have it constructively challenged by other users. Finally, based on the methodology of the forum, attendees will practice changing minds in a fun interactive exercise. This presentation is unique in it's delivery - we speak over our own hand-drawn animations of five persuasion principles. Our exercise at the end is also uniquely engaging. It causes attendees to debate an unknown and yet surprisingly controversial topic; it also compels audience members to really think about how open they are to changing their own minds.

Presentation Title: Beyond the Ball: Sustainability Success in Nontraditional Athletics
Description or Abstract: By leveraging sports like synchronized swimming (The Ohio State University), diving (IUPUI), or engaging K-12 students through on-campus sports sustainability games (University of Colorado/University of Louisiana), campuses are able to engage athletes, fans, and the broader community in their pursuit of successful sustainability programs and influence behavioral change among fans at home, work, and play. These programs not only reduce the environmental impact on campus, but also educate the local communities about making more environmentally conscious choices. Implementing sustainability through sports allows campuses to develop a strong platform for sustainability, and impact is broadened when the programs are used to educate fans and communities about contributing to sustainable places where we all live, work, and play. Additionally, SDG's (such as: Good health and well being, sustainable cities and communities, Partnerships for the goals, Responsible consumption and production) can all be exemplified in these programs, and can provide a framework of inspiration and duplication across campuses around the world.

Presentation Title: Green Office Programs and Certifications
Description or Abstract: Green Office Programs can be an effective strategy to engage the campus community by identifying and training allies that may otherwise be out of reach. Engaging sustainability champions can become an essential strategy to expand the capacity of time and resource-strapped sustainability staff. It can also help elevate the resources and initiatives available through campus sustainability programs, doing the necessary work of reaching target audiences that would otherwise be difficult to find in a decentralized university structure. Learn from two universities with mature Green Office Programs who have recently retooled programs with dramatic results. Presentations will cover the foundations of both university's programs, as well as their experiences with revamping and increasing outreach efforts to take these programs to the next level. Presentations outline how the institutions exceeded participation goals through creative incentives, referral programs, and strategic involvement of key university leadership.

Presentation Title: Implementing a Sustainable Living Program on Campus: Encouraging Students to Walk the Talk
Description or Abstract: The Lehigh University Eco-Rep Leadership Program has successfully designed and implemented a Sustainable Living Program where Eco-Reps work with their peers in residential halls and Greek houses to make their living spaces more sustainable. This is a voluntary, self-guided certification process that includes specific questions that address day-to-day living habits in various categories including energy, water, purchasing, recycling, food/dining, and involvement. By taking action in a variety of topic areas, students take the lead to reduce their environmental impact, are responsible stewards of the university's resources, and contribute to Lehigh's sustainability goals and commitments. But how do you get started with a certification program like this? What is the path to designing a successful program? In this session, we will discuss Lehigh University's path to developing a Sustainable Living Program from determining program coordination, the application process, the checklist of actions, the different certification levels and incentives, and program logistics. We will also discuss key lessons learned, best practices, and next steps for expanding the program. Through efforts like this, institutions can increase overall campus engagement, build community, and enhance the culture of sustainability on their campus.

Presentation Title: Transformative Change, the SDGs, and the Future of Sustainability in Higher Education
Description or Abstract: This session uses a panel discussion format to explore transformative change, the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and the future of sustainability in higher education by drawing on the wisdom and insights of a noted panel of campus sustainability thought leaders and practitioners The session builds on a panel organized by Meghan Fay Zahniser for the 2016 AASHE Conference to focus on recent, high-level calls for transformative change in HE-and in particular those by the UN and UNESCO in relation to the UN SDGs (to prepare graduates to play meaningful roles in creating well-being focused societies)-while also addressing barriers and challenges and articulating ways to tunnel through these barriers (both in theory and practice). It will focus on both progress during the past two decades and the significant organizational, curricular, pedagogical, and modeling gaps that currently limit the reach and impact of HE to contribute toward creating well-being societies and meeting the aspirations set forth in the UN SDGs. A special issue of Sustainability: the Journal of Record will be produced that reflects the panel commentary, while more fully developing the ideas and challenges discussed by the panelists and audience. Panelists will be given 1 - 2 key questions in advance to stimulate the conversation. A summary of the Panel will be published in a special issue of Sustainability: the Journal of Record.

Presentation Title: Intersections: Integrating the UN SDGs to On-Campus Living Environments
Description or Abstract: The goal of this presentation is to discuss how on-campus housing programs, in conjunction with academic partnerships & campus sustainability staff, can weave the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into their Campus/Departmental Sustainability Plan and programmatic efforts. Guidance for developing a curriculum plan for academic living-learning programs, sponsorship of diversified campus sustainability programming, and service related student initiatives will be explored during the session. Attendees will have the opportunity to discuss the impact of the political and institutional climate at their home institutions in accomplishing the UN SDGs, as well as the challenge of working across Student Affairs and Sustainability boundaries. The presentation will leave attendees with practical, real-life action points for how to engage in the process of implementing policy and programs that exemplify the UN SDGs.
