Presentation Title: Incorporating Environmental Justice Into Peer Mentor Programs
Description or Abstract: Many of us have been grappling with the question of how to intentionally incorporate environmental justice into higher education sustainability work. This session will identify key areas where a holistic vision of sustainability, one where sustainability is understood to be the intersection of human health, social equity, protecting ecology, and economic vitality, can be applied to peer mentor education programs. Through my work as the Coordinator of Western Washington University's Sustainability Representative Program, I have found that peer mentor programs often tend to focus on the ecological aspects of sustainability. Western Washington University's peer mentor program has been evolving over the past few years to better reflect this intersectional vision of sustainability that we strive towards. Using Western's Sustainability Representative Program as a case study, attendees will understand how to apply concepts into peer mentor programs to foster a more inclusive and justice based program. At the end of the session, attendees will have a deeper understanding of environmental justice and be able to identify areas in their own programs where ideas of environmental justice can be incorporated.

Presentation Title: Environmental Justice Grant Funding: Piloting Equity Efforts in Campus Green Funds
Description or Abstract: The Green Initiative Fund (TGIF) at UC Berkeley has a 10-year history of funding environmental sustainability projects for its campus community; however, the program has not specifically prioritized environmental justice (EJ) components to environmentalism until more recently. In an effort to address equity and inclusion, TGIF Staff and its governing Committee chose to pilot an environmental justice thematic grant cycle in the Spring 2018 semester. Modeled after the EPA's Environmental Justice Small Grants Program, TGIF's thematic grant cycle required forming a Planning Committee of students and a variety of collaborative discussions in order to define EJ, the thematic grant cycle's purpose statement, and eligibility for student organizations and departments on a college campus. In this session, UC Berkeley will share its lessons learned and best practices around hosting a thematic EJ grant cycle via a reductive model in the hopes of inspiring other college campuses to begin critically thinking about and applying environmental justice throughout their offered environmental programs and services. As part of UC Berkeley's Student Environmental Resource Center (SERC), TGIF has begun operationalizing tenets of EJ into its grant cycle through a multi-phase & multi-tiered grant review process that privileges historically underrepresented groups. This falls in line with a Strategic Organizational Goal (SOG) of SERC focused on thinking about and implementing equity and inclusion.

Presentation Title: Instilling Professional Development Into Eco-Reps Programs
Description or Abstract: This presentation will present key areas where you can grow professional development within your Eco-reps program, drawing on experience at four institutions of higher education. We will cover why it's critical to incorporate professional development into Eco-reps programs in today's world both for the benefit of your students and for the success of your program. We will also cover methods that can be used, including the role of expectations, contracts, soft skill building, goal setting, metrics, leadership opportunities and curriculum. The curriculum discussion will include the role that knowledge of SDGs can play in teaching about larger economic forces and the resulting professional opportunities. Join us to help learn how to make your program more meaningful for students and help them be better prepared for the job market.

Presentation Title: Visual Storytelling for Sustainability: Raising Your Game in Photo and Video
Description or Abstract: Do you struggle to take photos that look 'professional' rather than run-of-the-mill? Is the idea of making a video, or even the occasional Boomerang clip, intimidating? In short, are quality visual stories lacking from your sustainability communications? Visual storytelling has redefined the world of communications in recent years. New content sharing platforms, advances in cell phone and digital camera technology, and the broader cultural shift toward digital media means that quality photography and videography are crucial tools. While the majority of us are comfortable with the basic functions on our phones and digital cameras, it's not uncommon for sustainability programs to hire professionals for the occasional visual storytelling and documentation projects that 'really matter.' Given varying budgets and staffing, however, this solution is not always feasible. Moreover, inconsistencies in visual content are immediately apparent to our increasingly sophisticated and discerning audiences. In this session, we will seek to empower participants to achieve better overall quality in their visual content. We'll discuss concrete ways in which non-professionals can improve their photography and videography skills, as well as offer activities in which attendees can practice in small groups. Alongside dedicated storytelling projects, we will cover strategies for social media, websites, and internal documentation.

Presentation Title: Graphic Design Strategies for Sustainability
Description or Abstract: Graphic designers can create positive change by integrating sustainability into their work. Graphic design is often not a sustainable practice, even so, sustainable design guidelines can reduce its impact. Energy, water, paper, inks, solvents and packaging are used, but designing for originality rather than size, using optimum print jobs, avoiding full-bleed prints, picking chlorine free paper, buying from environmentally friendly paper suppliers, buying VOC-free printing ink, prototyping, and making clients aware of sustainable design guidelines are all methods that support sustainable design. In my presentation, I will outline how sustainability relates to design and how offices in higher education can make decisions with sustainability in mind. As a designer, I must consider the audience of the design. At the WMU Office for Sustainability, we make graphics that relate complex ideas in a clear, pictorial fashion. For example, we have created a graphic relating to Learning for Sustainability Core Competencies; this is conceptual, but it delivers the information in a clear and concise manner. Our process of graphic design employs high levels of active social learning, group brainstorming, sketching of concepts, creating prototypes, and open critiques until we arrive at a rich and compelling graphic. I will show examples of our most recent designs, how we arrived at the final product, and stories about what we learned along the way.

Presentation Title: Sustainability Week: A Case Study in Diversity of Programing to Maximize Outreach Across Barriers
Description or Abstract: The College of Charleston's Office of Sustainability has had several flagship programs and series over the years, but none near the scale and dynamism of the annual Sustainability Week. The goal of this Networking Meeting is to use Sustainability Week, and the planning and programming that accompanies it, as a case study in maximizing outreach and engagement throughout the campus community, taking into account the narrow public perception towards sustainability and the barriers incumbent in achieving campus-wide appeal among the myriad often insular and competing interests at a liberal arts university. The Office instituted Sustainability Week its first academic year in existence, Spring 2012, and over the ensuing years has benefited from consistent evolutions and explorations into various formats, target groups, and scopes for its events. This networking meeting will draw from, reflect upon, and compare upwards of one hundred unique events over seven years, ranging from keynotes from notable academics such as Vandana Shiva to student-implemented workshops. Utilizing visual aids and handouts to supplement discussion, we aim to engage participants in a thorough conversation about the pros and cons of various formats, logistics, impediments, etc. that go into planning and implementing major multi-day events such as Sustainability Week. This will facilitate sharing perspectives from participants and provide recommendations to be to taken back to home institutions. While actively soliciting questions and additional perspectives, we will delve into issues such as the spacing of events throughout the day and week, budgeting, how to build campus and interdepartmental/interoffice coalitions and collaborations, how to entice the 'uninitiated' on campus, navigating potential campus conflicts and politics when approaching sensitive or controversial topics, and challenge previously held conceptions of sustainability to expand understanding among the general population.

Presentation Title: Learning From the Past to Inform the Future: Leveraging Campus-Community Partnerships With Dialogue
Description or Abstract: Achieving complex sustainable development goals that integrate human and natural systems, including health and wellbeing as well as sustainable cities and communities, requires open and transparent collaboration with stakeholders. At Slippery Rock University of Pennsylvania, a World Café was utilized to bolster stakeholder partnerships and collaboratively re-envision the mission of the Robert A. Macoskey Center for Sustainable Systems Education and Research. The World Café is a creative dialogic process that facilitates a platform for everyone's voice to be heard. This approach provided a unique and innovative way for us to engage a broad diversity of stakeholders from Slippery Rock University and the surrounding community during a time of leadership transition at the Robert A. Macoskey Center. Collaborative input from students, faculty, staff, and community members allowed our leadership team to both learn from the past and focus future directions on shared goals. Results, such as the need to transition from planning to action and the need to expand interdisciplinary educational and employment opportunities at Slippery Rock University, are being used to guide the direction of research, outreach, and educational programming. In this workshop, we will share best practices, lessons learned, and next steps from our World Café experience. These have helped to better align our teaching and research activities at Slippery Rock University around the sustainable development goals. In addition, we will engage participants in a World Café simulation so that they will learn how to facilitate their own World Café session to gather information that leverages sustainable development goals on their campuses and in their communities.

Presentation Title: Undergrads as Consultants: Sharing Strategies and Experiences From a Student Intern Program
Description or Abstract: The UW-Madison Office of Sustainability (OS) employs student interns year-round to work on campus sustainability projects. The model for their efforts is one of consultation; the students serve as a resource for other entities on campus. By adopting this model, we are able to tailor our programs and projects to address the specific needs or goals of each client. Historically, the office has been comprised of two teams: the Waste and Recycling team, and the Green Office team. Both teams have targeted sustainability goals through direct engagement with various campus partners. The Waste and Recycling team has worked with dining and residence halls in an effort to reduce the amount of material sent to landfill by cleaning up waste streams. Meanwhile, through our Green Office Certification Program, the Green Office team gives UW-Madison employees the information and tools they need to learn about sustainability, better understand the impacts of their practices, and create healthy and sustainable work environments. These programs have been very successful and as a result, the OS is now expanding our efforts to other parts of campus. In keeping with the model of intern consultants, the new Green Labs team will develop its own certification program that will allow us to partner with labs on campus to help them pursue sustainable practices.

Presentation Title: Sustainability Surveys for Program Enhancement
Description or Abstract: For this session, panelists from Indiana State University (ISU), The College of Charleston (CofC), Ramapo College of New Jersey, California State University San Bernardino (CSUSB), Colorado State University (CSU), Lehigh University (LU), and Minnesota State University-Moorhead will walk the audience through the steps needed to successfully design, implement, and use the data from a sustainability survey. Each presenter offers a unique perspective on sustainability surveying - making this session applicable to all varieties of institutions. Presenters from LU and Ramapo will discuss the processes of designing a sustainability survey, they will share experiences both designing a survey internally and working with an outside firm to design a survey. CSUSB and CSU will discuss how to successfully implement a sustainability survey on a college campus. ISU and CofC will be discussing different ways to effectively use data attained from surveys. The last 20 minutes of the session will be used to answer any questions and/or to expand on any ideas talked about throughout the presentation.

Presentation Title: #stopsucking: Leveraging Coalitions to Turn #strawlesssummer into an Endless Summer
Description or Abstract: Approximately 630000 straws are used daily in Charleston, South Carolina. This single-use plastic often finds its way to the environment. Local branches of national organizations such as Surfrider, Lonely Whale, and 5 Gyres paired with The Greater Charleston Restaurant Association, Charleston Bartenders Guild, and Plastic-free Lowcountry to take a stand against single-use plastic by creating a campaign during which Charleston restaurants pledge to only give out straws upon request. The Strawless Summer campaign runs annually Memorial Day through Labor Day and aims to decrease plastic pollution. The College of Charleston (CofC) has pledged to be zero waste by 2030. Part of going zero waste means removing non-reusable items from campus, including plastic straws, bags, and food packaging. The biggest contaminants around campus are coffee cups, lids, and straws. According to September 2017 sales data at CofC's Starbucks, 1200 straws were distributed per week; meaning these 1200 straws could end up harming wildlife and humans due to environmental pollution. Modeled after the Strawless Summer Campaign, Strawless Week 2018 was spearheaded by CofC's Office of Sustainability in partnership with Healthy Human, Alliance for Planet Earth, GoPure Pod, Aramark, CofC's Dining Services, and CofC's SGA. During the campaign, reusable straws, water bottles, coffee cups, and other free items were distributed to Starbucks visitors in addition to information about plastic pollution. During this event, Starbucks offered their 'sippy lids' for their cold beverages instead of the classic lid and straw. The purpose of this event was to raise awareness about the pervasive single-use plastic issue on CofC's campus and in the greater Charleston community. After the event, the number of plastic and reusable straws used were quantified and compared to historical data based on September Starbucks' sales report to see how many plastic straws were 'saved'.

Presentation Title: Campus Controversies: How Should Sustainability Offices Respond?
Description or Abstract: Election results, sexual misconduct allegations, racist graffiti, controversial op-eds, poorly worded emails are resulting in cycles of anger, backlash, emotional release, exhaustion and division on many of our campuses. At Dartmouth, for example, a January 2018 op-ed published by a male student, speculating that his rejection from a leadership position was due to his gender, set off a cycle like this on our campus. As an office focused on training student leaders, equipping them with the skills to effect organizational change, and educating them about how sustainability is intersectional with justice issues, and with student interns involved on both sides, we felt obligated to respond. These moments are important learning opportunities for students. In the case at Dartmouth, we had an opportunity to explore issues such as how and when identity should be part of a hiring process, the role of media in cultural discussion, conversation across radical difference, empathy and what it means to 'be in solidarity' not just in words, but in actions. Each cycle of campus conflict provides moments that can foster discussion, learning and skills building. They also can be exhausting, overwhelming and disempowering. In this session, we will collectively explore the role of Sustainability Offices in these cycles and talk about whether, when and how our offices engage.

Presentation Title: Green in a Red State: Working Towards Sustainable Development Goals in a Conservative Environment
Description or Abstract: The era of Trump may have officially begun on in 2017, but Trump era ideas on issues of sustainability, inclusion & equity have existed in parts of the country for some time. Citizens, political & academic leaders in red states have held similar views of climate change & the UN Sustainable Development Goals since their inception. As sustainability staff, faculty & students in these places, how do we move forward with the work that needs to get done in these climates while avoiding the pitfalls of burnout & discouragement? In many ways, ultra-conservative environments have become one front line for sustainability work, as the necessity for change & innovation becomes more important, & the risks of falling behind nationally & globally are ever increasing. This session will focus on the experience of the presenters and attendees in order to create a blueprint for working on sustainability issues in red states and cities. The presenters will engage with participants through group work in order to create an outline for developing coalitions, recruiting students, staff & faculty, shifting culture & engaging with decision makers who may be hesitant to support the cause due to personal conviction or political ramifications. The goals of the discussion are twofold: to problem solve & exchange ideas, and to create a group of individuals who are working in these 'front line' states. This group will meet virtually regularly post-conference to create a community of sustainability-minded individuals.
PositionTitle_1: Asst Dir. Sustainability and Alternative Transportation

Presentation Title: Wrestling With the Invisibility Cloak: Catalyzing Student Action and Creating Office Recognition
Description or Abstract: As sustainability officer's we often lead from behind, supporting students as a silent or invisible partner. This enables them to bring awareness to issues and take ownership over the changes they seek. In fact, one could argue that without this approach we reduce the impact and educational benefit of our work. However, this approach also means much of our work goes unnoticed to the general campus community, making it difficult to sustain change and build the recognition needed to obtain higher-level support within our institutions. Many of us struggle with the right approach to ensure both of these goals are met: empowering and educating students (and sometimes other staff and faculty) to take action, and recognition of (and equivalent resource allocation to) the Sustainability Office. Furthermore, when much of our success is tied to quantitative reductions in energy use or greenhouse gas emissions, it can be challenging to express the benefit on the qualitative work we do. This session will be a chance to have an open and frank discussion about this problem, with a goal of collecting both best practices and common challenges that we can share with each other after the session. Some schools have identified ways to strike this balance, while others have examples of projects that didn't succeed in meeting both goals.

Presentation Title: Acts of Art for the Environment
Description or Abstract: In Sustainable Earth, there are two different project groups, one focusing on the intersection of environmentalism and technology, the other on environmental art. My poster will focus on how art can be utilized on college campuses to promote environmental issues, and the challenges that one might face when embarking on similar projects. The history of college students and activism is long, and has brought about great change. The purpose of this poster presentation is to help inspire other students that may be artistically-inclined environmentalist or environmentally-conscious artists. Specifically, the poster will discuss Sustainable Earth's most recent art project, 'What's Your Plastic Footprint?' as a model for how activism art works on campus outside of the art school and its resources.

Presentation Title: Partnering With Purpose: Curating Sustainability Leadership With Staff, Students, and Faculty
Description or Abstract: During the 2017 academic year, the Office of Sustainability at our university partnered with two AmeriCorps volunteers to create the Student Sustainability Leadership Program and the Employee Sustainability Ambassadors Program. The creation of these programs was inspired by a desire for greater campus collaboration around sustainability. Through eight, two-hour sessions focused upon regional characteristics, participants in each program were able to identify and discuss sustainability issues encountered in their departments, offices, classes, and even residence halls. The primary purpose of these two programs was not to create new projects or campaigns, but rather to foster a unified understanding and engagement around sustainability. These programs expanded upon our commitment to sustainable action and increased campus engagement in the activities of the Office of Sustainability, growing our ability to foster change. These programs were unique in creating platforms for sustainability literacy and discussion for all members of campus, helping any member of campus become a change agent for sustainability. Attendees in this session will learn about how to approach the development of such programs, consider key takeaways gained within the first year, and discuss how the UN Sustainable Development goals can be applied to further the programs' impacts on campus and in the community.

Presentation Title: Facilitation for Organizational Change
Description or Abstract: One of the most important, yet often under-appreciated, skill sets of any profession is the ability to be a strong group meeting facilitator. Whether it is a small staff meeting or a campus-wide strategic planning effort, being a confident and effective facilitator is essential. So, what does it mean to be a strong facilitator? What are concrete tools one can use to lead a group decision-making process? Part I will include facilitation refresher activities designed to guide participants through the important steps in group facilitation. The group will be able to test their knowledge of important tools that can help groups generate new ideas as well as help them converge those ideas into actionable next steps. Through fun and interactive activities, participants will be challenged to apply the tools they learn with these engaging, hands-on experiences. In Part II, participants will have ample time to practice facilitate meetings using tried and proven techniques and to receive constructive feedback from the group in a safe environment. There will also be time for group discussion where collectively the group will share new ideas as well as help converge those ideas into actionable next steps. This workshop, which is an essential tool in the UN SDG No. 17: 'Partnerships for the Goals' and will strengthen the capacity to accomplish Goals 1-16.

Presentation Title: Fostering Sustainability Culture on an Irish Campus, Lessons Learned from UCC's Green Campus Journey
Description or Abstract: This session will tell the story of University College Cork's experience in embedding sustainability on campus over the last decade. This journey has taken UCC from a student-led campaign to become a 'Green Flag' campus in 2007, to the university signing up to the STARS programme in 2018. UCC was the pilot university for the 'Green Flag' programme, which is now being run in 14 countries worldwide by the Foundation for Environmental Education. This programme is operationally focused, taking the university through an environmental management system across themes corresponding to the most significant environmental aspects. Following the publication of the Sustainable Development Goals in 2015, the university recognised the need to take a broader approach, and in 2016 UCC's Sustainability Strategy was published broadening the focus to areas such as engaged citizenship and health and wellbeing. In 2017, a Sustainability Officer was appointed (one of only two such positions across the entire higher education sector in Ireland). In 2018, the University commences its first STARS submission. The bottom-up approach of the Green Campus campaign, combined with high-level commitment, has resulted in a culture change throughout the university. This session will outline the differences in 'landscape' between the US and Ireland, and how institutions in both regions might learn from one another. We will describe what was learned in implementing the Green Campus programme in UCC.

Presentation Title: Creating Sustainability Director Position for Student Body Government (poster)
Description or Abstract: In the spring of 2017, University of Minnesota Duluth (UMD) student Dave Herrera proposed to UMD Student Association (UMDSA) to create a Student Director Of Sustainability. After much discussion and student interest, the motion passed, creating and electing Dave Herrera as the Student Director of Sustainability for UMDSA. Here, Herrera explains what the steps, actions, and discussions were that needed to happen in order to convince and explain why a student director was needed. Herrera also explains his goals and hopes for the future, his first order of business, as well as his experience as the first Director. He will also elaborate on his goals and aspirations for directors to come.

Presentation Title: Creating a Sustainability Director Position for the Student Body Government (presentation)
Description or Abstract: In the spring of 2017, University of Minnesota Duluth (UMD) student Dave Herrera proposed to UMD Student Association (UMDSA) to create a Student Director Of Sustainability. After much discussion and student interest, the motion passed, creating and electing Dave Herrera as the Student Director of Sustainability for UMDSA. Here, Herrera explains what the steps, actions, and discussions were that needed to happen in order to convince and explain why a student director was needed. Herrera also explains his goals and hopes for the future, his first order of business, as well as his experience as the first Director. He will also elaborate on his goals and aspirations for directors to come.

Presentation Title: GreenTech LIU: A Digital Platform for Campus SDG Collaboration
Description or Abstract: Sustainability and education for global citizenship are essential literacies for the 21st century. LIU Post's Center for Sustainability wants faculty and students to have powerful and effective digital tools for strengthening these literacies in classroom learning and research experiences. GreenTech LIU (GTLIU) will provide an integrated digital platform for faculty and students to collaborate on the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) with an emphasis on local and global citizenship projects. Education for global citizenship serves as a center axis that can help to integrate sustainability activities across university campuses. While many SDG projects will be grounded in local experiences and applications, it is important for universities to explore the cross-cultural and international dimensions of the SDGs. GTLIU will provide a campus hub for faculty and student social media engagement. GTLIU will allow students to track their ecological footprints; explore digital apps; and post videos, photos, and blogs. Digital platforms provide new interactive tools for student learning, research, assessment, and advancement of SDG goals. This can significantly expand the networks of faculty who integrate the SDGs into their teaching and research practices. In the United States, the UN SDGs are not prominent in university culture. Through the development of an accelerator model, the Center for Sustainability will bring dozens of LIU faculty members into communication and collaboration around the UN SDGs and strengthen the university's SDG culture. The accelerator model identifies and tracks campus leaders (or change agents) who are trained to mentor and support new faculty in our campus SDG network of interdisciplinary co-learners. After introducing this digital platform, the speakers will engage audience members in an interactive exercise to explore the benefits of GTLIU for other universities.

Presentation Title: An Environmental Sustainability Badge Program Using Co-Curricular and Community Service Learning
Description or Abstract: Integrating environmental sustainability community service learning into curriculum requires faculty, staff, and community engagement. Students and faculty that are passionate about implementing change in the community are developing mutually beneficial project partnerships beyond the campus. This requires collaboration and organization between the environmental sustainability office, faculty, and community partners. Central Community College's badge program empowers and rewards community stakeholders and students to support, build, and grow sustainability practices across multi-campus communities. With a combination of identified courses and co-curricular community projects, students can be officially awarded a badge on their transcript. These badges verify that the student has various sustainability skills that are applicable across diverse academic disciplines, foster community engagement towards a sustainable projects and education, and they gain exposure to local, regional, and national employers. Building the badge program after the initial pilot year in 2016-17 has increased the success of grant applications for environmental sustainability projects, connected staff better with faculty, and resulted in increased community partnerships and student engagement. This presentation will discuss our challenges and successes after our first pilot year of the badge program. The successes include increased service learning projects, community partnerships, and volunteer opportunities.

Presentation Title: Sustainabili-TEA: The Evolution and Efficacy of Podcasts as a Medium for Sustainability Literacy
Description or Abstract: The Office of Sustainability has seen a strong response to using Podcasts to highlight stories, perspectives, and information to the campus and greater community. The efforts were first introduced as part of an initiative modeled after NPR's StoryCorps in which subjects were interviewed about their relationship to place and the College. The lessons learned from this effort informed the creation of a designated Podcast Lead Intern position. That position today continues and has evolved over several semesters. The current format is a weekly podcast including profiles of fellow interns and Office staff to highlight the work of the Office. This has grown to include members outside the campus community, and expanded in format to include 'Sustainabili-TEA,' an informal conversation series held over a selection of tea. This initiative has successfully captured the millennial and youth affinity for Podcasts, and New Media generally, by adopting an already thriving format and focusing on condensed information and compelling content. It has offered tremendous outreach potential to the on and off campus community, not necessarily prone to sustainability literacy through more traditional mediums. This poster presentation hopes to illustrate the efficacy similar programs could have at other campuses, and to provide guidance on how best to establish and implement them. The poster will include the following: -A description of the motivation for creating podcasts through the Office of Sustainability -Details about each subsection of podcast topics -An examination of what makes podcasts an effective medium for spreading information -Details about what the Lead Intern personally gained from conducting and editing interviews -Tips on how to replicate the program at other campuses -Explication on all the above.

Presentation Title: Co-Curricular Learning and Sustainable Development Competencies: Towards Research Collaboration
Description or Abstract: This session will enable participants to compare and contrast practice and identify opportunities and challenges to developing students' competencies to address the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) via co-curricular activity. The session offers a distinctive contribution by both its thematic content (bringing together the themes of Co-Curricular Learning, Competencies and the SDGs) and its intended focus on international knowledge exchange leading to potential collaborative research projects. The Co-curriculum can be viewed as structured student learning experiences that sit outside of taught programmes. Potential sites of co-curricular learning include student societies, volunteering experiences, educational visits, work-based placements, mentoring sessions and study skills support. Competencies are widely recognised as a key enabler of action for sustainable development and include reflective capabilities, systemic thinking and transdisciplinary collaborative working. Such competencies can be developed via action learning through real-world projects, making co-curricular activity an effective complement to taught courses. The national, local and institutional context in which co-curricular activities are developed plays a key role in shaping what is feasible and effective.
PositionTitle_1: Senior Lecturer, Institute of Energy and Sustainable Development

Presentation Title: Using the Campus as a Living Laboratory: The Think 80:20 Recycling Program at Deerfield Academy
Description or Abstract: Many institutions struggle to integrate recycling and organics collections broadly across their campuses. In 2013, Deerfield Academy re-booted its traditional recycling program and began to implement composting out into the campus beyond the dining halls. Today, under the branding of our 'Think 80|20' program, Deerfield strives to emulate the San Francisco goal of diverting 80% of its waste from landfills. We will discuss our vision, share details of the roll-out, and discuss lessons learned from perspectives of community education and student engagement. A particular emphasis will be placed on our composting program which now has collection stations in nearly every academic building on campus, and has been a special opportunity for student programming and projects. One case study will explore student efforts to extend composting from two to eighteen dormitories.

Presentation Title: Fast-tracking a Comprehensive Responsible Leadership Initiative Highlighting the UN 2030 SDGs
Description or Abstract: The College of Business Administration at Kent State University became an advanced signatory to PRME and an associate member of GRLI in Spring 2017. We introduced our Responsible Leadership Initiative (RLI) in Fall 2017, which promotes business as a force for good and utilizes the United Nations 2030 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to provide a framework and common language for educating students and involving faculty and staff. The RLI is supported by the College's core values of respect, ethics, collaboration and a sense of purpose in all we do. Our SDG awareness campaign creatively targeted students and faculty. Students were introduced to the SDG's through social media (Snapchat), participative iconography (SDG Banner & tiles) and a variety of reinforcement activities in the classroom. We created a SDG focused student group (oikos / Net Impact), SDG focused international student trips (France, Greece, India), an RLI website and a new leadership minor incorporating the SDGs. We informed faculty of their collective teaching efforts and SDG-related research, and hosted a faculty workshop with a panel of corporate sustainability professionals and a student delegate to the United Nations. Moving forward, the College will continue to fuel this momentum by engaging the professional community through incorporating the SDGs in College sponsored events and promoting the benefits of hiring students with a strong focus and understanding of sustainable development.
Tags: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs),Principles for Responsible Management Education
PositionTitle_1: Associate Dean. College of Business Administration

Presentation Title: Changemaker Maps: A Roadmap to Transform Your Backyard and Your World
Description or Abstract: How ASU is leveraging 17 global goals as a framework to reach beyond the choir, transcend disciplines, connect with communities, and catalyze social change. Want to create change, but not sure where to start? Changemaker Maps helps students explore resources, learn new ideas, and connect with organizations/people both across the institution and the broader community; launching their ideas into action more effectively. Leveraging the UN Sustainable Development as a framework, Changemaker Central @ ASU has been able to reach beyond the typical 'green crowd', map 'what is', and identify new partnership opportunities. Changemaker Central @ ASU exists to create a university wide culture that empowers students to apply their passion, knowledge and expertise to create innovative solutions to local, national and global challenges. We do this by providing the opportunities and resources to inspire, catalyze and sustain student-driven social change through community service, high impact careers and social entrepreneurship. We believe in the power of student-led, staff supported. Join us for a dialog of how global goals can tap the your university's collective knowledge, expertise, and resources to spark local change through your students.

Presentation Title: Placed-based Education in Co-Curricular Programs: Bringing Global Goals to Local Places
Description or Abstract: Placed-based education has been a core component of the sustainability across the curriculum movement for more than 10 years. However, applying sense of place to co-curricular learning has made less progress among sustainability professionals in higher education. As we rise to the challenge of the achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), we need practical applications of these goals in our local sustainability education programs. Dickinson College has developed innovative long-term and short-term programs for students that exemplify place-based learning that connects with global SDGs, outside the classroom. The presentation will highlight a three day, sustainability-focused pre-orientation and first year mentor program, and an experiential learning series, 'Exploring Our Place'. Both of these programs have successfully translated Global SDG's to practical, local co-curricular learning experiences through places, people, and processes. These learning models can be replicated by any institution looking to use local resources and issues as a way to engage students in the environmental, economic and social challenges facing our world. Place-based education is a proven pedagogy that has helped Dickinson connect experiences outside the classroom to our successful sustainability across the curriculum initiative. This session will leave participants brainstorming ways to utilize 'place' as a way to strengthen existing co-curricular sustainability programs.
Tags: experiential learning,sense of place,Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)

Presentation Title: The Campus-Community Urban Sustainability Program at LIU Brooklyn
Description or Abstract: The Brooklyn campus of Long Island University (LIU) has recently established a Campus-Community Urban Sustainability Program (CUSP) with the support of a Humanities Connections grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities. CUSP is an interdisciplinary initiative that seeks to cultivate consciousness, education, and ethical and civic engagement among all our community members, especially undergraduate students, in order to address sustainability issues as local and global citizens. The program has three main features: (1) an integrated set of courses in four disciplines (biology, English, philosophy, and adolescent education); (2) experiential learning opportunities for students through internships, service learning, and research with community collaborators; and (3) spaces and opportunities for dialogue with the campus and community. CUSP at LIU Brooklyn particularly focuses on sustainability issues associated with environmental degradation, health and wellness concerns, and social inequities that are often exacerbated in urban settings. Here we share our progress and plans, and give special attention to the unique opportunities and challenges of establishing a sustainability program on an urban campus.

Presentation Title: Northern Arizona University Sustainable Citizens Program
Description or Abstract: We have been quite concerned about the general lack of climate science and sustainability knowledge that students have when they graduate from higher education institutions. We know that climate change is the world's greatest global challenge and that understanding the basic science behind it, as well as the three tenets of sustainability, can contribute to its remediation. NAU is rising to the challenge of addressing this gap in higher education by creating the Sustainable Citizens Program (SCP). After we identified a need to provide basic sustainability education and empowerment to students from all majors, we researched AASHE's website, other universities, and talked to peers. We couldn't find an existing program that meets these needs, so we created the innovative SCP. We are confident SCP can be used in universities across the country. After launching SCP last year we made it in the AASHE Bulletin, and universities from across the nation showed curiosity about it. SCP is a unique, interdisciplinary program that prepares students to take on sustainability challenges as individuals, community members, and professionals. Students who complete the program will have a new credential for their resume and the know-how to tackle issues of sustainability in their future profession and life. During our session, we will explain the need for the program, the behind-the-scenes details of student registration through a CMS system and Blackboard hosting, details of the 'Program Path' (also found at nau.edu/scp), content of the two required seminars (which focus on the three tenets of sustainability: social justice, economic health, and environmental stewardship), and program marketing. SCP is addressing the challenge of preparing our students to be globally aware and engaged in sustainability. It is our dream that one day, every college/university will have their own version of an SCP and that employers will expect sustainability credentials such as this on a resume.

Presentation Title: Recapturing the Learning Opportunities of University Sustainability Indicators
Description or Abstract: In the 1990s students conducted campus environmental audits and assessments, which were often the first step towards improving university environmental practices and creating sustainability programs. These audits, often conducted as class projects, capstone projects or theses, gave students agency in a significant environmental issue, and they provided integrative, compelling, and collaborative environmental learning experiences. Today, university sustainability ratings and rankings are largely developed by organizations outside universities, with data provided by university administrators. Hundreds of colleges and universities participate in the Sustainability Tracking, Assessment and Rating System (STARS) administered by the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education (AASHE), posting information in 70 categories in public reports. Environmental Studies and Sciences (ESS) faculty and students can participate in the process of assessing university sustainability by producing their own sustainability indicator reports from the STARS data. A literature of sustainability indicators, particularly the work of Donella Meadows, describes indicators from a systems thinking perspective and explores how the selection of indicators can change system behavior by providing missing feedback or influencing a system's goals. It describes an inclusive process for developing indicators to ensure they will be meaningful to the larger community.

Presentation Title: Integrating Participatory Action Research Into Internships and Outreach - Univ of Illinois at Chicago
Description or Abstract: The University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) is Chicago's only public research university with 30,000 students, 15 colleges, a hospital and a health sciences system. This session introduces Participatory Action Research (PAR) methods in the context of UIC's sustainability internship program focused on providing information about energy, conservation, and new 'smart' grid technology to the campus and community. PAR methods help identify high-priority problems, potential solutions, and create a sense of assurance that solutions are useful to constituents. The Illinois Sustainability and Energy Innovation Foundation funded this research which helps achieve UN Sustainable Development Goal 7 of affordable and clean energy. The Year 1 program included a train-the-trainer piece using education and outreach to engage our student body. Students conducted interviews with primarily fellow students and some faculty. They used their findings to develop a set of tools to engage students including an 'EcoPong' game, videos, table displays, and an energy calculator. In Year 2, students dived deeper by shadowing various employees at work. They expanded their understanding of a number of campus units, departments and organizations whose core-work, mission and values already align with sustainability issues, especially as they relate to energy use and conservation. The latest program has three major components. The students participated in three existing student-focused events to engage students. The second piece was holding ten learning lunches with campus departments. The third piece is a remaking of the concept of an energy saving competition into a quiz. We will discuss how we used the results of these efforts. Through all of this work, the Office of Sustainability has come to learn that the most successful sustainability outreach programs are those that integrate into already existing programs and engage community members through what they care most about.

Presentation Title: Improving Inclusivity at Campus Farmers Market and Garden
Description or Abstract: The University of Utah Sustainability Office coordinates an on-campus farmers market and two edible garden sites that provide students, faculty, staff, and community members with local, healthy, and sustainable food. Produce from the gardens is sold at the University of Utah Farmers Market, a campus staple located outside the Union building where it receives an estimated 5,000 walkthroughs each market. As community-based food grows in demand, how do we ensure these opportunities are inclusive? And how do we ensure that spaces and events are inviting to people of all backgrounds to create sustainable, inclusive communities? These questions led the Sustainability Office, in partnership with an environmental justice community-engaged learning course, to evaluate who was actually attending its farmers markets and to ask questions about the types of foods grown at its garden locations. At this session, review steps taken by the Sustainability Office to define and understand inclusivity issues at the U of U Farmers Market and Edible Campus Gardens and our plan to address them.

Presentation Title: Sustainability, Equity & Inclusivity: Diversifying the Conversation
Description or Abstract: Sustainability Weekend is a conference organized by graduate and undergraduate students from various departments at CMU. This year's theme, 'Sustainability, Inclusivity & Equity' seeks to expand the scope of environmental sustainability, bringing people to the table who would not normally engage with one another. Environmental stewardship requires deliberate collaborations across disciplines, socio-economic backgrounds, ages, and lifestyles. Throughout the planning process students reflected on how to become allies for people unlike themselves by considering the accessibility of the event and the limitations to participation. A primary goal was to build lasting relationships that bridge disciplines and the campus-community divide in a way that fosters continued dialogue beyond the event. By engaging students with different viewpoints, an emphasis was placed on constructive conversations outside of an echochamber. Panels on foodscapes, transportation, community resilience, and technology were curated to ensure diverse stakeholder representation to foster interdisciplinary perspectives. Participants include academic researchers, industry, local community advocates, start-ups and policy makers as well as speakers addressing the environmental reality of native communities and climate communication in faith-based spaces. In addition, a 'learning lunch' is organized with local vendors which serves as an example of how to support sustainability efforts within the local community.
PositionTitle_1: Materials Science and Engineering & Engineering and Public Policy Double Major

Presentation Title: Urban Emerald
Description or Abstract: Four miles from Manhattan on 25 acres in Jersey City is the nearly 150 year old Saint Peter's University..A United Nations NGO, SPU has a Jesuit, Catholic mission committed to sustainable practices. With energy efficient upgrades back to 2003, the University's president signed ACUPCC (now Climate Leadership Network) in 2008 and the Catholic Climate Covenant in 2016. Since 2012, the Sustainability Council, consisting of students, faculty, and staff, shepherds the many programs, events,& activities that focus on sustainability and well-being of SPU & the surrounding community. The Council collaborates with SAVE (Students Against Violating the Earth), academic departments, offices, local and statewide organizations. In 2015 Pope Francis issued the encyclical Laudato Si' calling us to care for our common home. Through its Ignatian pedagogy, service, & social justice, SPU seeks to fulfill this philosophy in and out of its classrooms. Today, 25% of undergraduates have ESL; 50% are first generation college; 70% from minority backgrounds; 50% from low-income families. This presentation seeks to reveal how this Urban Emerald, with very limited resources advances many of the SDGs and is a model for other institutions. Highlights: G1 - Education as a pathway out of poverty. Generous aid; comprehensive Academic Success Program; Center for English Language Acquisition and Culture. G2: Campus Kitchen staffed by students since 2014 delivered over 36,000 meals to needy with 39,000 pounds of reclaimed fresh food. G3: SPU went entirely smoke-free & tobacco-free in Fall 2017. Wellness Fair promotes healthy living, Junkyard Dogs clean up Jersey City. G7: Co-generation plant and solar panels provide renewable energy and reduce carbon footprint. G11: Collaboration with NJHEPS, Sustainable JC; Mayor's Office of Innovation; others; for programs and Earth Week events. G16: Establishment in 2014 of The Center for Undocumented Students. Other SD goals & strategies will be presented.
PositionTitle_1: Chair, Sustainability Council; Special Assistant to the President; Professor of Mathematics

Presentation Title: Women Empowerment - Sustainable Development Goal 5
Description or Abstract: Women are challenged by social norms and systems that limit their potential and stifle their development. Too often we view these challenges as problems to be solved with policies, laws, and economics. We forget that each of us has the potential to engage and contribute to the evolution of these systems. With the goal of disrupting and evolving our conversations about the role of women in society I am proposing a 60-minute engagement at AASHE 2018. The aim is to have high quality exchange on ways to reconnect women to their personal agency to affect change.

Presentation Title: Countdown to Nowruz 2018
Description or Abstract: The development of sustainability-focused homes on the campuses of college and universities has the potential to have significant and profound impacts on the teaching, research, and service missions of these institutions. Currently however, most investments in these projects are focused on the creation of the facilities, and less so on leveraging the long-term value of the facilities. To expand the offerings of an existing solar home at Penn State main campus, on 2/27/2018, World NGO Day, we designed a welcoming and developmental experiences for our community: an invitation to celebrate Persian New Year. Understanding our connection to nature and to the change of seasons is a large part of this celebration. The resulting engagements were recorded and documented and will be shared at AASHE 2018.

Presentation Title: Local to Global - 5 Strategies for Leaders to Win Change Now and After Graduation
Description or Abstract: First they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they fight you, and then you win' - Gandhi This dynamic, interactive workshop will hone your public leadership skills and teach you how to create massive change and political action on your campus & community, from winning sustainability and social justice campaigns to convincing your elected officials. Attendees will learn tips, tools and techniques to grow your leadership, run a public campaign, and strategically engage people in power. You'll take home actionable tips for change, identify strategic targets and goals, develop a campaign plan, execute, build power, and succeed. Learning how to organize to achieve success is like learning how to ride a bike - the more you do it, the more you learn, and the better you become. The skills you learn in this workshop will serve you throughout life, and are essential to change your community and the world. For sustainability student leaders & soon-to-be graduates who want to make change now and after you graduate. Attendees are encouraged to come with your big, audacious goals for your campus and community, to define what wild success looks like, and to identify - both inside and outside - what it will take to succeed. Led by internationally-renown former elected official Dominic Frongillo, who helped trained by Al Gore, five-time delegate to UN climate talks.

Presentation Title: Shorter showers? There's an App for that!
Description or Abstract: Over the past 6 years, UMass Dartmouth has been tracking student's shower times. This has ranged from self-reported times, to specifically supported timed studies to now the development of an App. Come learn about the challenges of self-reported times and how the data collection from the App helps to eliminate those challenges. For the statistical nerds out there, we'll show some cool charts and graphs to compare a variety of demographic info. We'll also share lessons learned in creating an App, including special levels of bureaucracies never before experienced...

Presentation Title: PSEG Institute for Sustainability Studies Green Team Internship Program
Description or Abstract: The Green Teams program is a one-of-a-kind multi-institutional internship program targeted to upper level undergraduates from any discipline who are interested in Sustainability. Green Teams are transdisciplinary teams of students who serve corporations, organizations, non-profits, municipalities and community groups to address substantial Sustainability issues identified by host organizations. Teams of 5 students are constructed from acceptable applicants coming from many different disciplines and multiple institutions, and whose backgrounds match those required to achieve deliverables requested by corporations and organizations. To ensure students are well positioned to produce high quality deliverables, PSEG ISS provides trainings throughout the course of the program in core Sustainability subjects, hands-on experience with Sustainability skills, and guidance in professional development. Students attend trainings, visit field sites and engage in enrichment and volunteer activities, attend meetings with corporate representatives, and work on their projects and deliverables the remainder of the time. They work intensively 40 hours per week for 10 weeks. Students use information gained to carry out projects and develop deliverables that meet a variety of corporate and municipal needs. Green Teams students work on projects including, but not limited to, wastewater management, renewable energy feasibility, waste management, greenhouse gas emissions inventory, watershed management, green building analysis, corporate social responsibility and sustainability reporting. As a result of the program, student interns are much better capable of entering into their respective careers with a background and education in solving local and global sustainability issues.

Presentation Title: Grassroots: Connecting Diverse Louisville Communities Through Sustainable Initiatives
Description or Abstract: The environmental threat of food waste looms over the United States alongside the imminent threat of hunger. Watching food on campus being thrown away or composted, Erin and Henny believed one solution could address both concerns: organizing a Food Recovery Network. While Erin and Henny were cofounding the University of Louisville's chapter of the Food Recovery Network in their spring 2018 semesters, they realized the opportunity that arose to create bridges between diverse communities on and off campus through sustainable actions. They used this organization, alongside other sustainability resources such as the campus Free Store, garden commons, and student groups such as Eco Reps, GRASS, and Green House, to unite diverse student populations and community members in promoting sustainability education and fulfilling various needs within the community. The need for sustainability is ever-present, but is often times left unaddressed. With hopes to encourage more eco-conscious action, Henny and Erin propose we promote sustainable efforts with a community mindset to develop unity, with hopes to address both environmental action and the social needs of their community. In this panel, they propose an open forum discussion on the uniting elements of sustainability by sharing how they've attempted to bring various populations together, and how others have done this within their campus and community. Erin and Henny hope to foster creativity and the spread of ideas, so that they and others can bring home new methods of building bridges through sustainable efforts.
PositionTitle_2: Student, Department of Sustainability Communications Intern

Presentation Title: Fighting Food Waste on College Campuses
Description or Abstract: BACKGROUND: An estimated 40% of food produced in the US goes uneaten, yet 1 in 8 Americans struggle with hunger. And that number may be even higher on college campuses, according to some studies. Wasting food also wastes water, energy and often wildlife habitat, and it has additional negative environmental impact when it goes to landfill by emitting harmful climate change-causing gases, like methane. How can we prevent food from being wasted? WHAT: WWF and ASU are working to develop a national food waste awareness program to be implemented across higher education campuses in the spring of 2019, to bring attention to the environmental impacts of wasting food and spark a conversation around possible solutions to this problem on campus. TOGETHER POSSIBLE: Our plan is to partner with groups already engaged with food recovery and hunger on campuses such as the Food Recovery Network, Swipe Out Hunger, DC Central Kitchen's Campus Kitchens, Presidents United to Stop Hunger and more, and to ask universities and colleges to host a post-consumer food waste awareness program in dining halls, so that students can learn about the food waste produced daily on their campus. What gets measured, gets managed. We hope this hands-on experience will help students understand the magnitude of this issue and become better educated about the impacts of food waste from both a food security and environmental perspective, and to start conversations across campus about how this could be solved.

Presentation Title: The Campus Kitchens Project: Connecting the Campus and the Community
Description or Abstract: For more than 15 years The Campus Kitchens Project has been empowering students around the country to recover and transform would-be-wasted food into meals to feed members of their community facing food insecurity. To date, The Campus Kitchens Project network has recovered and transformed more than 7 million pounds of food into over 3 million meals for community members experiencing food insecurity. The work being done by 63 schools within The Campus Kitchens Project network relates mainly to the sustainable development goals of ending poverty and hunger while also promoting good nutrition, and promoting well being for all ages. This workshop will explore how The Campus Kitchens Project model aims to fight hunger differently, by addressing the causes of hunger rather than just hunger by itself. It will focus on building relationships both on and off campus, as participants learn to use an asset-based community development model to build partnerships, identify need, manage volunteers and effectively run their own nonprofit programs, much like the work being done at all Campus Kitchen chapters. Other topics of conversation for this workshop include students going 'beyond the meal' as they engage their community members in nutrition education, anti-isolation activities, snap enrollment, and food insecurity awareness to target some of the root causes of hunger. Participants will be tasked to use the asset-based model to assess their own communities and brainstorm solutions.

Presentation Title: Urban green spaces connecting people and place
Description or Abstract: The following concept is a new project designed for the Arizona State University Polytechnic campus; the development and implementation of an urban green space titled The Lot @ ASU, that serves as a multifunctional outdoor learning center by embracing sustainable land design and student connections to people and place. This space will meet the educational, emotional and spiritual needs of the campus and support the university goal of developing our campus as the Nexus of Food, Water and Energy. There is mounting evidence that natural environments offer multiple benefits to humans in the areas of stress relief, nutritional health, and mental health plus provide a type of nature therapy that can have a lasting effect. Positive relationships between social and environmental urban spaces are said to enhance human longevity and mental health, and therefore should be considered in the built environment. This project highlights the lasting benefits of developing urban green spaces in university and college settings. We will design, develop and build this green space in the heart of the campus to promote connections to people and place by providing an atmosphere that encourages creativity, adaption and collaboration or 'A New Community'. The Lot will showcase sustainable land design and management, promote social interactions and support healthy living attributes, plus support the goal of providing 'A New Environment', in which to learn, engage, and share. The development of this new urban green space will accentuate ASU's interdisciplinary themes and become an important component to the overall student experience. Studies show that connecting with nature helps to reduce stress, enhance creativity, and promote clarity. Our vision includes themed areas; a community garden for organic food production, an interfaith space for meditation or prayer, a distinguished entry that serves as a welcome point to the campus, an outdoor learning center and an urban orchard.
Tags: sense of place,urban focus,gardens,campus grown foods

Presentation Title: Synergies in Sustainable Food Systems for Students, by Students
Description or Abstract: In 2017, students, faculty, and staff at the College of Charleston were compelled by Charleston YOUth Count's data administered by the Joseph P. Riley Jr. Center for Livable Communities. It revealed that 30% of CofC students are food-insecure, with this issue affecting marginalized communities most. Through synergistic relationships with The Office of Sustainability, CofC Sustainable Agriculture, Aramark, Cougar Food Pantry, Charleston YOUth Count, The Stone Soup Collective, Tri-County Food Alliance, and local organizations, there are numerous opportunities for students to contribute to the fight for food justice. Quality education at our college can only happen after basic needs are met, thus, by growing food in green spaces, distributing food regularly, and replacing negative stigmas of being in need with support, our campus can be the change. By encouraging students to participate in these initiatives, we hope to highlight the urgency for more locally sourced, nutritious food and boldly communicate that help is available. These options take the forms of free food pick-up from food pantry and gardens, Swipe Away Hunger meals in cafeteria, and soup from the Stone Soup Collective chapter. Educating our community about nutritious food production is the gateway to fighting food insecurity and reducing energy leaks within efforts. These efforts address food production, consumption quantity and behaviors, food origin, and the externalities of the food system. Aside from our school, non-profit, Food Trust, has pinpointed various food desserts in South Carolina, with the majority being in the tri-county area, thus we hope these solution could be implemented in other local communities. Hungry students should be empowered by their campus with ways they can access healthy food to fuel their academic mission and life. We aim to drive holistic, creative, and tasty solutions to a campus and community-wide problem!

Presentation Title: Student Funded Initiatives & the Intersections of Social Justice & Sustainability
Description or Abstract: This is going to address clear and tangible ways students can have agency and autonomy over some of their Student Activity Fees in order to create more than just a 'Green Fund' which can help to provide students, staff, and faculty ways to fund important efforts, initiatives, and events that promote and further support a more just and sustainable future. What we will look at is how this is also an opportunity for the voices from marginalized groups who have often been unheard can participate more in this creating a more equitable, and inclusive sustainability movement at our schools. We'll also explore some of the programs and events that we at Portland Community College have done that involve food insecurity, women's health and empowerment, social/environmental justice work, and some of the classic sustainability initiatives that have improved our school, like learning gardens at all four campuses, cob structures (ovens and sheds), water filling stations, reusable dining ware, and composting systems. This will be a presentation format that will welcome plenty of audience engagement and participation. By examining and exploring the intersections of social justice and sustainability through this student funded program, we will also help to illuminate how intrinsically connected these two areas truly are. Ideally, at the end of this we can all feel even more connected moving forward and genuinely appreciate even more that we are all in this together.
PositionTitle_1: Student Body President ~ Cascade Campus, Portland Community College

Presentation Title: Student Oriented Sustainability Projects on a Small Educational Campus
Description or Abstract: In learning about sustainability practices, students acquire more knowledge through an active process of engagement, by constructing new ideas and working on projects, rather than traditional teaching practices such as the classroom lecture. Also, the learning is contextual and is acquired through experience and involvement in real-world situations. At SUNY Canton, a small university in Northern New York, I realized that teaching Introduction to Environmental Science as a general education requirement course, it would make the most sense if students were assigned sustainability projects that they could work upon. Concomitantly, two major projects were accomplished by students. The first one project involved establishing a Pollinator Garden on Campus. It served as a team building activity where students learned the problems of environmental degradation and habitat loss that has led to decline in bee and butterfly populations. They made efforts to tackle the problem and help spread awareness by creating a habitat for pollinators. Another similar successful project was the undertaking of composting of pre consumer food waste mixed with yard waste to mitigate carbon emissions from transporting and landfilling of wastes and also saving costs on buying fertilizer for our campus. The matured compost is currently being used in the flower beds and pollinator garden on SUNY Canton's campus. So far, the 21,000 pounds of waste used in the compost saved $2,800 in just waste removal costs. We added a second pile to our composting efforts which is expected to double savings and further reduce waste to landfill. This year the students are working on creating a tree nursery on campus so that we grow our own trees to be planted campus wide. The student-led projects have overcome little resources to make a great impact on SUNY Canton's campus.

Presentation Title: Paying for Sustainability: Creating a Relationship With Institutional Advancement
Description or Abstract: Over the years, the percentage of alumni giving to their alma maters has been declining. Lower alumni giving not only means less income; it also lowers an institution's standing in national rankings, such as in U.S. News and World Report. To address this, university advancement/development offices are looking for new ideas to engage alumni. Sustainability initiatives offer a unique opportunity to connect with alumni who might not be interested in traditional engagement around athletic success or supporting general scholarships. At the same time, many sustainability offices are in need of additional funding to implement transformational initiatives. These two factors mean that staff from sustainability offices should be working to cultivate relationships with their institution's advancement offices. This session will help attendees understand how institutional advancement offices operate, and will share tips on how to discuss sustainability fundraising opportunities with your advancement and alumni staff. We will cover guidelines on crafting projects to propose to donors, and share specific examples of successful fundraising to support co-curricular opportunities and faculty development in sustainability. Additionally, we will share our tools for maintaining connections with your student partners (interns, club leaders, etc.) after they graduate. We will review correlations between STARS scores, Sierra Cool School rankings, and alumni giving rates.

Presentation Title: Ideas into Actions: The ECOllective Fund and Student-led Sustainability Initiatives at CofC
Description or Abstract: Each semester at the College of Charleston, students pay a 'Green Fee,' established in the fall of 2009 of $10 that is put into a fund that we call the 'ECOllective Fund'. This fund, which was formally established in the fall of 2011, supports multiple projects and initiatives that make contributions to all aspects of sustainability on campus. A portion of this fund is also set aside specifically to fund student-led projects that aim to 'educate the campus community, encourage positive action for society and the environment, provide research data, and promote collaboration of various academic disciplines' (sustainability.cofc.edu). This funding is administered by the ECOllective Student Project Committee (ESPC), a committee recruited by and composed entirely of College of Charleston students. To secure ECOllective funding for a project, students have the opportunity to work collaboratively with a case manager from ESPC to complete the online application process and then hopefully, make their sustainability project a reality here on our campus. Student project leaders can apply to receive one of two levels of funding, small-scale and full-scale. Expedited small-scale projects can be awarded up to $500, and the application is typically open year-round. Full-scale projects can be awarded up to $5,000, which is typically granted at the end of the semester. It is the hope of the Office of Sustainability that this fund will serve as a model for other universities across the country hoping to further student-driven sustainability initiatives across their campuses. This fund not only helps give students experience in grant writing, develop presentation skills, and enhance leadership abilities, but it also gives students an opportunity to transform their ideas into actions and to create a tangible, sustainable difference on campus that will benefit other students for years to come.

Presentation Title: Evaluating and improving the UDC student's knowledge on the campus sustainability projects
Description or Abstract: Abstract: This research examines the University of the District of Columbia (UDC) student's knowledge on the campus sustainability projects and evaluates three intervention techniques to enhance the student's knowledge and awareness. Eight non-environmental-science majored, undergraduate classes (105 students in total) participated in this research. The students divided into two groups: intervention and non-intervention groups. The non- intervention classes (29 students) considered as our baseline. The intervention group is further divided into three sub-groups and was invited to be involved in a level of sustainability educational intervention. The interventions include: sustainability signage (23 students), sustainability lecture (32 students), and in-person tour (21 students) of the UDC sustainability projects. Each intervention lasted for 20 minutes and the students in each intervention were exposed to the UDC sustainability projects, which was followed by a survey. Findings show that just 28% of our baseline group knew about the UDC sustainability projects. The interventions significantly increased the student's knowledge on the UDC sustainability projects. In lecture intervention group, 58% of the students indicated good knowledge of the projects after going through a 20 minutes presentation. The Tour and Signage Intervention groups also indicated 48% and 27% awareness respectively after going through a 20 minutes intervention. Regression results show moving from signage intervention to tour and lecture intervention, on average, increases students' awareness by 0.76 sustainability knowledge score (highly significant). Interestingly, regression analysis also shows that the older and Hispanic students are more aware of sustainability challenges compare to younger and non-Hispanic students.

Presentation Title: Community-Driven Reuse Initiatives
Description or Abstract: This session will explore examples where waste, whether that is food, electronics, clothing, and more are recovered and either resold or redistributed by creating and leveraging purpose-driven communities. It explores barriers to engagement present in less immediately tangible sustainability projects and presents volunteer-led waste recovery and redistribution as a 'square one' for any otherwise unengaged members of the campus or off-campus population.

Presentation Title: The Intersectionality of the Arts and Environmental Activism
Description or Abstract: At the University of Denver, the Center for Sustainability has established a Zero Waste Program at all sports games, and the average diversion rate of waste from landfill is approximately 90%. The Zero Waste team also works to establish zero waste habits in the library and other buildings on campus, but until recently, there has never been any Zero Waste programming in the Newman Center for Performing Arts. The most recent student-run initiative to increase diversion rates across campus at the University of Denver is the incorporation of Zero Waste and the arts. In 2016, a student submitted a proposal for the installation of two tri-bins, one on the practice room floor for students and one in the atrium for audience members. She also proposed the idea for Zero Waste concerts. The goal of this project is to inspire conversation amongst performers and concert attendees about the environment in which they create, share, and listen to music. The Newman Center for the Performing Arts displays artists who express social justice concerns which serve as powerful tools for social change, but the Lamont School of Music, in combination with the Newman Center, needs to educate their students, audiences, and performers about environmental practices to foster holistic sustainability. Through this, the University of Denver would move toward becoming a just and inclusive institution as described under the United Nations' Goal 16 for Sustainable Development. Since 2016, the Center for Sustainability has piloted three Zero Waste concerts with an average of a 90% diversion rate whereas 100% of waste produced usually goes straight to landfills. Most recently, there has been an installation of a tri-bin in the Joy Burns Plaza of the Newman Center and one on the practice room floor of the Lamont School of Music. In the future, the Center will establish all concerts as Zero Waste to create greater engagement between the arts and environmental sustainability.

Presentation Title: Advancing Organizational Change for Sustainable Development Goals Through Neuropsychology
Description or Abstract: What role does neuropsychology play as a determinant for successful organizational change toward Sustainable Development Goals?
