This session explores the inter-related notions of reflective practice, metacognition, cultural norms, and critical thinking as a means of creating the individual and organizational conditions necessary to recalibrate anthropocentric behaviors, rethink the dominant market-driven paradigm, and practice morally responsible behavior toward all the earth's inhabitants. Using a synthesis of nascent literature and review of best practices, this interactive session encourages consideration of what, if any, incongruity exists between higher education outputs and the unmet needs of society's most excluded and marginalized members as foundational to scaling a new futures-oriented mindset that mitigates the sustainability paradox and moves our colleges and universities toward SDG achievement.
Academic_Discipline_1: Behavior Sciences (Social Work, Counseling Psychology, etc.)

Presentation Title: Reel Sustainability: Connecting to Audiences Through Video Storytelling
Description or Abstract: From television commercials to YouTube, Snapchat, and even Facebook Live, it's no secret that video has become a staple of our everyday lives. Video provides an easy and efficient way to reach audiences through an attractive, versatile, and shareable medium. Video can help to illustrate complex and sometimes politically divisive topics such as climate change or the UN's Sustainable Development Goals and can even direct viewers to a specific call of action. But videos can be incredibly challenging to create, taking up a lot of time, energy, and resources, and may not always have the direct impact you intended. This panel will showcase a diverse collection of 5-6 videos from institutions across the country, all with different production quality, intended audiences, content/theme, and impact. Furthermore, the panelists will identify ways that the videos were shared, how they were received, and what kind of measurable action they had among the campus community. We will also discuss lessons learned during the video-making process and open up the room for a dialogue about making and sharing sustainability videos to achieve the greatest impact.
PositionTitle_7: Campus as a Living Lab & Sustainability Project Manager

Presentation Title: Academic Libraries Fostering Resilient Communities
Description or Abstract: Every institution of higher education already has an academic library that can be a partner in campus sustainability. This program offers specific ideas for how faculty, sustainability staff and administrators can make better use of existing library resources and will seed new ideas for how your own library can become a more integral part of campus sustainability. In 2013, the American Library Association formed a Sustainability Round Table (SustainRT) with an agenda of 'libraries fostering resilient communities.' Since then, academic librarians have been working together to advance sustainability both in academics and campus operations. After the initial disruption of the digital age, academic libraries have re-imagined themselves as community centers. While libraries retain a core mission to share things (not just books) and to support the campus community, they are also expanding into new areas of service. Typically, academic librarian-liaison assignments mirror the subject-based structure of academic departments but sustainability blurs the line between academics and praxis so that campus libraries have taken on a campus-wide role to provide information for sustainable facilities, planning and community engagement. In the age of climate change, libraries can even serve as centers to help rebuild community resilience after a disaster. The presentation begins with a brief overview of the activities of SustainRT given by a SustainRT board member and a short PechaKucha style.
PositionTitle_2: Associate Librarian, Liaison to the College of Agriculture & Life Sciences
PositionTitle_3: Science Collections Coordinator and Environmental Sciences Librarian

Presentation Title: Develop Your Toolkit for Sustainability Communications
Description or Abstract: Communications play an increasingly important role as we rise to the challenge to reach the global Sustainable Development Goals. However, many sustainability professionals may find their toolkit a bit empty when trying to navigate the communications arena. This entry-level workshop will map out the essential elements in a sustainability communications strategy, introduce best practices, and help participants to get started with a well-rounded sustainability communications campaign. This workshop will discuss: university and departmental branding; newsletter basics; social media do's and don'ts; best practices for news and blog writing; audience and analytics; web content management; video and content creation; and relationship building with your university's communications department. After reviewing the above topics, participants will work with the presenters and their colleagues to develop a component of a communications plan for sustainability at their institution.

Presentation Title: Communication Strategies to Reach Beyond the Choir
Description or Abstract: Often times, sustainability professionals and communicators can reach a plateau when working to reach new audiences. Our institutions can often be so siloed that it is challenging to draw in new audiences to build a larger, more inclusive sustainability story in your community. This presentation will share the communication strategies four institutions have used to reach 'beyond the choir' and engage new audiences in sustainability. This presentation will discuss best practices for working with campus communications, engaging campus partners and utilizing innovative, 'outside of the box' communication tools. Expanding reach and improving sustainability communications can help our institutions to rise to the challenge to meet our global goals. This presentation will bring together representatives from a variety of institutions ranging in size and type, and provide diverse perspectives from both sustainability and communications professionals.

Presentation Title: Mobilizing Colleges with Earth Integrity Training
Description or Abstract: Earth Integrity Training (EIT) is a program for colleges to mobilize their communities about urgent environmental issues. It provides creative and multimedia content for a 2-3 hour seminar that colleges use to train their own employees (and can be extended to students). EIT has the following goals: Increase awareness beyond environment-focused departments, especially since most adults have not had environmental science instruction since high school or none at all. Prepare students and the rest of the community for the challenges of climate-change and resource depletion. Help create and motivate a more eco-literate electorate. Enable colleges to take a stand for accurate science and demonstrate their commitment to the environment. Explore and help overcome the widespread lack of information, denial, and unconscious fear that slows the necessary cultural shift to sustainability from occurring. The program is currently being piloted at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, taught by faculty, EHS staff, & also facilitated by Mental Health Counselors who attended Climate Psychology training. The session will cover lessons learned so far, with feedback by trainers and attendees. Background - In 1992, over 1700 independent scientists, including the majority of living Nobel laureates in the sciences, wrote the 'World Scientists' Warning to Humanity,' cautioning that 'a great change in our stewardship of the Earth and the life on it is required, if vast human misery is to be avoided,' due to Earth's ecosystems being pushed beyond their capacities to support the web of life. Data was provided to quantify ozone depletion, freshwater availability, marine life depletion, ocean dead zones, forest loss, biodiversity destruction, climate change, and continued growth of human and livestock population growth. In 2017, a second World Scientists' Warning to Humanity was issued.
PositionTitle_2: EdD Grad Student / Adjunct Asst Prof.

Presentation Title: Bridging the gap: Community Engagement Programs, Sustainability, and the SDGs
Description or Abstract: During this session participants will gain an understanding of how alternative breaks can support and collaborate with sustainability initiatives towards the SDGs. How do sustainability and community engagement offices engage with the objectives of the SDGs? How can you collaborate with community engagement programs and other office efforts to assist in local and global sustainability efforts? Presenters will focus on the Active Citizen Continuum, community engagement programs and how they support on campus sustainability goals, and how students can contribute to reaching global sustainability goals. - Participants will leave with an understanding of how alternative breaks can support and - collaborate with sustainability initiatives towards the SDGs. - Participants will gain an understanding of community engagement and leadership programming and their application to social issues - Participants will learn how to empower students to initiate positive sustainable change.
PositionTitle_2: Coordinator of Alternative Breaks and Community Partnerships

Presentation Title: Building a Consistent Sustainability Brand
Description or Abstract: In order to reap the full benefits of consistently communicating the values and messages that are core to your sustainability brand, it is important to design brand guidelines the define the look of your communications and materials. Brand guidelines are a powerful tool that create a consistent look and feel so communications and design projects are easily recognized by faculty, staff, students, alumni, and visitors, and communicate the key sustainability values of the university. Through brand guidelines, your campus community will come to know and recognize the sustainability brand through the consistent presentation and expression of the brand in all communications and marketing. But how do you get started? What is the path to developing brand guidelines? Who needs to be involved? In this session, we will discuss Lehigh University's path to developing a branding guide, how you can choose branding elements that harmonize with your school's visual identity elements, and how you can apply the concepts in physical materials. Discussion will include topics such as: core brand objectives, logo (simple and full versions), color palette (primary and extended), typeface standards, image usage guidelines, and identity elements - do's and don'ts. The utilization of a cohesive sustainability image and brand is very important.

Presentation Title: Activism or Silence as a Sustainability Office?
Description or Abstract: We live in a time when activism has become a regular part of our lives and addresses a multitude of issues. As Sustainability Officers, our passions and worldviews are often aligned with these campaigns - yet, our position in the establishment can discourage activism. Is activism something an Office of Sustainability should partake in? As an administrative office, how do we support and/or participate in activism? Join this discussion with the Director of Sustainability from New York University who will share insights on how her Office navigated politics to support the March for Science, the We Are Still In campaign and the People's Climate March. Participants will discuss when we should be involved in a movement, what value can be gained from incorporating an activist role into our work and who needs to be involved in the process to do this.

Presentation Title: Back to Basics
Description or Abstract: Eco-Reps is turning over a new leaf at Ohio University. This year we will focus on being a community-service based sustainability student group. Through community clean-ups, we will be actively making Ohio University and Athens a more beautiful and healthy place. Eco-Reps will also engage in a variety of outreach programs in order to help the general student body and the Athens population become more aware of sustainability concerns. This group of Eco-Reps is different from previous generations at Ohio University because we are emphasizing the community-service based approach, instead of the former weekly meeting workshops that only included group members. All volunteer opportunities organized by Eco-Reps will be open to the general population in efforts to include a greater variety of people. We are also centering our volunteer opportunities on Athens nonprofits which are not affiliated with the university. We hope by being more active in the community we will be able to help students engage with local Athens residents. By making sustainability more visible in Athens and around campus, we will be able to educate and bring together the Athens and Ohio University communities. The mission of Eco-Reps is: 'Eco-Reps is a student organization focused on offering friendly, sustainable education to its peers in a multitude of ways. We also participate in various ecological volunteer opportunities around Athens in order to improve the community and collaborate with other organizations, including the Office of Sustainability, to promote environmentalism. Eco-Reps strives to encourage a sustainable culture on and around campus by example; we aim to be personally sustainable, constantly educating ourselves about what it means to live a green lifestyle.' As a group, we are optimistic that returning to the community-service based approach will help us fulfill all the goals of our mission.

Presentation Title: Becoming a 'spokes' person for campus sustainability: The smoothie bike & other outreach efforts.
Description or Abstract: Ohio University, like many universities nationally, has been affected by budget and staffing streamlining. Campus services and departments, like the Office of Sustainability, were profoundly affected. However, presidential strategies and sustainability plan benchmarks maintain that sustainability is at the forefront of university efforts. All Office of Sustainability efforts are important to generating long-term solutions, sensibly increasing efficiencies, and creating thoughtful efforts. However, campus outreach is generally the primary method in which students become engaged in sustainability. Therefore, continued and improved programming is critical to gaining momentum within the student population. The issues mentioned above have consequently pushed Ohio University's Office of Sustainability into being more innovative and creative with it programming. The proposed poster presentation aims to articulate how to become a spokesperson for sustainability within higher education settings. Specifically, targeting questions such as firstly, how to partner across interdisciplinary boundaries without losing sight of sustainability. Secondly, how to navigate sustainability subjects with individuals in positions of power. Thirdly, how to maintain sustainability focus within collaboration efforts. The following case study uses the three pillars of sustainability (people, planet, and prosperity), modern student interests, and local themes/events to develop meaningful student engagement activities. Further, information gleaned from this poster and handouts has been generated to improve sustainability outreach programming within other institutes.

Presentation Title: Building and Supporting Social Movements for Institutional Change and Beyond
Description or Abstract: Even as the campus sustainability movement has grown, the issues in our food system have continued to deepen. The average age of farmers in the U.S. is over 65, farmworkers are sickened from pesticide exposure, food chain workers are paid sub-living wages, and many communities lack access to nutritious, affordable food. Control of our food is in the hands of fewer and fewer mega-corporations, and those building sustainable alternatives are often barely hanging on. We are facing a moment of crisis and also a moment of opportunity. Looking to social movement theory and social movement case studies, this workshop will explore how the campus sustainability movement can rise to the challenges facing our food system today. Students will learn about the role they can play in advocating for a just and sustainable food system, beginning on their campuses. This workshop will also discuss the basics of campaign organizing and planning. Through interactive activities and active dialogue, participants will come away with some of the tools needed to begin making real food system change beginning on their campus.

Presentation Title: United Nations Association Campus Network
Description or Abstract: Advance the UN's Sustainable Development Goals on your campus through the United Nations Association of the United States (UNA-USA) campus network. Learn about how to bring innovative SDG programming to your campus through the UNA-USA network and learn from other UNA campus chapters through this networking session. Examples of past programming includes: over 20 local human rights projects funded in by UNA-USA's partnership with the UN Office of the Human Rights High Commissioner; service-learning projects that connect with the SDGs; the opportunity to support refugee education through UNA-USA's Adopt-a-Future initiative with the UN Refugee Agency; and the opportunity to host UN speakers on campus to celebrate United Nations Day each October. Since 1946, the United Nations Association of the United States has been dedicated to building understanding of and support for the ideals and work of the UN among the American people. It is only with the continued commitment of passionate supporters that we can continue to educate, inspire and mobilize Americans to support the vital work of the United Nations! UNA-USA is a grassroots network comprised of over 200 community and campus chapters across the U.S. Affiliation with the network will provide your campus access to high level UN speakers, Sustainable Development Goals materials and toolkits, and the opportunity to apply for grants and scholarships. There is no cost to starting a UNA-USA campus chapter at your institution.

Presentation Title: Advocacy for the Global Goals
Description or Abstract: Be an advocate for the UN and the 17 Sustainable Development Goals in your community! Learn advocacy strategies from the United Nations Association-USA (UNA-USA) to creatively engage with community partners, school administrators, and elected officials. UNA-USA represents the single largest network of advocates and supporters of the United Nations in the world. This workshop will seek to empower students to be local leaders for the Global Goals.

Presentation Title: Four Steps for Leading Impactful Environmental Change On-Campus
Description or Abstract: How can students effectively foster an environmentally conscious and sustainable community within their university? You can have the best and brightest ideas, but if their implementation is not strategic, they may never see the light of day. The Campus Environmental Center (aka 'the CEC'), a student organization at UT Austin since 2002, is sharing their four steps to fostering environmental change on a college campus. With over 15 years of experience in student-led project management and campus engagement, the CEC has successfully transformed student interest into several projects, including an organic micro-farm, a series of pop-up second hand item sales around campus, a zero-waste event consulting service, and much more. Bring a notebook and pen because you'll want to take these tips back to your own organization.

Presentation Title: WCUPA Student Brandywine Project
Description or Abstract: The Student Brandywine Project was a student led half-day workshop to engage West Chester University students in helping design, implement, evaluate, and improve the various environmental, social, and economic sustainability initiatives happening on campus. The program included: an overview of sustainability, information on different resources WCU students have to engage in sustainability, presentations from other WCU organizations tying in the different sectors of sustainability, interactive breakout sessions discussing various facets of sustainability, networking opportunities, a tour of the campus geothermal pump house, and a waste audit. Multiple student lead initiatives that took place during the semester including grab a mug program, composting for an annual campus event, and banning of single use plastic bags in our school convenient store. These few student driven initiatives continue to highlight the desired involvement against environmental issues at West Chester University. We plan to continue hosting Student Brandywine Projects each semester, and hope to host a Part 2 for students interested in continuing their sustainable education. This will dive deeper into one of the facets of Sustainability.

Presentation Title: Fair Trade Chocolates: Raising the Challenge with Sweets
Description or Abstract: UNCW is one of over 46 universities nationally that have embarked on a campaign to achieve Fair Trade (FT) Status by ingraining FT practices, principles, and policy into their campus communities. By using institutional buying power to source products on campus and at events, building a student team, committing to education, and passing a resolution, UNCW has engaged students, faculty, staff, and the broader community in creating a conscious impact and more informed consumerism. Embarking on this campaign has offered a platform that addresses many of the United Nations' SDGs including an emphasis on ending poverty & hunger, providing quality education, promoting reduced inequalities, facilitating decent work & economic growth, supporting responsible consumption & production, and sustainably managing life on land. This spring chocolate was used as the lens for a unique educational opportunity that facilitated cross-sector collaboration at UNCW, as well as in the local, national, and international economy. Dining hosted a FT Chocolate Pop Up Shop to create awareness about FT & the campaign, educate about cocoa production & countries of origin, and allow participants to make a conscious purchase for Valentine's Day. Event partners reached out to FT chocolate companies who generously donated samples and bulk scrap chocolates. Local businesses then turned the donations into specialty chocolates. These were sold at the event incorporating educational partners from Sustainability, Office of International Programs, and CARE: Collaboration for Assault Response & Education. All sales went to the Kuapa Kokoo, a cooperative of cocoa farmers in Ghana. Chocolate proved to be a great conversation starter that sparked interest in supporting not just a more locally sustainable community, but globally as well. The session will include lessons learned, offer insight on how to incorporate FT at your campus, and allow for discussion of how to expand on this idea with other FT products.

Presentation Title: Campus Sustainability: A Motivational Analysis for Change
Description or Abstract: Current business practices are a leading source of environmental degradation, especially employee actions in the workplace that generate excessive waste to landfill, resource depletion, and other negative impacts. The UN's Sustainable Development Goals identify 'Responsible Consumption and Production' (GOAL 12) as a critical focus for research and practice, with particular emphasis on encouraging companies to adopt sustainable practices (12.6) and ensuring that people everywhere have the relevant information and awareness for lifestyles in harmony with nature (12.8). This study adds to understanding in this domain by identifying the attitudes and motivations driving PEB (Pro-Environmental Behavior) within key constituencies in a campus setting. Results are intended to guide effective targeted interventions to increase of sustainability awareness and practice on campus and in other organizational settings. Three phases of survey research over a 10yr period assessed pro-environmental attitudes, beliefs, values and behavioral intentions within campus populations. Findings indicate 'environmental concern' as the primary driver of PEB for every subgroup, with motivations for PEB differing between groups. 'Instrumentality' (measured as 'I believe my actions make a difference') had the greatest impact for undergraduates and staff, while 'empowerment' (measured as 'environmental responsibility is a priority for me') had the greatest impact for graduates and faculty.

Presentation Title: How to Podcast Your Way to a More Environmentally Sustainable and Socially Just Future
Description or Abstract: In this session we'll be looking at the journey of starting a Higher Education Sustainability Podcast and how it can be something that could benefit nearly every college or university in the nation. Portland Community College has a Podcast called 'PCC, Sustain Me!' and it started out with the intentions of exploring the many levels and ways that PCC as an institution was addressing Sustainability, Environmental Justice, and the 17 Sustainability Development Goals. This process involved creating a series interviewing members of PCC from bottom to top including students leaders, instructors, faculty/administrators, board members, and working its way up to the college President, Mark Mitsui. By creating this rather comprehensive look at Portland Community College as an institution, this podcast is creating a qualitative way to illuminate all the different levels of sustainability and social justice, equity, and inclusion efforts the school is making. It's accessible because it is story telling. By replicating this podcast each higher education institution can create a more transparent dialogue that can provide great potential for better efficiency and ways to remove redundancies in programming or efforts as well as opportunities for engagement from students who may see ways the school can improve its actions and/or commitments. The session will include reflections on the trials and tribulations of starting a podcast, suggestions for tools, tips and tricks too!

Presentation Title: CU Boulder Tests Behavior-Tracking Platform's Effect on Student Engagement in Sustainability
Description or Abstract: What if a more engaged student was also a more successful student?' Research in fact bears this out. And 'what if there were an App that helped to deepen engagement among students in behaviors that drive up success?' These fundamental questions prompted Dave Newport, Director of the Environmental Center at CU Boulder, to persuade the University to beta-test in academic year 2017-18 an innovative new motivation-engagement platform, called PIPs Rewards. The purpose of the pilot was to see whether student engagement with an App that tracked and rewarded verifiable beneficial behaviors - such as riding the bus, biking, bike sharing, recycling, refilling water bottles, volunteering and participation in sustainability events - could at once turn these positive impact behaviors into habits and boost retention rates. Once earned, students can redeem their PIPs for discounts on healthy and responsibly sourced food, textbooks, fitness classes, responsibly made clothing, gear rentals and more or donate them to a charity. And come spring, students will be able to earn and use PIPs for and to achieve financial wellness goals. Few sustainability engagement apps require action verification. What also makes the PIPs App unique is it so light and low-friction that many actions are tracked without a user taking her phone out of her pocket. This makes the data analytics the app gathers about user engagement in purpose, sustainability, health and financial wellness behaviors.

Presentation Title: Partnering Student Green Advisors With Staff Advocates: Swarthmore's Innovative Eco-Reps Model
Description or Abstract: This session will showcase an innovative Eco-Reps model at Swarthmore College that partners a paid, student internship program (the Green Advisors) with a voluntary staff program (the Sustainability Advocates). I will describe the three-year design process of these two programs, an overview of the SDG-heavy training that the Office of Sustainability provides to each of the two groups, and how they collectively have been a vehicle for accelerating the College's recent Zero Waste commitment. In studying national Eco-Rep models, we have not found programs that match student and staff as liaisons in this novel way. A brief description of the two programs is below: The 20 student Green Advisors (GAs) work as paid interns on three fronts for a full academic year. First, they serve as peer leaders in the residence halls, collaborating closely with RAs. In this role, they play an essential function in waste management during move-in and move-out. Second, they are key players in the operation of the College's campus-wide compost system, as they manually sort contamination from the compost stream in daily shifts and support custodial staff in compost bin pick-ups. Finally, they are each partnered, one-to-one, with a Sustainability Advocate department to provide their expertise to staff who have volunteered to lead small-scale, departmental sustainability projects. The GAs receive a full week of training on myriad and complex sustainability topics just prior to New Student Orientation.

Presentation Title: From 'Fix it Fest' to Fix it First: Nurturing a Campus Culture of Reuse
Description or Abstract: Student accessibility to sustainable living resources is an absolute priority at any university. We want students to not only recycle, but also reduce and reuse what they have in order to develop sustainable living habits. Fix it Fest is WKU's first annual repair event aimed at addressing this goal. Through partnerships with our campus 'Fixers' we are able to provide fixing service and education to both students and staff. For WKU, the event was just the start of our institutional goals to promote reuse. After outlining the event, we will look at strategies to maintain reuse momentum on your campus. In this session, you will build your own blueprint for a 'Fix It' event and leave excited to infuse repair education into current waste reduction efforts.

Presentation Title: Green Gurus Unite! Discussing the Promise and Perils of Becoming Your School's Moral Compass
Description or Abstract: We were flooded with requests to set something up to continue the conversation at the conclusion of our lively, well-attended 30-minute 'High Priests of Sustainability?!' presentation at AASHE 2017. This topic was clearly resonant for our colleagues at other institutions and there is an obvious need for more space to discuss these issues. So let's do it! Whether we are brand new on the job, or have been in a Sustainability Coordinator position for decades, we have all been there. It is that awkward moment when we are introduced not by our actual titles, but by some weird euphemism that tells us how people on campus really see us: 'Our Green Guru,' 'Our Sustainability Guy/Person,' 'Our Sustainability Czar,' 'Our Sustainability Queen,' 'Our Sustainability Maven,' 'The Face of Sustainability,' 'The Vehicle for Sustainability,' 'The Creator of Our Sustainability Initiatives,' or even 'The Conscience of the University.' We also find ourselves faced with colleagues coming to us with 'confessions' about their 'green sins' or, conversely, seeking affirmation for their good green deeds. Something is going on here that needs to be explored. What does all this mean and how can we respond appropriately? What are the implications of this kind of a role for sustainability professionals? Join us for a discussion of our perceived roles within the institution, especially as it pertains to openly living our values and the ramifications for how we are viewed by others.
PositionTitle_1: Assistant to the Provost for Sustainability Initiatives

Presentation Title: Addressing Sustainable Development Goals: Non-profit, Campus and Community Collaborations
Description or Abstract: With a theme of 'Global Goals: Rising to the Challenge,' this year's conference examines the role of higher education in achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This workshop will not only offer tangible resources for those wishing to integrate the SDGs into campus and classroom initiatives, but will primarily serve as a case study for how non-profit organizations and the higher education community can collaborate in order to advance the Sustainable Development Goals. Participants will learn about the process one organization (Northwest Earth Institute) underwent in order to both conduct an organizational assessment and integrate the SDGs into programming. This workshop will share tangible steps in order to effectively integrate SDGs into programmatic offerings. Participants will leave the workshop with examples of how to conduct research and assessments, and will also discuss a variety of ways the SDGs can be integrated into existing coursework or programming on campus. Participants will consider goal-setting and will examine examples of SDG integration. Achieving the United Nations' SDGs will involve every level of community. To exemplify this, the workshop will also highlight the process of collaboration with a local community partner to advance Education for Sustainable Development (ESD). Leaders of the Greater Portland Sustainability Education Network, a United Nations University Regional Center of Expertise on Education for Sustainable Development (RCE) (http://gpsen.org/), will share their work forming an RCE and advancing the SDGs. They will also discuss ways in which the higher education community can partner with non-profit organizations in order to advance both the SDGs as well as deepen ESD (Education for Sustainable Development). At NWEI, we reference the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) as an avenue for impact on the global scale.

Presentation Title: Introducing the Campus Community to the UN Sustainable Development Goals
Description or Abstract: Presentation covers opportunities to introduce the campus community to the UN SDGs through special events, professional development, integration into strategic plan, funding and outreach materials. Covers alignment with academics and research, preliminary results, challenges and opportunities.

Presentation Title: Peer-to-Peer Educator Programs: Examining Four Common Styles
Description or Abstract: Based on overwhelmingly positive feedback on the EcoReps Networking Session last year, a team of sustainability staff members from four institutions has come together to provide another opportunity for further information sharing and community support. This session will be facilitated by representatives from four different campuses with different models for their Peer Education/EcoReps Programs. Each panelist represents one of the four typical program types: Residentially Focused & Paid / Residentially Focused & Unpaid, and Campus-Wide & Paid / Campus-Wide & Unpaid. They will explain their program's beginning and current operation, including key highlights and pitfalls with the intention of illustrating some pros/cons of that model that are NOT just specific to their campuses. This will be a 25 minute panel with 5 minutes for questions. For the second half of the session, attendees will self-select into one of the four program type groups. These groups will have the rest of the meeting to discuss challenges and best practices, through a facilitated discussion led by the associated panelist. Each group will be expected to compile these session notes into a summary of considerations for each program type that can be presented at the end of the network session, and written up to be shared online as part of the growing public Google Drive folder of resources started after last year's session. There will also be time for the groups to share out or ask questions.

Presentation Title: Students, Sustainability, and Social Media: Tools for Content and Collaboration
Description or Abstract: Communicating sustainability efforts across social media platforms is an important but often challenging part of our work. As social media trends emerge and change, how can we convey our messaging clearly, effectively, and imaginatively? We suggest that students can be the best indicators of how to engage your base, and can also help lighten the burden of your communications efforts. Meanwhile, there are more ways than ever to utilize easy, beginner tools to master professional design from your smartphone. This session offers strategies for taking your social media strategy from good to great, from creating guidelines for staff and student collaboration and improving techniques for smart phone photos and video, to understanding the do's and dont's of platform features like Instagram stories and Facebook live. Learn from the failures and successes of five schools as we share what we've gained in the process of making social media an integral part of our engagement efforts and give you hand-on experience in creating better content.

Presentation Title: Sustainability-themed Living and Learning Communities
Description or Abstract: As residential living and learning communities become more commonplace across higher education, a great opportunity for sustainability emerges. Join representatives from Boston University, Colgate University and Virginia Commonwealth University to hear strategies implemented, goals met and lessons learned regarding sustainability-infused residential communities. Participants will have the opportunity to reflect on their own programs and engage in lively discussions.

Presentation Title: Student Engagement through Research Experience: The U-Challenge at Texas A&M
Description or Abstract: In the spring semester of 2017, the Department of Residence Life and Utility & Energy Services at Texas A&M partnered to host their first annual Utilities Challenge (dubbed the 'U-Challenge'). The U-Challenge is a semester-long research competition for students that has evolved over the past two years to encompass both graduate and undergraduate teams from all majors. Student teams of 4-7 people are assigned a residence hall on-campus. The teams are given data about the utility and energy consumption in the hall from the past two years. Teams work closely with our two sponsors, Siemens and Johnson Controls, and Utility & Energy Services staff to understand how their research experience can translate to any future career. They then put together a presentation on recommendations for sustainable infrastructure and increased student engagement to reduce utility and energy usage. Their presentations are delivered in two separate rounds to a panel of judges made up of faculty, staff, and professionals. Sustainability recommendations brought forth by the teams have the chance to be implemented at the largest university in Texas. In the first two years, the applications to participate surged from 12 to 60 students. Applicants come from a wide array of majors and academic classifications, with many of them working with their advisors to receive course credit in the process.

Presentation Title: Texas Regional Alliance for Campus Sustainability (TRACS) Networking Session
Description or Abstract: This is a networking meeting for Texans and other parties interested in the Texas Regional Alliance for Campus Sustainability (TRACS) to connect and discuss campus sustainability topics unique to the Lone Star State. We will also cover how attendees and their institutions can participate in the TRACS organization, and we will discuss our upcoming TRACS Summit hosted by Huston-Tillotson University in February 2019.
PositionTitle_1: Director, Administrative Center for Sustainability and Energy Management

Presentation Title: Break out of a Social Media Slump: How to Create a Strategy, Build Community & Engage Your Audience
Description or Abstract: By 2021, it's estimated that there will be more than 3 billion social media users around the world. If universities and colleges are going to be leaders in addressing the global Sustainable Development Goals, we must be able to capitalize on the power and potential of social media to build visibility, community and engagement among diverse audiences both on campus and beyond. This session will focus on two institutions: Agnes State College and the University of Florida, and how they each re-envisioned their approaches to social media. Agnes State College's Center for Sustainability underwent a social media transformation during a critical time for their programs in 2017. The Center created a working group to produce posts about the Center's initiatives, including a video series about the LEED-certification process of a building renovation project. Their focus on enhancing social media engagement resulted in increased attention from off-campus viewers, including alumnae across the nation and the college's Board of Trustees. UF's communication team revamped their lagging social media presence, using a strategy designed to build community, engage new and existing followers, and elevate the visibility of programs and campaigns. This strategy resulted in an increase in engagement across the 3 major platforms - Facebook, Instagram and Twitter - and is directly linked to an increased participation rate in behavior-change campaigns by members of the UF campus community.

Presentation Title: Involving the Greek Community in Sustainability
Description or Abstract: Greek communities nationwide have large impacts on college campuses. Currently, close to one million undergraduate students are associated with Greek organizations. Influential and prominent, involving the greek community in sustainability is necessary for growing environmental awareness and increasing sustainability education. This session will cover how we have done greek sustainability on our campuses, how to start a greek sustainability program at your college, program funding strategies, how to interact with university Panhellenic and Inter-Fraternity Council's, how to directly and effectively engage with the greek community, accomplishing meaningful outreach, and program success and impact. We hope that after this presentation audience members will have gained an understanding as to why greek sustainability is imperative, what greek sustainability looks like, and have learned the tools to create a greek sustainability program of their own.

Presentation Title: Is your staff engaged with your sustainability practices?
Description or Abstract: At Carnegie Mellon University there are numerous sustainable practices on campus. Our presentation is to share the ways we engage the faculty, staff and students to raise awareness about green practices. Carnegie Mellon University's Strategic Plan 2025 includes sustainability as one of its seven values. Sustainability, reflected in our shared commitment to lead by example in preserving and protecting our natural resources, and in our approach to responsible financial planning. Many on campus are not aware of all the ways they are already practicing saving the environment. The programs we will discuss include Scotty Goes Green which supports and promotes offices that are taking steps toward reducing their environmental footprint. The Green Practices Committee which strives to develop university practices that improve environmental quality, decrease waste and conserve natural resources and energy, thereby establishing Carnegie Mellon as a practical model for other universities and companies. Opportunities are grouped into three categories: Campus Life, Facility Infrastructure and Transportation. The Sustainability Committee of Staff Council which develops a more comprehensive waste reduction and energy conservation program specifically for staff members working in coordination with CMU's Green Practices Committee.

Presentation Title: Bees as a Bridge From Local Experiential Learning to Collaborative Global Education
Description or Abstract: The Champlain College Apiary was established in 2013 in order to provide experiential learning opportunities for students and community members and to support the college's commitment to sustainability. This living laboratory has been incorporated into 50+ classes and extra-curricular programs, produced and sold over 1,700 pounds of honey, and hosted over 1,000 visitors from the Champlain and wider Burlington communities. It is financially self-sustaining and depends on volunteers, class projects, faculty collaboration, and independent and work study students for its labor force. After a few successful years on campus, we expanded our reach to the Peruvian Amazon with the creation of Project Beetopia, the research, education, and service endeavor started by German Perilla, director of the George Mason University's Honey Bee Initiative, and me. The mission of this project is to use beekeeping to promote individual and community empowerment, entrepreneurship, and economic self-sufficiency, while preserving natural and cultural resources. The primary research undertaken by this project is to successfully domesticate and manage endemic bee colonies as a source of medicinal and marketable honey, creating supplemental income and skills for rainforest communities. The educational aspect of Beetopia is the global studies courses developed for each of our institutions, which immerse our students in global learning through the context of the Amazon rainforest.

Presentation Title: Graduate Students Implement Sustainability During a Short Academic Window: Case Study Eden Hall
Description or Abstract: Eden Hall Campus at Chatham University was built to be a living learning lab for sustainable initiatives in the Falk School of Sustainability. Although the focus of the university is for implementing sustainability, practicing sustainability by students is underutilized due to the relatively young age of the campus (3 years) and the barriers present in garnering student interest in the planning and execution of campus-wide initiatives. When compared to undergraduate students, graduate students are typically less involved in their university community due to other pressing responsibilities like full or part time work, family obligations, or long commutes. Getting graduate students involved in campus activities is a common challenge and it becomes increasingly difficult when implementing sustainable initiatives. Achieving sustainability on any level, let alone an entire university, is no easy feat. However, to truly represent a campus of sustainability ideology, graduate students need to be involved in the conversations that dictate campus sustainability to bridge the gap between class discourse and personal interest. Even though the burdens associated with graduate students presents challenges in enabling change, a more concentrated effort to include graduate students can advance sustainability measures. This poster presents a case study of Masters of Sustainability students at Eden Hall who have found and created ways to bridge this gap and contribute to sustainability efforts during their brief academic window, thus fostering a deeper connection with the campus and entire university community. The factors that have led to Masters of Sustainability students becoming involved and impacting sustainability on the Eden Hall campus will be discussed through this poster presentation. Audience members viewing the poster will become more aware of how to accomplish sustainability even with barriers present.

Presentation Title: Sustainability Student Engagement Through the use of Online Platforms
Description or Abstract: This 30-minute presentation will cover two successful student engagement campaigns run at Colorado State University that primarily relies on custom online platforms. These engagement campaigns have been run for multiple years at CSU and have statistical evidence to demonstrate their effectiveness. The online platforms will be shared with attendees through ipads and the digital screens.The blueprints on how we created our online engagement campaigns will be shared with attendees as well as how we measure our success in changing behavior.

Presentation Title: Sustainability Perspectives: A Video Showcase
Description or Abstract: This session will showcase a diverse collection of videos from institutions across the country, all with different production quality, intended audiences, content, theme, and impact. Start off your morning with a cup of coffee and a film!

Presentation Title: From Awareness to Action: Behavior Design for Campus Sustainability
Description or Abstract: This workshop will provide participants with an overview of Root Solutions' proven human-centered design approach to environmental behavior change. You will learn how to strategically select which behavior(s) to target, and how to determine barriers and motivators to those behaviors. In the second phase of the workshop, we will move into an overview of our Behavioral Building Blocks that are most relevant to the campus setting, and will show you how to use combinations of those building blocks to design effective behavioral interventions on your campus. The workshop will provide real-world examples and strategies for behavior change interventions intended to reduce paper use, energy use, achieve zero waste, increase recycling and other sustainability challenges relevant to universities and large institutions. Participants will leave the workshop equipped with background knowledge and techniques for implementing sustainability behavior change initiatives at their institutions.

Presentation Title: Smith College House Sustainability Challenge
Description or Abstract: As part of Smith College's efforts to integrate environmentally sustainable practices into institutional operations and student life, a diverse group of campus stakeholders launched the House Sustainability Challenge in 2017. The Challenge seeks to develop innovative programs and strategies that help increase student engagement in sustainability through house (dormitories) activities. The Challenge invites our students to develop programs that promote scalable, sustainable practices that can be adopted or implemented by all houses campus-wide. In the first phase of the Challenge student teams develop proposals for programs they'd like to implement in their house. Proposals are then judged by staff members from the co-sponsoring offices, and three to five teams are selected to move on to the second phase, where the teams pilot their programs. This year the proposals were judged by staff members from the co-sponsoring offices: Campus Sustainability; Center for the Environment, Ecological Design and Sustainability; Design Thinking Initiative; Jill Ker Conway Innovation and Entrepreneurship Center; and Residence Life. Proposals were judged based on the following criteria: understanding of environmentally sustainable practices, understanding of human behavior/needs, value add to the campus, innovativeness and economic feasibility. In the second phase teams receive up to $500 to fund pilot program development, during which Challenge co-sponsors provide guidance. Teams present an overview of their pilot and its impact to the judges during Earth Week at a program that is open to the campus community. The winning team receives a $1,000 grand prize for their house. Winners also receive the opportunity to work with the co-sponsors to implement their program in all 35 campus houses the following year, with the goal of providing sustainability programing that is for students, by students, and programming that creates real cultural and operational change.

Presentation Title: Interactive and Captivating: How to Create a Successful Workshop
Description or Abstract: Texas A&M University has found the most effective way to communicate the importance of sustainability with our campus community is through interactive and engaging content. Our most successful approach has been a hands-on workshop series created by office interns. These bi-annual workshops consist of interactive activities relating to social, economic, and environmental topics. During workshops, we split the audience into groups and assign them to different interactive stations led by the interns who created them. While planning the workshops, interns focus on topics they are passionate about that are timely and relevant in hopes of generating interest in the event and captivated participants. A key for success is developing activities that lead to a direct conversation with students. At the conclusion of the workshop, participants receive a high-quality water bottle with the Texas A&M Office of Sustainability logo. Using a quality give-a-way item helps create an additional layer of incentive to attend the event, and it also promotes a sustainable lifestyle by giving students a tangible tool that makes sustainable choices easier. Finally, we advertise for the workshops through campus-wide email, tabling events, and social media. We hope our experience with campus outreach will benefit the AASHE community and encourage others to implement similar strategies on their campus.

Presentation Title: Leading and Integrating Sustainability 2.0: A Discussion About Deep Organizational Change
Description or Abstract: Many institutions are entering a 'Sustainability 2.0' phase, where offices have been established for up to ten years and topics such as recycling, composting, Eco-Reps, and active transportation plans have seen the ebbs and flows of success. Many of us are feeling like it's time to take campus sustainability to the next level by developing transformational leadership programs that will establish sustainability as a strategic institutional priority and be fully integrated into all facets of business in higher education. Let's come together to share our successes and challenges, learn from the experiences of a few of our colleagues who recently attended the REFOCUS workshop, 'Leading Deep Change in Higher Education,' and discuss the future of AASHE and how it can continue to meet its members' leadership needs.

Presentation Title: Resilience Bootcamp - Turning Threats into Opportunities
Description or Abstract: Resilience is a hot topic for those who work within the campus operational and built environment. But what does it really mean for a campus community and how does it apply to your campus specifically? This workshop, which is designed to complement Second Nature's 'Organizing a Campus-Community Resilience Building Workshop', will provide guidance on sustainable best practices in the planning and design phase of the project as well as a means of evaluating completed projects. It will use Rochester Institute of Technology's recently updated CAP as a case study. RIT was one of the first schools to incorporate resilience and adaptation into its plan. Since best practices were not yet well established, RIT examined practices from cities, states, academic literature, and sought faculty expertise. Ryan Kmetz will introduce participants to the Inst. for Sustainable Infrastructure's Envision Process and how it can aid in successfully planning and implementing resiliency projects. Participants will be able to: Describe the current state of campus resilience planning; Apply the tenets of resilience to their existing sustainability plans; Be equipped with tools, templates and possible metrics to guide their planning processes; Frame the path forward for campus resilience performance; Explore, using the interactive web map at https://arcg.is/mjuTK some common hazard data sets in your region that could impact your organizations.
PositionTitle_1: Senior Sustainability Advisor to the President
PositionTitle_2: Asst. Dir. Sustainability and Energy Mgmt.

Presentation Title: How Do Sustainability and Resilience Work Together in Practice?
Description or Abstract: Resilience and sustainability have had a confusing relationship over the past decade. While resilience has long been an important element of sustainability, for example going back to the work of C.S. Holling in the early 1970s within the framework of ecological and subsequently socioecological systems; and It has also long been an important concept in public health and in psychology including within the context of responding to disasters; and within the context of the IPCC, resilience was a core element of treatment of impacts, adaptation and vulnerability. But somewhere along the line, a current of resilience thinking and interests began to position it as a preferable alternative to sustainability. This was perhaps best captured by phrases such as 'Good bye sustainability, hello resilience' and 'forget sustainability, it's all about resilience,' and 'Forget Sustainability It's Time to Talk Resilience.' This created an unnecessary and unproductive confusion and competition between two concepts that are complementary, mutually reinforcing and interdependent. In addition, 'resiliency' has become en vogue creating added confusion. With this background in mind this session will look at resilience and sustainability within the context of assessment, planning and projects on two campuses: The University of New Hampshire and MIT.
PositionTitle_1: Executive Director Sustainability Institute/Chief Sustainability Officer

Presentation Title: Achieving SDG Targets: The European Approach: Compliance - The Case of Energy & Irish Universities
Description or Abstract: Ireland, as a nation, has signed up to the SDGs. The main drivers in reaching these targets will be through a set of interventions that are encompassing - legislation - compliance to higher regulations - incentives - dissemination of effective best practice. When all put together, it is a large and complex tapestry of actions.  The presentation proposed will take Energy as an example. It will outline how the targets have been set nationally to achieve our internationally agreed targets. The resulting Irish approach will be highlighted, filtering down to what specific steps are taking place in the public sector. The resulting actions that are being implemented in the Irish University sector will be presented, with specific examples being provided from the actions taking place in the Dublin Institute of Technology (DIT).  In short, Ireland has set a target for private organisations to achieve at 25% energy use reduction by 2020 over baseline measurements made by 2008. Public Sector bodies are to achieve a 33% reduction. Over the past 9 years DIT has had to make decisions that deliver on this target. The decision making has been assisted by a blanket of initiatives provided by central government encouraging sharing information, setting procurement requirements, upskilling key staff, establishing proven and robust frameworks, platforms for informing and educating 23,000 staff and students. The initiatives and interventions will be presented alongside the framework.

Presentation Title: Projection and Scenario Analysis for Climate and Nitrogen Action Planning
Description or Abstract: Campuses are now calculating their carbon and nitrogen footprints together in SIMAP, a web-based platform launched in fall 2017. Once you have calculated your campus' footprints, how might you use your results to develop an integrated climate and nitrogen action plan? We will explore this question through three parts of this session: case studies on current action plans, identification of strategies for integrated planning, and a preview of projections & solutions in SIMAP, the Sustainability Indicator Management and Analysis Platform. Part 1: Current action plans. We will first present two case studies on stand-alone footprint action plans: A climate resilience plan at the University of New Hampshire, and a nitrogen action plan at the University of Virginia. Part 2: Integrated planning. We will explore different strategies for combining a climate and nitrogen action plan into a single campus initiative. To inform these strategies, we will review and compare projection and scenario results for campus carbon and nitrogen footprints to demonstrate the overlap and co-benefits for a range of management strategies. Part 3: Projections & solutions in SIMAP. Finally, we will share a preview of and solicit feedback on a prototype of the new projections & solutions module in SIMAP.
PositionTitle_4: Project Manager of the Nitrogen Footprint Network for Institutions

Presentation Title: Organizing a Campus-Community Resilience Building Workshop
Description or Abstract: This workshop will train participants in how to organize and facilitate a Community Resilience Building (CRB) Workshop. The CRB Workshop is a community-driven process, rich with information, experience, and dialogue to equitably improve resilience to natural and climate-related hazards. Colleges and universities can use this process to: Develop relationships with key stakeholders in their communities; Understand shared strengths and vulnerabilities across the campus and community in the context of climate-related hazards; Identify initial actions to increase resilience; Fulfill the requirement of completing an initial campus-community Resilience Assessment for the Presidents' Climate or Resilience Commitment. The training will walk participants through all steps of the CRB Workshop process, including: core team establishment; goal setting; defining top hazards (past, current, future); participatory mapping of strengths and vulnerabilities; development of actions against multiple hazards; and prioritizing solutions. Participants will leave prepared to organize CRB workshops with their respective campuses and communities. This training is relevant for campuses in all stages of the resilience assessment and planning process; the CRB can be used to kickstart the conversation around resilience or it can be used to further refine planning goals.

Presentation Title: Designing a Realistic, Challenging, and Effective Climate Action Plan: Options and Best Practices
Description or Abstract: This session will present the results of a research project aimed at understanding how institutions of higher education have developed and structured their Climate Action Plans. The goal of the session is to provide attendees with resources and insights that will help them to design a realistic, challenging, and effective Climate Action Plan (CAP). The research is centered on a comparative and systematic analysis of a set of Climate Action Plans, with the aim of understanding the various ways in which institutions have decided to structure their plans, in terms of organization, content, and format. By illuminating common features of these plans, the choices and options available to institutions, and best practices, the research is useful to any institution seeking to develop their own CAP. A second part of the research, based on both interviews and written materials, focuses on the processes and strategies used by colleges and universities to develop a CAP. During the session, attendees will be provided with an overview of the different strategies used by institutions to execute and structure their plans, as well as an analysis of how to determine and customize the best strategy for one's own institution. Attendees will also receive a handout with tools for making choices about a CAP. By contributing to efforts to develop Climate Action Plans, this session supports work by institutions to contribute to efforts to meet Sustainable Development Goals 13, 11.

Presentation Title: Three Zeros Environmental Initiative at UNC Chapel Hill: The Chancellor's Sustainability Charge
Description or Abstract: The University of North Carolina (UNC) has set a new global standard for sustainability in higher education's constantly evolving environment. UNC is scaling its impact through the Three Zeros Environmental Initiative (TZEI)- net zero greenhouse gas emissions, water usage, and landfill waste-a framework that is critical to its physical, operational, and community planning. Learn how the Chancellor's initiative is reinventing the great global public research university through sustainability and apply lessons learned at your institution. Through this session, the panelist aim to demonstrate how UNC: - builds road maps for achieving triple zero initiatives on campuses. - weaves the university-scale sustainability charges into capital building and planning projects. - embeds sustainability into your campus's DNA through engagement, awareness, and team building. - challenges conventional sustainability pathways with pan-campus initiatives to achieve a triple zero initiative. Throughout the UNC Chapel Hill Sustainability Plan and Three Zeros Environmental Initiative, community engagement was paramount. This session will not only demonstrate how the planning team engaged the community through a wide range of exercises, town halls, working groups and interviews, but aim to actually use this session to establish some fundamental themes in sustainability in our industry.
Tags: sustainability plans,net zero water,zero waste,carbon neutrality

Presentation Title: Resiliency in the Face of Global Change: Developing a Sustainability Program That Thrives
Description or Abstract: In December 2017, China announced a waste importing ban that upended the global recycling markets. In January 2018, the U.S. imposed a 30% tariff on solar equipment manufactured abroad. In 2017, super storms Harvey, Irma and Maria hit the southeastern United States, sending ripple effects through the conversation about climate disaster preparedness and federal emergency response. These global shocks have a direct effect on how sustainability offices and universities develop and implement sustainability initiatives and drive organizational change. They also provide opportunities for us to rethink and work towards broader, global systems change. How can we proactively prepare for these moments? What should we know about these changes and how will they affect our work? In this session, we will propose frameworks and brainstorm tactics that enable sustainability offices to be resilient and innovative in the face of changing global landscapes. This will include strategies for educating senior administration on the impacts of these events on campuses and strategies for leveraging shocks as moments of opportunity to generate investment in proactive, innovative systems.

Presentation Title: Extending Sustainability Practices to Tenant Spaces: Green Leasing at Portland State University
Description or Abstract: Portland State University (PSU) is home to approximately 60 commercial tenants. Tenants range from food service and retail, to offices, banks, ATMs, and advertising. To encourage sustainability practices and behaviors among tenants and enable stronger adoption of University Technical Design Standards, PSU Campus Sustainability Office staff are working with stakeholders in Campus Planning, Facilities & Property Management, and Capital Projects & Construction to implement a green leasing program. To date, PSU's green leasing program has focused on capturing the newest tenants on campus by examining the LOI and lease negotiation process, as well as the tenant improvement (also known as the fit-out). Moving forward, PSU stakeholders also hope to ensure ongoing engagement and training with tenants, by collaboratively celebrating best practices and identifying areas for improvement. The program has been designed around a few key required measures, like alignment with University solid waste management policy, and additional encouraged measures, such as attainment of the City of Portland's Sustainability at Work certification. While green leasing is increasingly being used in the private sector, it is not common at higher education institutions. Therefore, this presentation will provide a brief overview of green leasing and how its application to higher education is similar to and different than in the private sector. This presentation will outline the program design at PSU.

Presentation Title: Campus Central Plants - Assets or Liabilities in Achieving Carbon and Resiliency Goals
Description or Abstract: Pratt Institute along with many other Colleges have central plants that provide power and HVAC to campus buildings. How do these plants fit into the new carbon restrained world with increasing needs for resiliency? This presentation will outline Pratt's 'Roadmap' to answer these questions.

Presentation Title: Leverage Key Facilities Metrics to Advance Sustainability - Survey Could be 'Gateway Drug' to STARS
Description or Abstract: Most participants know that STARS is a holistic value laden intensive survey that has produced fantastic results and encouraged sustainability success from campuses. Overall, by reviewing and implementing the AASHE STARS program, a campus is likely to advance development of programs, improve operations, advance initiatives and relate better to community. However - not all campuses are willing to undertake the effort to complete STARS. For those campuses that cannot - APPA/NACUBO formulated a simple, six question survey to gather data on operations issues related to BTU/EUI, electrical, water, waste and carbon. For campuses that have already done AASHE STARS filling out this survey will be simple, and will assist in getting others to improve their baseline consumption. There is no cost to the survey, and a campus does not need to be a part of either APPA or NACUBO. In its fifth year, the survey has motivated many campuses that do not participate in any kind of sustainability survey. Results are that campuses can participate and leadership can work with the information to improve their own consumption and reduce physical operational costs. 'You cannot manage what is not measured' is an old, but true, adage. See results of how campus participating with the APPA//NACUBO Key Facilities Metrics and worked with leaders to reduce consumption. See how to graphically display items that will motivate others to reduce consumption.

Presentation Title: Mainstreaming the Sustainable Development Goals: An Insiders' Account of change in a UK University
Description or Abstract: Higher Education institutions have a crucial role to play in catalysing action to address the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The call to action that the Goals represent can be seen as aligning with universities' long-standing purpose to positively contribute to society via education, research and public engagement. However, successful take-up of this agenda within institutions is likely to rely upon a wide range of factors, including national/international pressures on the higher education sector and internal dynamics and agenda setting behaviours of staff, students and university leaders. This poster offers a contemporary empirical account of such factors from a UK university that has recently vigorously adopted the SDG agenda. The poster summarises key factors affecting how over 12 months the SDGs went from being relatively unknown within a UK university, to being the cornerstone of a new institutional strategy that aims to use the Goals as a prism to inform all of the institution's activities. Drawing upon literature on Transition Management and organisational change and insights from staff involved in teaching, research, campus sustainability and public engagement, the poster offers a view from the inside of how a strategic commitment and enhanced activities emerged via complementary top-down leadership and bottom-up initiatives. The analysis highlights a broadening of support for sustainable development and three key emerging tensions: between a reductionist and holistic framing of sustainable development; between working to achieve the SDGs and critical exploration of the concepts involved; and between marketing-oriented and impact-oriented intended outcomes of engagement. Through highlighting these issues in the context of a live and evolving situation at a UK university, the poster offers a timely summary of the challenges and opportunities inherent in mainstreaming sustainable development within the higher education sector.
PositionTitle_1: Senior Lecturer, Institute of Energy and Sustainable Development

Presentation Title: Latin Flavor in AASHE: Contributions to Sustainability Offices
Description or Abstract: In many institutions of higher education and universities around the world, there are offices that manage the issue of sustainability for years. AASHE is a multicultural space where many of the people in charge of this topic meet annually in their institutions. In this conversation, we want to highlight the contribution made by some directors of sustainability offices with Latin roots, in institutions of the USA or Colombia, and as part of our heritage and essence can contribute significantly to the training of students and the operation of the institutions in which we work. To be American (that is, citizens of a country in America) is to have a mixture of languages, behaviors, traditions and values. From food to music, we want to highlight how the Latin flavor is contributing to the construction of sustainability in different universities, and in turn, learn from the other cultures that participate and are part of the AASHE world. We will mention the experiences in USA and Colombia: at the University of Texas in the Rio Grande Valley, Dallas County Community College District and the EAN University, but beyond that, the experiences from other Hispanic attendees to this session, will allow strengthening the link of work in sustainability to starting from the things that unite us as people.

Presentation Title: ISSP Networking Session: Do You Have All It Takes to Be an Effective Sustainability Professional?
Description or Abstract: Calling all active and aspiring sustainability professionals: come learn about the International Society of Sustainability Professionals (ISSP) community and earning ISSP's sustainability credentials. Meet with ISSP members and hear sustainability leaders in the higher education field tell personal stories about the value that recognition for their sustainability expertise has brought to their careers. Learn about ISSP's credentialing process including: the professional standards it examines; who the credentials are designed for; and the key benefits these professional credentials brings to individuals as well as the sustainability field as a whole. Find out if YOU have all it takes to be an effective sustainability professional! This will be a highly interactive session where attendees will work in small groups through examples of the credentialing exam's scenario-based questions and discuss their experience in similar situations. Finally the group will discuss the similarities and differences between the role of a sustainability professional in higher education versus other industries. This session is open to anyone interested in learning more about ISSP and the ISSP Sustainability Associate (ISSP-SA) and the ISSP Certified Sustainability Professional (ISSP-CSP) credentials.

Presentation Title: How to Design an Annual Report People Actually Read
Description or Abstract: Have you struggled with keeping up with annual reporting for your sustainability program? Are you somebody who's on top of their annual reporting but feel like nobody reads your report once it's been finalized? Or maybe you're an annual reporting all-star but are looking for better ways to effectively quantify data and qualify narratives to communicate your program's successes out to your campus community and the larger sustainability community? In this session, Pomona College's Assistant Director of Sustainability, the University of Tennessee's Sustainability Manager, and the green fund Coordinator and Student Environmental Resource Center (SERC) Director of the University of California at Berkeley have teamed up to share their experiences working on annual reports that are effective and that people will actually read. This team of sustainability professionals has planned a session to hash out what makes an effective annual report, reflecting on each campus' challenges and best practices. This session hopes to meet people where they currently are. Whether you're a beginner on annual reporting, have some experience, or are a seasoned annual reporter, this session is intended to provide you with the tools and inspiration you may need to leverage sustainability on your campus.

Presentation Title: International Networking Meeting
Description or Abstract: Members of the international community who are attending the AASHE conference and those who are interested in international issues are invited to join in a networking meeting to share resources, challenges, and ideas in our countries. Let's discuss ways that AASHE can work with organizations and institutions within and across countries to support our broader education for sustainable development (ESD) efforts, including advancing Agenda 2030 and the Global Goals.

Presentation Title: Top Down and Bottom-Up: The Pitt Sustainability Planning Process
Description or Abstract: In 2017 Pitt embarked on their first comprehensive sustainability plan which launched early this year. This session outlines the top-down approaches to connect with leadership and link this planning effort, and the implementation that follows, directly to the Plan for Pitt, the University's Strategic Plan. The presenters, through presentation and hands-on exercises, will demonstrate the 'bottom-up' engagement processes used to reach the campus community to inform and drive the plan. From the desk of the Chancellor: 'Long-term sustainability extends beyond environmental practices. It requires deep and lasting changes that will enable future generations to thrive in a world that is environmentally responsible, socially equitable and economically robust. It is a great challenge - one that our University's mission, which is to harness knowledge for society's gain, perfectly positions us to tackle. To advance this work, we established a University Sustainability Committee in the fall of 2016. These committee members set out to think boldly, develop goals and recommend supportive actions for promoting sustainable practices across the Pitt community. The result of their efforts - the Pitt Sustainability Plan - is a strategic framework that calls for dramatic improvements in sustainability across our University by 2030.' The session will outline the planning process, engagement exercises and outcomes, the plan organization and survey results.
PositionTitle_2: Director of Administration, Business and Operations

Presentation Title: How a Team of Student Ambassadors Can Amplify and Accelerate Wins for a Small Sustainability Staff
Description or Abstract: Facing the Big, Hairy, Audacious Goals of campus sustainability work with small offices can feel impossible; however, despite having a small staff, college and university sustainability offices can effect real change on campus by leveraging student employees. CWRU's Office for Sustainability hired its first group of student employees in 2014.
