Known as Climate Leaders, this small group of students were tasked with creating presentations designed to educate our campus population on various sustainbliity-related information and delivering these presentations to 3 groups within their spheres of influence. The intention behind the program was amplifying the sustainability message from the University to the 16,000 students, staff, and faculty on campus who were not familiar with the work being done by our office of 2 staff members. 4 years later, and the CWRU Office for Sustainability now employs 16 Student Ambassadors, who work across the spectrum of sustainability topics on campus. Our Student Ambassadors now not only share and magnify the values, lessons, and work being done by the Office for Sustainability, but they are increasing the capacity of our still small office of 2 full time staff to accomplish sustainability projects on campus and accelerating the rate of sustainability change on campus. This session will share the lessons we have (sometimes painfully) learned as we honed the structure of our student employee program to be effective in meeting the SDG goals.

Presentation Title: The Design Thinking Process: User-Centered Solutions to Complex and Confounding Problems
Description or Abstract: Coming out of Stanford's Institute of Design, the Design Thinking (DT) framework has taken the Architecture, and now the business world, by storm. However, this solution- and user-focused design process is incredibly useful for sustainability professionals as we traverse complicated behavioral, institutional, and financial barriers in creating more just and sustainable campuses. For many, the process of creating solutions often starts with problems from our own point of view: our recycling rate is not high enough, our alternative transit numbers are not high enough, etc. While starting here can eventually lead to useful solutions, shifting your point of view can be incredibly useful in creating lasting, working solutions. The DT process, instead, begins with the needs of the user: how are they currently interacting with, say, your recycling program, and what are their needs around this topic? This forces us, the planners, to truly understand our problems, and therefore reach solutions that help our users, rather than ourselves. The Center for Sustainability at the University of Denver has used this process in a number of our planning processes, from assessing our student employment program, to re-writing our mission statement, to including sustainable elements in a new residence hall being built on campus.

Presentation Title: How to Overcome Challenges at Large, Urban Campuses
Description or Abstract: This will provide a space for large urban campuses to discuss challenges and accomplishments of working on sustainability on Urban campuses. AASHE has lacked the spaces for these types of campuses to have dialogues because change is so hard at these types of campuses. This will provide that space.

Presentation Title: Organizational Transitions and Continuity in a University Setting
Description or Abstract: Turnover is the cardinal issue that plagues collegiate organizations because of the ever changing minds of the student population as well as the traditional four year system of undergraduate education. To remain successful, organizations must battle these forces with tools and techniques of accountability, commitment, and most importantly interest. For this 60-minute session please join Thriftsburgh, the University of Pittsburgh thrift store, for a presentation and conversation about how to keep your organization successful year after year!

Presentation Title: Using the Analytical Hierarchy Process to Perform a Materiality Study on the SDGs
Description or Abstract: To effectively 'ignite change' in regards to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, a university must first determine which of them are applicable and material to the organization. This process helps ensure that the limited resources available for sustainability efforts are utilized in ways the stakeholders deem important. At Villanova University, applicability and materiality studies will be performed on the SDGs using the Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP). AHP was developed by Saaty in the 1970's to facilitate large subjective decisions, which makes it perfect for determining the relative importance of the SDGs to an organization such as a university. AHP also makes it easy to incorporate the views of many diverse stakeholders. The process boils down a seemingly large decision into many simple and easy decisions to reduce overall stress on the decision makers. The final result is a weighted list of all the compared items, in this case UN SDG Targets. This prioritization of the UN Targets can facilitate the creation of Sustainability Strategic Plans around the most important targets. Future work will include the development of a scoring system for each UN Target, modeling of projects to determine the improvement they are expected to bring an organization's score, and a statistical cost benefit analysis of said projects. The net benefit of this combined work will be a qualitative determination of the 'optimal' way for each organization to spend their resources, customized to what they find most important in the SDGs. The methodology for completing a materiality study on the SDGs using AHP will be presented along with the Villanova results.

Presentation Title: Institution Nitrogen Footprints in SIMAP: Updated Results and New Insights
Description or Abstract: Seven campuses that participated in the development of the nitrogen footprint tool (NFT) published findings from their initial nitrogen footprint calculations in the April 2017 special issue of Sustainability: The Journal of Record. In October 2017, SIMAP was released by the UNH Sustainability Institute as a web-based tool for institutions to calculate carbon and nitrogen footprints simultaneously. Beyond the major contribution of combining carbon and nitrogen footprints, SIMAP included updates and improvements to nitrogen footprint calculation methods. Institutions that had previously used the excel-based NFT for assessing their nitrogen footprints have since uploaded their data inputs in SIMAP. In addition, several more institutions in the NFT Network have completed nitrogen footprint analyses using the new SIMAP tool. This presentation will cover a. the updated nitrogen and carbon footprint results from SIMAP, b. how the new results differ from the initial findings using the NFT, and c. an updated analysis of sustainability metrics using a larger sampling of institutions that have completed nitrogen footprint analyses. A deeper understanding of the results and sustainability metrics used for campus nitrogen footprints will inform sustainability planning and goal setting around nitrogen, and it will also contribute to our knowledge about how institutions can participate in addressing broad environmental issues.
PositionTitle_1: Project Manager of the Nitrogen Footprint Network for Institutions

Presentation Title: Resiliency: A Platform for Institutional Change, Case Study Cal State University San Bernardino
Description or Abstract: Historically, California State University San Bernardino (CSUSB) has embraced sustainability through faculty curriculum, students initiatives, and facilities management retrofitting projects, however, sustainability efforts are not coordinated and transformational change is still needed. Resiliency is of particular interest to the CSUSB campuses at San Bernardino and Palm Desert because of its geographical location, diverse campus population, economic and environmental challenges. To tackle this approach the CSUSB Office of Sustainability identified key metrics including energy, water, transportation and mobility, education and community, building and land use, and food and waste. CSUSB then developed working groups around these metrics that include faculty, staff, students, alumni, and regional partners to inform the plan and develop actionable strategies and resources to reach our goals. Finally the plan established a Task Force to coordinate the campus wide efforts, and to inform the President and Chancellor to ensure administrative support through financial and policy avenues. This project has re-energized the campus community around sustainability initiatives. CSUSB has been successful in bringing stakeholders together from across campus and community to develop our sustainability plan and to continue to vet sustainability initiatives. This work has created a more deliberate, coordinated approach to sustainability in campus operations, curriculum, and research opportunities that engage students, faculty and staff. This presentation will highlight the newly developed Resilient CSUSB Plan components, identify lessons learned and provide a framework for other campuses looking to create a strategic and comprehensive sustainability plan.

Presentation Title: Abandoned Bikes on Campus: Redistribution and the Sustainable Development Goals
Description or Abstract: Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) in Richmond, VA and Eastern Mennonite University (EMU) in Harrisonburg, VA are presented with a number of bikes abandoned by students each year. As cycling gains popularity on campuses across the U.S., universities increasingly face this obstacle and must find ways to process these bikes. This session will explore how VCU and EMU recycle, refurbish and redistribute abandoned bicycles and how those methods relate to various Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The presentation will cover two areas: Sustainable Communities and Good Health and Well-Being: Refurbishing bicycles and redistributing them within the university population furthers these SDGs. VCU refurbishes bikes for a semester long rental program that serves international students and a short term rental program for the larger student population. EMU similarly refurbishes bicycles for a semester long rental program available to all students on campus. Reducing Inequalities and Partnerships for the Goals: Redistribution of bicycles to populations outside the university contributes to meeting these SDGs. VCU partners with local non-profits to redistribute its abandoned bicycles to youth Earn-A-Bike programs in local middle and high schools. EMU has additional bikes refurbished that are then distributed to a local refugee resettlement program.

Presentation Title: Imposters, Insiders, and Collaborators: Bringing Outside Expertise to the World of Sustainability
Description or Abstract: Sustainability is often viewed as a field reserved for those with expertise gained through an academic background in Environmental Science, Ecology, Sustainability or similar areas, and individuals from outside of those fields can feel they lack the credentials and the credibility that comes with it. In actuality, 61% of us come from a field or area of study considered to be outside of the core domains of sustainability. We bring with us expertise in business, public health, education, political science, the humanities, and dozens of other fields of study, and are key to creating robust, innovative and effective sustainability programs. We know that our most pressing global challenges cannot be solved by sustainability professionals alone. Creating tangible, significant progress toward the UN's diverse Sustainable Development Goals requires a robust set of experiences and knowledge bases that extend well beyond the sustainability-focused disciplines. This session features four current professionals in the field from different backgrounds and in varying positions within the sustainability umbrella to show how each of their unique areas of expertise have augmented the impact they are able to have on their campus. Our presenters will share the work they've done as a journalist, a city planner, a public health specialist, and a language educator and describe how these experiences inform and support the work they're now doing in sustainability in higher education.

Presentation Title: How to Create Sustainable Solutions in Your Community
Description or Abstract: Want to learn how to implement sustainability projects with local businesses in your community? Join GreenLight Solutions Foundation for an interactive brainstorming session to create a strategic framework for catalyzing positive change. This unique workshop provides an opportunity to create your own VMOST² canvas specifically designed to create real solutions to environmental, social, and economic challenges you see and experience in your community. Used by organizations both large and small, VMOST² is a strategic analysis tool which stands for Vision-Mission-Objectives-Strategies-Tactics-Tools. Since 2013, GreenLight Solutions at Arizona State University has utilized the VMOST² for over 40 student-led sustainability projects in our local business community. It has proven to be a simple yet effective project management tool to bring about positive change throughout the Phoenix metropolitan area and beyond. The utilization of the VMOST² for designing and executing student-led business sustainability projects is unique to GreenLight and has proven to be very effective over the past five years. Whether you're by yourself or with a team, join us for an interactive workshop and engaging discussion. We believe that with proper organization and effective collaboration, we can catalyze passionate students to apply their classroom knowledge to real world challenges in order to create sustainable solutions that make a difference in the lives of others.

Presentation Title: Leveraging the SDGs to Build a System-Wide Higher Education Sustainability Strategy
Description or Abstract: Sixty-Four schools, nearly half a million enrolled students, 33,000 faculty and 96,000 degrees granted annually--the higher education scope and impact of the State University of New York system is vast and deep. This breadth and depth is a great asset but it can also be a challenge when thinking about a coordinated and integrated sustainability strategy across the different institutions--especially in a decentralized governing model. This session will focus on the challenges and opportunities of creating a campus to system (bottom up) sustainability strategy using the Global Goals or Sustainable Development Goals as a key organizing tool to find common ground and purpose across diverse intuitions. We will explore the process of forming a committee of campus sustainability professionals who lead the project, developing the strategy, the identification of the SDG's as a vehicle, the process of drafting university system specific targets and presenting those to the Chancellor for adoption. The session will also spend considerable time looking at why this initiative was undertaken and the inherent benefit it can provide for sustainability coordinators at the campus level as they work to achieve the grand challenges we collectively face.

Presentation Title: Notre Dame's Success in Developing a Sustainability Strategy Aligned to SDGs and Its Mission
Description or Abstract: In response to Pope Francis' 2015 encyclical Laudato si', the University of Notre Dame leadership championed a committee out of the Executive Vice President's office to take action. Using a participatory approach comprised of faculty, staff and undergraduate and graduate students, the committee was formed to not only review the current state of the University's sustainability efforts but also develop realistic actions and recommendations. As a result, the comprehensive sustainability strategy was developed, which called out specific five-year plans in six key areas of sustainability that are consistent with the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. The long-term vision for the University to become a more sustainable campus was strengthened by identifying small working groups that would meet routinely to review progress and establish metrics in support of the key strategy areas: Energy and emissions Water Building and construction Waste Procurement, licensing and sourcing Education, research and community outreach This session will present a case of one institution's participatory approach to preparing and advancing a comprehensive sustainability strategy. The session will also seek to exchange best practices for aligning sustainability goals with a broader mission at higher education institutions.

Presentation Title: Got Plans? Perspectives on Developing and Implementing Campus Sustainability Plans
Description or Abstract: Panelists and audience members will share diverse perspectives on and experiences with sustainability strategic planning. To serve a broad audience, our panelists (and, hopefully, audience members) represent the following perspectives: - Programs that want to develop a sustainability plan or are seeking support for one - Programs that are in the process of developing or drafting a plan - Programs that have finished a plan, but might be struggling with implementation - Programs that are well on their way through implementing a plan - Programs that are updating or want to update a plan - Programs that created a plan through an internal process - Programs that created a plan via hiring outside consultants The panel will consist of five campus sustainability officers representing institutions with different sizes, locations, histories of sustainability programs, etc.. This panel session will appeal to a broad audience by presenting such an assortment of viewpoints on the subject. We will have a moderator with his own experiences asking questions to each of the panelists then the last 20 minutes will be opened up for Q&A with the audience.

Presentation Title: AASHE STARS: Field Notes From New Adopters
Description or Abstract: The AASHE STARS program is invaluable. It provides higher education institutions a unified platform for assessing and reporting their contributions towards the United Nation's Sustainable Development Goals. However, obstacles remain. AASHE's 2015 membership survey results highlighted the primary barrier to ongoing participation in STARS: lack of time and resources to complete STARS. In response, AASHE's 2018-2020 Strategic Plan calls for a series of initiatives aimed at simplifying data collection, and making the reporting process more collaborative. This will culminate with the release of a simplified STARS 3.0 in 2020. In the interim, institutions remain eager to undertake the reporting process. This panel highlights the experience of two institutions working toward their first-ever STARS Report. The University of Chicago began their reporting effort in 2017, with a Readiness Assessment. The aim of this assessment was to establish inter-departmental data and information collection processes and build on existing strategic partnerships with senior administration and campus stakeholders. Case Western Reserve University has reported to Sierra Club and Princeton Review for several years. In 2017, the institution decided to pursue STARS reporting. Since then, the aim has been to verify historic inputs, and complete previously un-pursued credits. The panel will begin with a brief overview of the challenges first-time reporters face. Then, the panel will shift to discussing practical suggestions for efficiently 1) gaining institutional buy-in; 2) collecting data; 3) verifying accuracy; and 4) submitting reports.

Presentation Title: Mapping the Pathway to STARS Platinum
Description or Abstract: AASHE's Sustainability Tracking, Assessment, and Rating System (STARS) is the leading North American green/sustainable campus rating system developed by colleges and universities for colleges and universities. STARS provides the foundation for other campus sustainability rankings and is quickly becoming the standard which peer institutions use to evaluate overall achievements and progress in sustainability. Completing STARS also requires investing considerable resources. With STARS providing a version of key performance indicators (KPIs) for higher education sustainability, and given the resource commitments necessary to complete a full and serious report, sustainability officers in the University of California system find that is critical to treat STARS as a strategic tool and leverage these reports to drive tangible changes. We will describe how we use our systemwide STARS/Metrics Coordination Working Group to coordinate on STARS and other common metrics reporting, align on external rankings issues, find opportunities for shared credits and streamlined reporting to reduce reporting burdens and resource load, and advocate for STARS as a strategic tool for UC campuses to drive change and add value. We will present UC Merced's and UC Santa Barbara's gap analyses, and share our findings and observations. This session is open to anyone interested in using STARS as a planning and engagement tool; no prior experience with STARS is required to attend this session.
PositionTitle_1: Director of Sustainability and Campus Sustainability Planner

Presentation Title: A Framework for Sustainability Competencies for Your Campus
Description or Abstract: Last fall we published a study on competencies for sustainability, 'Developing a framework for sustainability meta-competencies,' based on interviews and focus groups with Penn State University employees serving in a wide range of functions in that institution. Our intention was to produce common terminology around sustainability that could easily be adopted and applied across university functions. Five sustainability meta-competencies resulted from the work: systems thinking, temporal thinking, interpersonal literacy, ethical literacy and imagination/creativity. This framework assumes that certain foundational competencies are in evidence, including logical thinking, critical thinking, quantitative analysis, reading and writing. This year, our study was named a finalist for the AASHE Campus Sustainability Research Award. Encouraged by this interest in the work, we present a summary of our findings as an invitation for conversation around the importance of these sustainability meta-competencies and their practical application on large and small campuses.

Presentation Title: What is a Residence Life Sustainability Plan?
Description or Abstract: The Department of Residence Life at Texas A&M operates as an auxiliary enterprise to provide student housing to approximately 12,000 students annually. Concurrent to the University's update to the campus-wide Sustainability Master Plan, the Department of Residence Life sought ways to evaluate its contribution to institution-wide sustainability efforts and prioritize future endeavors. Precedent research revealed very few examples of codified sustainability planning within housing and dining operations at peer institutions although many make positive contributions to university-wide efforts. Engaging with the outside consultant Ayers Saint Gross, the Department of Residence Life embarked on a 10-month process to evaluate the capacity of the department's built assets to support sustainable life skills education, determine the availability and efficiency of existing programming in teaching sustainable life skills, and how both its built environment and programming contribute to on-campus housing's competitive advantage in the College Station student housing market.

Presentation Title: Integrating Social Equity: Texas A&M's 2018 Sustainability Master Plan
Description or Abstract: Released in the Spring 2018 semester, Texas A&M's new Sustainability Master Plan has three primary objectives: to better integrate social equity objectives with environmental and economic efforts, to balance the need for long-term structure with short- and medium-term accountability, and to advance the institution's STARS performance. This planning effort, guided by external consultant Ayers Saint Gross, engaged a cross-section of over 460 students, faculty, and staff in an 11-month process to examine nine themes and develop context-specific goals, targets, and actions that will support Aggies in addressing sustainability more comprehensively. The plan highlights social sustainability as an independent subject of equal importance to efforts that address energy use, stormwater management, the built environment, and waste as well as institutional efforts such as curriculum, research, engagement, and administrative support. Join us as we share lessons learned in this case study about how a participatory-decision making process influenced this work's development, how this plan is being implemented to advance sustainability at Texas A&M, and the value of engaging an outside consultant in the process.

Presentation Title: Inducing Paradigm Shifts through Complementary Curricular and Co-curricular Program Engagement
Description or Abstract: The Office of Sustainability (OoS) at the College of Charleston offers a unique work environment. Housed in Business Affairs & led by 2 Staff who also serve as College Faculty, the OoS is well positioned to propose & implement high-impact institutional infrastructure & behavioral changes with the added benefit of helping students develop life skills. Its 7-year history is marked with innovative initiatives & sustained programming. OoS approaches sustainability within and among 5 spheres, which align with the UN's 17 SDG's, with an emphasis on systems thinking. In addition to 2 permanent staff, integral temp staff contribute their area of expertise, institutional knowledge & mentorship, enhancing the student's experience & OoS's productivity & effectiveness. OoS maintains reciprocal, co-created & mutually beneficial community partnerships to position involved parties to be catalysts for change in the pursuit of points of intervention, resulting in a larger impact & level of engagement. These cultivated networks connect students to potential employers & help to further the missions of OoS's partners. Students are encouraged to attend community organization meetings in which Staff are involved to broaden their understanding of sustainability in action, expand their networks, & gain exposure to the challenges of the field within a multi-lensed, synergistic solution context. OoS employs students representing a wide array of academic disciplines, generating dynamic intern cohorts. Methods employed to build team cohesion & a sense of community will be described. Diverse leadership opportunities include the coordination of field trips, guest speakers & personal resilience workshops. All Program requirements are designed to guide these students toward successful outcomes through empowerment & systems knowledge. OoS program highlights will be featured with the goal of providing the audience with helpful insights to advance sustainability-centered programs across higher ed.
PositionTitle_2: Assistant Internship Coordinator, Office of Sustainability

Presentation Title: Preaching Beyond the Choir: How to Institutionalize Sustainability Into Organization-Wide Culture
Description or Abstract: It is easy to get caught up in and become comfortable in a group that shares the same views. We know the people who have our back and who will help champion our missions and passions in life, but it is becoming increasingly challenging to reach across the aisle and communicate with the other side. This is especially true in sustainability when so many people are not purposefully exposed to these ideas in their day to day activities. It may seem like a simple idea to one individual, but to someone who has the opposite view on the situation, or someone who may not have a view at all, it may be more of a challenge to see the potential. The session will take a deep dive into strategies that have worked to integrate sustainability but also those that have failed, as we learn more from our failures in this space. We will highlight specific pilot programs and initiatives that skyrocketed engagement and participation among many groups on campus, not those just involved in sustainability or sustainability related issues. You will specifically hear and learn from a staff member at University of Washington Tacoma who lobbied for the schools' own Center for Leadership and Social Responsibility and another faculty member of Denison University who is the coordinator of the Office of Sustainability on their campus. They will share their barriers and how they pushed past opposing viewpoints to bring sustainability into their institution as a main pillar.

Presentation Title: Go Green or Get Gone: Teachers College as a Case Study
Description or Abstract: What is the role of graduate schools of education in the face of local and global environmental challenges? This session explores this question by presenting the development process and implementation of a strategic plan to enhance the engagement of Teachers College, Columbia University (TC) with sustainability practices and education. Over the past decade, TC supported several faculty initiatives to advance the cause of sustainability. Building upon these efforts and in 2015, the authors established a College-wide Working Group on Environmental and Sustainability Education (ESE). The group developed a three-part strategic plan. The first part was dedicated to crafting a shared definition for ESE. The group examined different definitions and synthesized them into a coherent and inclusive statement that has, in addition to an environmental focus, social equity, inclusion and holistic development. The second part focused on better understanding the mechanisms through which TC can engage in ESE efforts across multiple facets, from facilities to curriculum to research. The group hosted four public roundtables, analyzed survey data from current students, conducted a curriculum mapping of courses relevant to ESE, and identified the need for degree and non-degree programs. The third part, currently ongoing, is dedicated to engaging the NYC's public school system, among the largest in the world. The group is collaborating with the NYC-DOE Office of Sustainability on research and professional development. The group also developed a mentoring program for schools that serve low-income communities and have expressed interest in creating a student green team. In particular, this presentation will describe the process and implementation of our strategic plan, as well as and plans for future for how our inclusive definition of ESE can be woven across the fabric of Teachers College. We will share lesson learned and we will discuss strategies and resources that we found useful.

Presentation Title: Sustainability Goal Setting at Universities: A Nitrogen Action Plan at the University of Virginia
Description or Abstract: A nitrogen (N) footprint is the amount of reactive N released to the environment as a result of an entities' resource use. In 2010, the University of Virginia (UVA) became the first institution to establish an N footprint reduction goal. That goal is to reduce the University's N footprint 25 percent below the 2010 baseline N footprint, by the year 2025. Reaching a 25 percent N footprint reduction at a large, growing university is a challenge. In 2010, Allison Leach and James Galloway, built a Microsoft Excel-based module for calculating an institution N footprint. The development of this tool led to a partnership between UVA and the EPA to develop the Nitrogen Footprint Tool (NFT) Network. The NFT Network is comprised of 21 institutions who have used the N footprint module to calculate, assess, and plan reductions for their campus' N footprint. Hundreds of institutions now have the ability to calculate their N footprints through the Sustainability Indicators Management and Analysis Platform (SIMAP) launched in November 2017. Similarly to UVA, these institutions are faced with the challenge of reducing environmental impacts while growing in population. The main focus of this session will be to discuss feasible ways institutions can set and meet N footprint reduction goals. This session will highlight the development of UVA's Nitrogen Action Plan which outlines the University's proposed N reduction strategies it will implement to meet its goal. The Nitrogen Action Plan was developed alongside the University's Greenhouse Gas Action Plan, Sustainable Food Action Plan, and Materials and Waste Action Plan, among others. Each of these other action plans describes at least one strategies, such as increasing vegetarian meals purchased or investing in utility-scale solar fields, that can also claim N co-benefits. The session will feature a panel of representatives from UVA's Nitrogen Working Group and Office for Sustainability.
PositionTitle_1: Project Manager of the Nitrogen Footprint Network for Institutions

Presentation Title: Developing an Energy Strategy for Sustainability to meet Climate Action Planning Goals
Description or Abstract: As ideas related to sustainability continue to grow on college campuses, college administrators and facilities directors look to develop plans that align campus infrastructure and facilities to fulfill sustainability goals. Lafayette College sought a map to meet upcoming emissions reductions targets and ultimately to become carbon neutral. To support this goal, the College partnered with The Stone House Group, a facilities and energy management consulting firm, to develop a comprehensive Energy Strategy for Sustainability that will ensure the campus has reliable, safe, sustainable, and cost-effective energy infrastructure to support the College's educational mission. Successful stewardship for a campus' facilities is a complex management challenge that requires a comprehensive approach to ensure the College's facilities align with its mission. Although each study is a distinctive process, great synergies exist between them whereby information collected in one study will feed into another study, ultimately creating an integrated energy strategy tailored to Lafayette College's goals, existing conditions, and opportunities. This method yields the ability for facilities directors to make informed decisions about sustainability and resiliency on their campuses, and also provides an economy over using a fragmentary approach. Our multi-faceted, holistic approach consists of: - Participation in the College's Climate Action Plan Committee; Student Engagement; ASHRAE Level 1.5 Energy Audits; ASHRAE Level 3 Energy Audits; Carbon Reduction Strategy; Energy Capital Investment Plan; Utility Master Plan. We will discuss how each study contributed to the overall energy strategy and what best practices were used and learned throughout the process.

Presentation Title: The Power of Process: Thoughtful Engagement for Successful Projects
Description or Abstract: You probably know best practices in, say, composting. Maybe you have researched the best compost haulers, how composting food can reduce GHG emissions, and how it saves water and energy. But what if your expertise doesn't lead to a successful program? What if no one joins you for the ride? This is where engaging everyone, including (maybe especially) your critics, comes in. This session provides an overview as to why creating a thoughtful and engaging planning process is more important than the program itself. With the launch of a campus-wide compost program as a case study, the audience will learn about the steps a major university took to engage all key stakeholders to create a unified compost rollout process that had the buy-in from dining services and custodial staff. This session will cover questions such as: How do you scale up a pilot program? Why it is important to bring your harshest critics to the table when mapping out your plan? How do you effectively use the collective wisdom of the group and develop a program that has staying power? Using campus composting as a case study, participants will learn how meetings were designed to solicit group wisdom, unearth potential barriers to the program's success, and create a space that encouraged critique without fear of escalation into infighting. Finally, participants will walk away with lessons learned, what challenges the groups learned to embrace, and which challenges they were able to overcome.

Presentation Title: The Role of Private Sector Partnership in Sustainable Higher Education Operations & Education
Description or Abstract: Throughout the American University in Cairo's 100-year history, we have strived to be leaders in all we do. Recently, that mission has been applied to sustainability. AUC has implemented meaningful changes that make campus operations more sustainable, but as a globally-oriented university, we always seek to engage with external partners. AUC is a member of the United Nations Global Compact, a network aimed at mainstreaming Sustainable Development Goals in the private sector and the world's largest corporate sustainability initiative. As part of UNGC's Egypt office, AUC has participated in trainings and networked with various Egyptian businesses. Additionally, AUC's School of Business was the first home of the UN's Middle East chapter of Principles for Responsible Management Education, which aims to introduce sustainability and SDGs to business education. Both initiatives have helped AUC's Office of Sustainability move beyond its traditional portfolio of water, energy, and waste to embrace a holistic, SDG-aligned approach to sustainability. AUC's engagement with UNGC and PRME is a case study of how university-private sector partnerships enable sharing best practices and enhance campus sustainability. This approach has been especially critical in Egypt, where public sector and NGO based sustainability initiatives are neither well established nor highly effective and where AUC does not have a large network of peer institutions.
Tags: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs),Principles for Responsible Management Education,UN Global Compact

Presentation Title: Incorporating Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into Collaborative Sustainability Planning
Description or Abstract: Ohio University is proud to have an ambitious and community-created Sustainability Plan, and to reside in a community that values sustainability. Both the City of Athens and Athens County have active sustainability plans, and several local businesses, such as the local hospital, OhioHealth O'Bleness, do as well. However, the goals of the SDGs are even more ambitious than these local sustainability plans - and are so broad that incorporation of SDGs into individual sustainability plans alone is not enough to successfully reach the goals. Successful achievement of goals and targets will only occur when approached synergistically by multiple organizations within a community or region. Ohio University will be restructuring its sustainability efforts into new engagement ecosystems or Sustainability Hubs, to catalyze these synergies. This poster shows how various SDGs could be synergistically incorporated into multiple local sustainability plans to frame and accelerate progress toward sustainability targets. Topics of renewable energy, local procurement, alternative transportation, and health & wellness in our Appalachian community are addressed.

Presentation Title: Global Priorities, Educated Solutions: the Role of Academia in Advancing the SDGs
Description or Abstract: In 2015, the Office of Sustainability created a project aimed at understanding how Yale's teaching and research aligns with the SDGs, with the purposes of: (i) identifying pathways for collaboration between disciplines; (ii) providing a rationale for thinking of higher education sustainability beyond operational commitments; (iii) identifying the expertise Yale might lend to the process of achieving the SDGs. Data has been collected on over 3,000 Yale faculty members. Results show that every department at Yale has at least one faculty member whose scholarship relates to the SDGs, and Yale's scholarship touches each SDG. The university is using this data to foster collaboration between faculty with shared interests. Paralleling the internal effort, Yale has been leading an initiative through the International Alliance of Research Universities to explore the role of universities in advancing the SDGs. In June 2018, IARU will host a half-day event during the International Sustainable Campus Network annual conference in Stockholm. This program will be divided into four themes: (i) Scholarship for solutions: teaching and research in the context of the SDGs. (ii) Walking the talk: how campuses can lead by example in terms of operational excellence and using the campus as a test bed for innovation. (iii) Next generation innovation: the role of students in advancing world-changing ideas. (iv) Service for society: universities as thought-leaders and collaborative partners.

Presentation Title: Case Study Revisited: Confirming how to Achieve Progressive Campus Sustainability Measures
Description or Abstract: A decade has passed since previous qualitative research was collected and evaluated to determine how three campuses achieved progressive measures of environmental sustainability. The findings of this comparative case study were considered when evaluating how South Dakota State University underwent change to move towards progressive sustainability actions. A number of individual case studies describing what certain institutions have done could be found; however, limited research existed to examine how institutions achieved their green success. The original research compared progressive measures of sustainability based on six aspects of sustainability that emerged in the literature review: green campus operation measures; campus administration, organization, and leadership; teaching, research, and service; campus wide actions and activities; institutional assessment of campus sustainability measures; and how each campus overcame barriers (James & Card, 2012). Using the same six identified categories of evaluation and the findings therein, South Dakota State University was recently examined and confirmed these findings. With respect to the role of higher education in achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), institutions can make a significant impact in promoting a sustainable future. 'Few, if any, sectors of American society are better positioned than U.S. higher education - and perhaps none face the moral imperative - to lead on issues of environmental performance and sustainability' (McIntosh, Gaalswyk, Keniry, & Eagan ,2008, p. 4). The findings of this current study identify and promote evidenced based leadership and practice in higher education, organizational management, and in turn, the SDG's of the United Nations.

Presentation Title: Overcoming Administrative Barriers in Waste Management Projects
Description or Abstract: My project will be primarily covering the barriers that many students face when trying to implement new sustainable projects on their campuses. The focus of my project will be a case study of my attempt to implement a nitrile glove recycling program on my campus during a period in which administration was wary of new sustainable projects. I will cover the steps I took, issues that arose, and lessons learned in hopes that my struggles will teach other students what to do (and what not to do) when working with different types of faculty.

Presentation Title: Is STARS Pre-Submission Review Required Now?
Description or Abstract: As part of our efforts to improve STARS data quality, AASHE released a STARS Review Template and conducted a STARS Review Pilot in spring 2018. Over a dozen Pilot participants used the template to identify and resolve potential data inconsistencies prior to submitting their STARS report. This session will begin with an overview of the Pilot results, including a summary of how data accuracy was impacted, and what requirements and incentives will be in place for pre-submission review in the upcoming version, STARS 2.2. A panel of Pilot participants will describe their experience using the review template and completing the Pre-submission review credit, and the session will conclude with audience discussion.

Presentation Title: STARS Town Hall
Description or Abstract: This session will feature a preview of the next version of STARS (2.2) from AASHE staff and will also provide an opportunity for attendees to pose questions and participate in a high-level discussion about potential improvements to the program. This will be a great opportunity to learn more about the technical development of STARS and to have your voice be heard in how the program evolves.

Presentation Title: Shooting for the STARS - How your Campus can use STARS to Measure Progress Toward the SDGs
Description or Abstract: In late 2017, the University of Calgary was selected by public vote as a UN Sustainable Development Goal winner in Canada. The majority of outcomes that attracted this positive recognition largely came from the university's STARS submission. During this session, learn how to practically leverage your work toward campus sustainability reporting to profile your institution as a leading contributor to the SDGs. Attendees can expect an interactive session that demonstrates how STARS credits can map directly to the seventeen UN SDGs, allowing institutions to raise the profile of their work among a new and broader audiences.

Presentation Title: Sustainability in the C-Suite: Preliminary Study Results
Description or Abstract: Sustainability can be a strategic driver when the function is included at the highest level of an organization. What are the most innovative leaders in higher education, business, and government doing to ensure that sustainability is integrated at the highest level of strategy and decision making? Professionals and graduate students from three institutions and two businesses have come together to find answers to this question. Conversations on leadership in sustainability from AASHE 2017 inspired this study that is plumbing the minds of college presidents, CEOs, professional recruiters, and senior professionals across the country through interviews and surveys. This presentation will reveal preliminary findings and reflections upon answers to questions such as: - How does a sustainability philosophy manifest in executive-level decision-making? - What are the compelling factors that motivate CEOS/Presidents to establish the positions? - What are senior leaders' perceptions of sustainability professionals? What are the perceptions of sustainability professionals? - What are the key pathways to including sustainability at the C-suite level ? - What are the actual structures (job descriptions, reporting structures, etc.) that allow it to manifest? - How do sustainability leaders use their backgrounds and philosophy to influence executive-level decision making? - There has been a spike in growth in the field over the past ten years - but it has recently plateaued.

Presentation Title: Leveraging the Campus Sustainability Committee: Zombie Committees vs Robust Change Agents
Description or Abstract: What is the secret to successful sustainability committees? Is there a magic formula for long-term effectiveness or do the committees need to evolve over time? Once sustainability programs become more institutionalized, are these committees even necessary? Does your committee on campus struggle to stay focused and action oriented? How does the need for, and objectives of, multi-stakeholder committees change over time? How do you maintain or revitalize interest over the long-term? Who should even be on your committee? Join sustainability experts from four different universities (Duke, NC State, Cornell and UMass Amherst) who will be the first to admit that this struggle is real folks! Discover the strategies they have used with their committees to advance sustainability planning and implementation on their campuses. Participate in a brainstorming session to crowd source our collective sustainability committee wisdom!

Presentation Title: Strategies for an Actionable Sustainability Plan: Tools and Lessons Learned From the Field
Description or Abstract: A common institutional challenge is to find an appropriate process for developing or revisiting strategic plans to advance sustainability, resilience, and climate action. Though a one-size-fits-all model has not emerged, there are highly replicable tools and approaches that can be borrowed and then adapted to each campus context. Representatives from American University, Santa Clara University, and the University of North Carolina Charlotte will speak to their recently completed planning processes, laying out process and goals, highlighting tools used, and sharing lessons learned from unique planning efforts. These institutions are at different stages of maturity in sustainability achievements, but their planning efforts held common challenges of establishing foundational values ('why'), expanding scope ('what'), and supporting implementation partners ('how'). American University is conducting resilience planning through an assessment workshop and the creation of an accountability structure built through consensus. Santa Clara University is updating a climate action plan into a strategic sustainability plan that provides tools like roadmaps, playbooks and metric-tracking. UNC Charlotte used compliance with university policies to frame a sustainability plan to address 3 strategic initiatives and their carbon commitment. The session will focus on usable, replicable insights and recommended actions, drawing upon both successes and failures.
PositionTitle_2: Director of Partnerships and Strategic Initiatives

Presentation Title: State of the Association Address: AASHE Member Meeting
Description or Abstract: Come join the AASHE Board and Staff while we present the AASHE 'state of the organization' address. You'll hear highlights from the member survey, programmatic priorities, and AASHE's vision for the upcoming year. You will also have a chance to ask questions and provide suggestions.

Presentation Title: AASHE Advisory Council Annual Meeting
Description or Abstract: During this one-hour meeting, AASHE staff will provide a review of the Advisory Council work over the last year and provide an opportunity to discuss any current topics.

Presentation Title: Sustainability Workshop Series
Description or Abstract: Northern Michigan University: EcoReps cohort one Sustainability Workshop Series This poster highlights the structure, funding, and success of the Sustainability Workshop Series piloted by Northern Michigan University EcoReps in the winter of 2018. Each workshop was developed and led by students on topics they were specifically interested in. The goal of this program was to capture student enthusiasm for sustainability while demonstrating that EcoReps could successfully execute campus wide programming. Throughout the semester, topics in all aspects of sustainability were covered. The workshop series was well accepted by students and people in the community. Each attendee completed a feedback form that will be used in future development of the program. This workshop series was an intrical part of EcoReps receiving funding from the university in May of 2018. After receiving funding, the Sustainability Workshop Series has become institutionalized within EcoReps and is constantly being developed and reviewed. EcoReps will use the feedback provided by attendees to continue developing the workshop series to cater to students as well as the community.

Presentation Title: Using STARS reporting as a framework for a modular campus sustainability plan
Description or Abstract: Creating a campus sustainability plan can be a daunting and complex task. In addition, limited staff and financial resources may also be barriers to creating a robust sustainability plan. The University of Washington is working on a comprehensive campus sustainability plan that will develop and implement modules of a larger plan individually rather than producing the entire plan all at once. To identify the modules, we began by using the four main categories of STARS. We then consolidated related topics to a smaller list of 12 sections, further broken into 20 module plans that would need to be developed based on the distinctness of the topics and the subject matter experts that would be engaged to create the module plan. For example, 'Academics' and 'Research' is one section but will actually be two distinct module plans. This modular planning process allows the sustainability office to work on pieces of the overall sustainability plan as resources are available, culminating in a comprehensive plan. This presentation will outline the process UW went through to identify areas for the sustainability plan, as well as the planning tools and resources the UW Sustainability office has used to lead the process.

Presentation Title: Teach Environmental Sustainability via Children's Literature
Description or Abstract: We propose to share methods of integration into curriculum and resources for teacher-educators to reach their students, starting with elementary students and continuing on up the grades, K-12. Because children's literature conveys information in the highly appealing and memorable form of storytelling, we propose to share the curricula that our team of faculty and students have developed over the past seven years. In particular, we wish to share our ever-growing list of book titles that have proved effective at conveying the principles of environmental sustainability. Our purpose is to share our sustainability curriculum and book list with teacher-educators, so that they can put these materials to immediate use, without having to start from scratch. Since 2012, nearly 800 students (elementary education majors and speech language pathologist majors) from the University of Wisconsin, River Falls have undertaken to create this curriculum to use in the schools where they would teach. Each student chose a sustainability topic and located Web resources and children's books to support the topic. They created lesson plans from scratch, and made certain that these plans would accommodate: Formative assessments Different kinds of learning styles Appeal to varying age-groups of students. In addition, to inspire their students, they integrated information about sustainable environmental projects all along the St. Croix River, which serves as the geographical boundary between Minnesota and Wisconsin. By now, our curriculum and booklist has been put to use in the classroom by hundreds of teachers, not only via our own graduates, but via the other teacher-educators in the schools where our graduates teach. The curriculum and booklist are simple, easy to put into practice, and by now these materials have reached thousands of students in our region.

Presentation Title: Mindful Unbuilding: A Zero Waste Campus-Community Adventure
Description or Abstract: What does a university do with a vacant old house that cannot be restored? Ordinarily: bulldoze it and haul it away to a landfill. But what if you were to take it apart, piece by piece, discovering what it's made of, where those materials came from, what secrets they keep, what stories they could tell, and what value they might still hold? In this presentation, we recount the two-year sequence of courses through which students, faculty, facilities staff, and community members worked together to deconstruct the house situated next to DePauw's campus farm, seeking to maximize not only the materials that could be salvaged for reuse and recycling, but also the educational potential embedded in the structure. We studied the ways places, houses, and objects can matter to people; apprenticed in the green art of rescuing, revitalizing and reusing building materials; and explored scientific research, scholarship, and creative works that reconceive the stuff we produce, consume, and throw 'away.' Mindful unbuilding taught us to look deeply into physical materials themselves - where they come from, where they go, and how they fit into the global materials economy. It taught us a great deal about the physical construction of buildings as well as the tools and techniques of deconstruction. Perhaps most importantly, it taught us to recognize this house as more than the sum of its material parts - as a hitherto Home, for People of character in our community, with a History, in a Place. Since all universities engage in renovation projects and increasingly look to deconstruction as an alternative to demolition, we seek to inspire creative high-impact collaborations that connect the liberal arts curriculum with the built environment, building a shared, 'concrete' understanding of the social dimensions of sustainability - helping us to reclaim the value of people and places as well as things.

Presentation Title: Re-Design Certificate: Regenerative Ecological Design
Description or Abstract: United Nations Environmental Program has claimed that our planet is amid its sixth major extinction of biological diversity. U.N. scientists estimate that 150-200 species become extinct every 24 hours. The leading cause of species decline is loss or contamination of native habitats. Current building patterns co-opt land and turn diverse ecosystems into anthropocentric monoculture, at roughly the rate of 2 million acres of U.S. open space per year. The need for continual growth is unavoidable, especially in the face of human relocation due to climate change. However, there are techniques that can be applied to reduce impact. While preserving land is important, it is not enough to offset the rate of growth and only increases the disconnect between humans and nature. Anthropocentric built environments are destroying native ecosystems at an alarming rate, this decline is just one of many issues that can be addressed through such problem-solving tools as systems dynamics science and ecological design thinking taught at the Ecosa Institute for Ecological Design. Our curriculum at the Ecosa Institute challenge the concept of built environments in conflict with nature and launched a new design revolution. Our curriculum is beyond interdisciplinary, its multi-disciplinary and cyclical in its nature. Our students are; architects, engineers, city planners, restoration scientist, and designers, who design for multiple species using a system's approach wherein biological diversity is enhanced, and resources are created instead of extracted. Our Design Strategy begins with ecology, biology, hydrology, and climatology evolving into an architectural and engineering design process to produce buildings that mimic and regenerate natural environments instead of degrading or compromising them. Our ultimate design challenge is to design a campus that serve the needs of humans and nature alike.

Presentation Title: Scenario Planning and Applied Learning in Sustainability Practica
Description or Abstract: Scenario planning is a versatile and widely applicable tool for developing robust strategies for dealing with uncertainty. It is used across numerous domains including national visioning and transition efforts, military preparedness, long-term corporate and business strategic decision making, and educational reform initiative among others. Over the past four years we have been teaching the technique to students in a practicum course that is part of the Middlebury School of the Environment currlcula. Students use it to develop a range of future scenarios based on key uncertainties they identify that will directly impact the resilience of the campus and the region to climate change. This panel will present the version of scenario planning we have developed for this purpose, share examples of how it has been applied, what makes it work well and not so well, and how it has been received by students.

Presentation Title: STARS Reporting as an Undergraduate Educational Opportunity
Description or Abstract: The University of Illinois, a STARS Gold Campus, has a strong focus on expanding its campus sustainability efforts. Since our 2017 report, administrators have made an increased effort to align strategies to meet existing Climate Action Plan goals with targeted efforts in line with current STARS Criteria. One key strategy UIUC began this year is enlisting the help of undergraduate seniors. As part of the Capstone experience for U of I's minor in Sustainability, Energy, and Environment, students delve into the institution's STARS report as well as those of peers to identify major areas of improvement and strategies to address them. In addition to providing a valuable deliverable to campus for immediate impact, students entering the sustainability field do so with an intimate understanding of the the leading certification of higher education sustainability. During this session, attendees will gain a deep understanding of the course framework and curriculum, initial outcomes from the first round of efforts, and ways the program can be tailored to other campuses.

Presentation Title: Demonstrating Impact Through SDG Cases - Creating Common Language and Shared Purpose Across Campus
Description or Abstract: The UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) exist as a Global platform for taking action to achieve sustainable development. The SDGs recognize that staying within our planetary boundaries and achieving sustainable development requires global effort by civil society, from all governments, and across all business sectors. Universities and private institutions around the world now find themselves facing a similar challenge, which is to identify how to apply the SDGs. To address this challenge, cross-border partnerships are being formed between universities and private organizations, combining innovation and knowledge resources to achieve sustainable impact. This session will demonstrate how the Danish consultancy company DEM has collaborated with universities including Aarhus University, Denmark, and the Harvard Office for Sustainability to develop SDG Cases for strategy planning and food standards. Each of these cases is connected by a common, replicable methodology, which lies in identifying SMART indicators (KPIs). Once these measurable indicators are in place, they are linked to specific Sustainable Development Goals and SDG Targets, so that impact can be tracked over time. This session will cover the benefits that can be achieved by university faculty, students and organizations applying this methodology to their work with the SDGs. This session will also cover a range of opportunities that exist for forming multi-stakeholder partnerships. Outcomes of this type of collaboration include raising awareness about sustainable development, generating new ideas for sustainability initiatives and their measurement, and reaching a broad range of stakeholders with a common language and shared purpose provided by the Global Goals.
Tags: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs),case based learning,performance indicators

Presentation Title: AIM2Flourish: Transforming Management Education Through Positive Business Innovation Stories
Description or Abstract: The UN Global Goals are the 'World's Must-Do List' to end poverty, combat climate change, protect life on land, and ensure a livable future for all people. Many business leaders are responding to the call to do well by doing good. In the same way, students want to change the story about business. They believe that business can be both positive and profitable, and they are eager to learn how. The Fowler Center for Business as an Agent of World Benefit's AIM2Flourish is a transformational, experiential learning assignment to prepare rising business leaders to be powerful forces for doing good while doing well. Come learn about how you can use our (free) resources to teach your students more about the potential for business to be an agent of world benefit and offer them the opportunity to learn first-hand from a business leader. The Fowler Center's AIM2Flourish is a class assignment that connects students one-on-one with a business leader for insight and inspiration. Using the UN Global Goals as a lens, students research and identify a positive and profitable business innovation, conduct an in-person 'Appreciative Inquiry' interview with a business leader, and then write about what they learned. These stories of business innovation as an agent of world benefit are published on AIM2Flourish.com to serve as inspiration for others. *The Fowler Center for Business as an Agent of World Benefit is at the Weatherhead School of Management at Case Western Reserve University.

Presentation Title: Service and Community Engaged Learning for Social and Environmental Justice
Description or Abstract: Service-Learning / Community Engaged Learning is a common practice in higher education and is increasingly found being paired with sustainability. This networking session will allow practitioners to share best practices, learn from each other, and create a forum for further discussion around the ideas of service-learning acting as a conduit or vehicle for dialogic problem solving in higher education, focusing on specific topics relevant to sustainability. Topics such as: — Globalization and local strategies for human development — Food, nutrition and healthcare in a global environment — Energy world watch for sustainable development — World population movement and growth — New media, information tech, intercultural communication — World traditions of wisdom and their contemporary relevance Depending on the size and interest of the group, the group could discuss logistical issues, including: Third party partners Funding hurdles Pre-and-post student volunteer education and engagement Campus as Living Laboratory/ Campus Partners.

Presentation Title: From Theory to Practice: Applied Community Projects in Environmental Capstone Courses
Description or Abstract: Over the past five years, Environmental Studies and Environmental Sustainability seniors at Earlham College have completed an 'integrated research project (IRP)' in collaboration with a community partner. The IRP is part of the requirements of these students' Senior Capstone Course and is a team project designed to integrate approaches from the many disciplines that contribute to Environmental Studies. In most years, the students have partnered with a department within the City of Richmond, Indiana, on this project. Projects have varied in focus, including a plan to rejuvenate the local Farmers' Market, an evaluation of neighborhood revitalization efforts, design of and fundraising for a sensory playground, and development of a revitalization plan for a reservoir. These projects offer students the opportunity to put into practice many of the concepts they have learned about throughout their college careers while also offering a deliverable product to the community partner. Learning moves from the classroom to the real world, allowing students to make a difference in the local community and to consider their role, as temporary residents of Richmond, in helping to promote community well-being and sustainability. This poster will focus on the 2018 Capstone Project and offer faculty, student, and partner perspectives on the IRP, focusing on benefits, challenges, and lessons learned.

Presentation Title: Uniting Human Rights and Sustainability Across the University
Description or Abstract: The United Nations Agenda 2030 and Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) are a powerful framework for alleviating human suffering and achieving social and environmental justice. However, making progress on the the SDGs requires robust, multifaceted collaborations across many disciplines or issue areas and such interdisciplinary collaborations are rare. We believe our experiences show that breaking down the divisions between human rights, sustainability, social justice, procurement, environmental, fair trade, and other issue areas can yield very powerful, positive results. Such holistic, inclusive, collaborative thinking and acting is required if we want to accomplish systemic change. The University of Dayton (UD) has identified combining Sustainability and Human Rights as a major strategic priority. A member of the UN Global Compact, the university is committed to fair, ethical, and sustainable sourcing, education, scholarship, and community development. For twenty years, UD has been engaged in human rights education, research, and advocacy. A key component of that work has been working against human trafficking and forced labor. More recently, the university has broadened its focus to include issues of sustainability--including a divestment from all fossil fuel-based holdings. Involvement in these issues is spread across the campus and local community: Student life, research and scholarship, centers and institutes, campus engagement, academics, purchasing, facilities, etc.
PositionTitle_3: Executive Director Procurement and Payable Services

Presentation Title: From the 3Es to the SDGs: Updating Sustainability Frameworks Used as Educational Tools
Description or Abstract: With the 2015 announcement of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the 2030 Agenda, the Paris Climate Agreement, and the multitude of research projects, policies, and frameworks of Sustainable Development created as a result in the past three years, there is an urgent need for higher education sustainability to update its common educational tools to better reflect these recent innovations. Students coming of age now, and the professionals who work with and teach them, must all become more fluent in this new language of sustainability at the global and local scales. The 3Es, pillars, or legs of sustainability; the triple-bottom line; and the overlapping circles or nested dependencies of sustainability are all exemplary models of simplicity and mnemonic devices. But there is value in considering whether they satisfactorily capture all that they should. Does it really make sense to identify only three or so aspects of sustainability when there are now 17 SDGs? How can we succinctly capture so many diverse aspects of our shared vision for our planet into one, introductory model? The onus falls on faculty and staff in higher education to develop such a model(s). In this panel, we hope to provide instruction on several early-stage efforts that draw on both the SDGs and the concept of planetary boundaries. Melissa Tier, Sustainability Program Manager at Swarthmore College, will discuss a prototype 'Sustainability Sandwich' based on economist Kate Raworth's model.

Presentation Title: Sustainability in American Topics: US History, Conservation, and Sustainable Development Goals
Description or Abstract: Feasted Landscapes: Sustainability in American Topics' is the title of a two-volume reader that contains a collection of primary sources and original short essays that focus on sustainability issues throughout American history in economy, environment and society. The curriculum is intended for college courses in humanities, liberal arts, natural sciences, or sustainability, with discussion questions at end of each unit and an online platform with supplemental resources and videos for interactive student learning. This session will cover an overview from the co-authors of how the textbook was developed, including the Sustainable Development Goals. Volume 1 is a historical context from Pre-Columbian to the Civil War, and Volume 2 continues from Civil War to the present day. Excerpts and highlights of the textbooks include notable authors like Rachel Carson and John Muir, legislation like the Wilderness Act and the New Deal, topics of Monarch Butterflies and Water Conservation, and important social issues throughout U.S. history such as the Johnstown Flood, Sanitation Workers, and Occupy Wall Street. Attendees of this session will also work in breakout groups to develop curriculum for college courses that incorporate three or more of the Sustainable Development Goals and focus on important issues in the history of the United States and present day.

Presentation Title: Pursuing the SDGs in Education Abroad: Tools, Techniques, and Assessment Strategies
Description or Abstract: Well-designed education abroad programs expose students to the many ways other cultures prioritize and pursue the UN SDG's. Foreign approaches to sustainability, biodiversity, and social justice reveal to students abroad the culturally distinct skills, attitudes and behavioral habits that can be experienced, assimilated, assessed and--more importantly--transferred back home. How do we design programs that go beyond cultural learning and help students experience--through comparative approaches to implementing the SDGs--how other people live lives far more sustainable than theirs? How do we situate sustainability literacy within cross-cultural contexts and use assessment instruments like the culturally adaptable Sulitest to measure attitudinal and behavioral change both within and across cultures. This session highlights tools and techniques for advancing the SDGs through study abroad. Session learning outcomes include: Recognize that the mission of study abroad must include student learning outcomes related to the SDGs. Appreciate the urgency with which educators abroad should regard sustainable behavior as a critical learning outcome of study abroad. Identify policies, activities and assessment techniques--notably the Sulitest--that lead to learning outcomes in education abroad focused upon the SDGs. Develop advocacy skills for building stakeholder commitment to the SDGs into the ethos and outcomes of education abroad.

Presentation Title: Green Chemistry: Meeting the Challenge of Equity and Environmental Justice for a Sustainable Future
Description or Abstract: Chemistry is an inherently creative yet reductionist approach to understanding how the world works at the most fundamental levels. Chemists are trained to create molecules to fill a given need or that have a particular function. While this has produced incredible innovations that has allowed global population growth through advances in agriculture and technology, it has also had unintended negative consequences on human health and the environment. These impact have disproportionately impacted people of color and lower socioeconomic classes. Green and sustainable chemistry principles and practices aim to train chemists to use life cycle or systems thinking to reduce waste and increase resource efficiency in the development of chemicals and chemical processes. Is it implicit that green chemistry supports our definitions of equity and environmental justice, where all people have the right to live, work, play and learn in healthy, safe environments? The goals of this presentation are to identify ways chemists can partner with other stakeholders to advance the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Chemists will be critical partners in many of the SDGs, including: SDG 4 (advancing quality education); SDG 6 (clean water and sanitation); SDG 7 (affordable and clean energy); SDG 8 (decent work & economic growth); SDG 9 (industry, innovation, and infrastructure); SDG 10 (reduced inequalities); SDG 12 (responsible consumption and production); SDG 13 (climate action).
Academic_Discipline_1: Physical & Earth Sciences (Chemistry, Geology, Atmospheric Sciences, etc)

Presentation Title: The Sustainability Exchange at Washington University - Interdisciplinary Focus on Real World Issues
Description or Abstract: The Sustainability Exchange, founded in 2014 by Bill Lowry and Liz Kramer, brings together students from across the academic spectrum to focus on and seek solutions to real world issues and projects. Potential projects are proposed during registration for the upcoming semester and students self-select depending on their interest and expertise. The number of projects activated depends on the number of students that enroll. The innovation that underlies the Sustainability Exchange is bringing students together that don't normally get a chance to interact academically. The course itself has two parts, the first part provides students with critical creative problem-solving tools, collaboration models and sustainability philosophy; the second part has the students apply these tools to typically 5 focused real world projects or barriers. Each project focus group is comprised of 4-5 students and 1 to 2 professors/advisors/clients. As the problem statements are open-ended and have not necessarily been 'solved', the students are challenged to creatively utilize each other's expertise and collaborate on a sustainable solution. The students themselves chart the direction of the class and their advisors/professors/clients help them achieve their goals without directing them to a solution, a process that can be quite unnerving for certain types of students.

Presentation Title: How to Create an Innovative and Interdisciplinary Sustainability Major
Description or Abstract: This case study examines several innovative degree programs that create unusual disciplinary alliances with sustainability. Integrating sustainability across the curriculum is an important goal for AASHE members. While many universities have developed interdisciplinary sustainability majors or minors affiliated with Environmental Sciences, a broadening to non-traditional partners is underway. For instance, as a way to locate sustainability within the larger globalization discourse, the University of Virginia introduced an undergraduate major in Global Environments + Sustainability. This program joins three interdisciplinary Global Studies programs in Public Health, Development Studies, and Security & Justice. As Director of that program, the presenter will discuss the conceptual framework, curriculum and implementation process of this complex partnership between six academic units. The session will also examine interdisciplinary sustainability programs in Bioethics, Entrepreneurship, Environmental Design, Food Science and Fashion Design. Columbia University has launched a unique Master of Science program in Bioethics & Sustainability Management, while the University of Vermont offers an innovative MBA in Sustainable Entrepreneurship. Session participants will be encouraged to imagine new possibilities for their schools, while examining the challenges and opportunities for creating innovative interdisciplinary sustainability degree programs across the country and globally.

Presentation Title: Escaping the Silos and Generating Collaborations: A Sustainable Faculty Development Program
Description or Abstract: The Faculty Affiliates Program gives faculty from all departments on our campus opportunities to meet monthly during the academic year to share ideas, generate resources and foster interdisciplinary connections throughout the university. This program fosters collaboration through these monthly meetings as well as through the network created by the program, and its associated interdisciplinary annual faculty grant program. This program's unique aim to provide connections between disciplines, research, and faculty across the university gives it a value that is not often found in higher education where siloed departments are the norm. In its 10th year, the program has had the opportunity to prove its worth and mature into long term sustainability. The program is run by the David E.
