Shi Center for Sustainability, a first of its kind academic department that leverages the strengths of a liberal arts institution by serving all faculty, all students, and all academic departments within the university. We serve as an animation hub which facilitates inter- and trans-disciplinary learning and research through the lens of sustainability. The Faculty Affiliates Program joins a suite of programs that cater to faculty, staff, students, and our community. This presentation will detail the naissance and history of the program, delineate the program's components, and describe the benefits and challenges of the program. This information will provide the spark to inspire participants to seek possibilities for their home institutions. Interactive elements will be used to ensure reflection and idea generation.
PositionTitle_1: Associate Director of Sustainability Programs, David E. Shi Center for Sustainability

Presentation Title: A New Resource To Engage Your Chemistry Department In Sustainability
Description or Abstract: Despite the underlying fundamental reliance on chemistry innovations for a more sustainable future, undergraduate chemistry teaching laboratories still use traditional experiments that are resource-intensive and employ hazardous reagents. It is imperative that we educate the next generation of scientists to design experiments with sustainability in mind. It is also critical to the sustainability goals of most campuses that the environmental impact of laboratories is reduced. The recently released 'A Guide to Green Chemistry Experiments for Undergraduate Organic Chemistry Labs' seeks to address these concerns by providing educators with a set of safer, greener alternative organic chemistry experiments to demonstrate key transformations to undergraduate chemistry students. This presentation will focus on how to use the guide to engage the chemistry department in campus sustainability efforts, and will elaborate on ways it can assist campuses in meeting their sustainability goals.
Academic_Discipline_1: Physical & Earth Sciences (Chemistry, Geology, Atmospheric Sciences, etc)

Presentation Title: Pulling the Paradox of the SDGs down to Uneven Ground: A Transdisciplinary Learning Journey
Description or Abstract: Advocates of the Sustainable Development Goals see them as an important improvement over the Millennium Development Goals, that expired in 2015, that represent an inspiring and inclusive framework for international collective action over the next twelve years: The SDGs are universal: they apply to everyone, all countries, and they are intended to alter underlying conditions that violate the principles of sustainability, and not just respond to symptoms. But for others, the SDGs represent an instance of top-down planning efforts that 'shows what happens when a bureaucratic process runs out of control;' a naïve wish list of 'unactionable, unquantifiable, and unattainable' goals and targets. And in between are those that say the SDGs are ok as far as they go, but are undermined by glaring omissions and gaps with potentially destructive implications; or that while they are far from perfect, they reflect a core principle of inclusivity that is central to their value as an integrated system of goals going forward. If higher education is to clarify its role or roles in achieving the SDGs, we will have to actively embrace divergent views of what the SDGs are and what they represent, including a range of alternative and conflicting futures that they implicate. We will have to call on a kind of paradoxical intelligence that can hold opposing truths and navigate ambiguity as we manage uncertainty and disagreement; and we will need to cultivate practical wisdom through learning.
PositionTitle_1: Executive Director Sustainability Institute/Chief Sustainability Officer
PositionTitle_2: Affiliate GUND institute for Environment, Lecturer Honors College and Romance Lang. & Linguistics

Presentation Title: Building on the NAE Grand Challenges Scholars Model to Incorporate the UN SDGs in Higher Education
Description or Abstract: As sustainability becomes a more and more popular addition in the higher education system, attempts to incorporate it into existing curricula and campus life diversify and too often lose their efficiency and purpose. Students become overwhelmed by the options and the myriad of overlapping missions. There is a growing need for a unifying program under which interested personnel could come to and relate their ideas. Recognizing this need, Bucknell University is exploring the incorporation of the UN Sustainable Development Goals into academic endeavors by building on the National Academy of Engineering's Grand Challenges Scholars Program. By matching the Sustainable Development Goals with corresponding NAE Grand Challenges, the efforts to integrate sustainability into the higher education system could become more synchronized and thus more effective. Although the goals may not match up completely, they provide a broad platform for which universities and colleges can consider meaning and take action upon. As exemplified, the GCSP at Bucknell benefits from this extended synchronization as these goals no longer apply too exclusively with engineering majors. This allows for more interdisciplinary projects between majors, both between faculty members and students. Service learning experiences required by GCSP take on more diverse and vital roles under the Sustainable Development Goals theme, as they focus more specifically on more than the humanitarian aspect of the process. In conclusion, incorporating the Sustainable Development Goals into the NAE Grand Challenges Program would lead to a more fruitful pathway into sustainability in higher education. Motivated students and faculty are no longer bound by the limits of the exclusionary program, and as more people take on the challenge, we better ourselves for the quest for sustainability. Bucknell University has dedicated itself to this mission, and hope more institutions do the same.

Presentation Title: Experience The SDGs Abroad: Reimagine Your Curriculum with The GREEN Program
Description or Abstract: The GREEN Program (TGP) is an experiential education and workforce development program for young leaders in sustainable development. Created for students, by students, TGP has introduced a new model for education abroad- driven by a desire to provide purposeful, hands-on industry exposure at a fraction of the time and cost. Inspired by the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals, our short-term, accredited, career focused approach creates truly transformative experiences for students around the world- unlocking doors to governmental, public, and private facility access, exclusive tours, and unique bucket-list experiences. Our unique partnerships with universities around the world allow our students to have a truly authentic experience by learning from local professors, experts and government officials that are working to advance the Global Goals. TGP seeks to redefine the classroom by enabling one-of-a-kind experiences like studying the effects of climate change on the top of our world's glaciers. Our presentation will review our unique educational and partnership models as a case study. We have had success bringing over 2500 student leaders abroad and have partnered with universities including Drexel, University of Pennsylvania, Australia National University, and Penn State. We'd love to connect with faculty and staff who are interested in learning from our model and using international education as part of their curriculum.

Presentation Title: Best Practices in Integrating Sustainability and Business Education
Description or Abstract: This workshop focuses on how to integrate sustainability concepts into business education and increase engagement with the business community to improve their impacts. The primary focus will be on how the 'B Corp Impact Assessment' framework can be used to integrate sustainability into business curriculum while facilitating crossdisciplinary engagement with non-business students and faculty. Faculty members will discuss how they have integrated sustainable development concepts into business curriculum, and business concepts into sustainability-related curricula, particularly among environmental disciplines. We will also discuss how the SDgs, and in particular their measurement, are shaping the design of business education to integrate sustainability principles. With the development of the UN Global Compact, which helps organizations identify business opportunities that help achieve the SDGs, as wells the UN Principles for Responsible Investing, which is focused on impact investing, the business community has been called to action to work through partnerships with the public sector to pursue courses of action to achieve global goals. Impact Assessment frameworks help businesses identify and measure the material impacts their operations have on environmental and social resources, which is the necessary first step in improving these impacts and sustainability performance.

Presentation Title: Teaching Sustainability and Environmental Stewardship Through Contemporary Art
Description or Abstract: What role can art play in solving current environmental challenges? What should artists do to promote awareness? Is it ethical for artists to make more objects in a world already littered with too many? These are questions students grapple with in an art history course I regularly teach on contemporary environmental art. In this AASHE session, people outside the 'art world' as well as those working in art and art history are invited to tackle them, too. I present the broad outlines of my course, and highlight how 'Contemporary Art in an Age of Global Warming' is helping the Environmental Studies program at a small liberal arts college instill in students an understanding of key principles of sustainability -- including the value and necessity of creative, inter- and multidisciplinary, collaborative approaches to problem-solving. Session attendees will be tasked with finding connections between their own course material, campus sustainability efforts and a sampling of artworks; an interactive exercise I use in my class will provide a framework. I conclude by describing a final project assignment I have developed and sharing successful collaborations my students have forged with campus sustainability and facilities staff, and with key constituents in the broader community of the town.

Presentation Title: Advancing Sustainability: Student-led Projects, Interdisciplinary Studies, and Inter-Silo Teamwork
Description or Abstract: Carleton College's study abroad program titled 'Sustainable Energy Principles and Practices in India' exemplifies how higher education institutions can foster experiences and skills that students can use to promote sustainable development. The physics program involved a pre-departure course where students learned about the complexity of energy, what sustainability means in a developing country, and the interdisciplinary nature of these issues. While students were abroad in Auroville, they met with nonprofits, businesses, and individuals to delve deeper into the mentioned issues. Back in the US, students enrolled in a post-program course in which they focused their efforts on sustainability projects, such as developing a Climate Action Plan for the City of Northfield, and carrying out the '2017 Lighting Audit Project.' These two projects, in particular, suggest how institutions can help students gain the skills necessary to promote sustainability by fostering collaboration across organizational silos to achieve a desired goal. The '2017 Lighting Audit Project' successfully brought together students, faculty, and staff in a project that would save $17,000 a year, receive $66,000 in funding, and mitigate 155.3 tons of carbon dioxide (equivalent) every year. The project was led by the student-run Energy Club, and sought to install occupancy sensors in non-residential bathrooms and stairwells. The project required collaboration across several institutional divisions, including: facilities, custodial services, maintenance, the sustainability office, academic departments, and student clubs. The project involved performing light audits, calculating energy savings, and creating a proposal for funding. These events exemplify various ways higher education can implement SDG's into teaching and general campus life by 1) encouraging a sustainability focused club whose mission fosters learning and skill development, 2) implementing study abroad programs or interesting courses that blend a primary field of study and sustainability, 3) encouraging student led projects that involve inter-silo collaboration.
Academic_Discipline_1: Physical & Earth Sciences (Chemistry, Geology, Atmospheric Sciences, etc)

Presentation Title: How Do We Meaningfully Integrate Sustainability Into Global Studies Curricula?
Description or Abstract: As higher education increasingly acknowledges the necessity of producing a globally-engaged student body, it has a responsibility to create a high-quality and relevant global studies curriculum. Former iterations of global studies curricula tended to treat humans and the environment as separate entities, but the reality of their interconnectivity cannot be ignored. Furthermore, the notion of sustainability as an exclusive, stand-alone topic within global studies is antithetical to its true nature of being woven into the traditions of land use and ecosystem management. This networking session would be for administrators, faculty, and international education staff who are interested in sharing and learning about the different ways that global studies is taught and managed at different institutions. My home institution of Champlain College merges a professional focus with a liberal arts general education and has made the production of engaged global citizens part of its mission. We have developed an innovative, interdisciplinary global studies curriculum for our third-year students and expanded opportunities for study abroad and faculty-led travel courses in order to fulfill our mission. My hope is to share and brainstorm with others on how they achieve global education competencies. Lastly, I'd like to spend time on the question: How do we meaningfully integrate sustainability into global studies curricula in a way that is foundational, rather than supplemental, to student learning?

Presentation Title: Campus Sustainability 101 - A New Course for First Year Students
Description or Abstract: Due to their complex and global nature, modern environmental problems like climate change, water scarcity, or mass extinction events can be overwhelming and really, really scary, especially for college students who have too frequently been told about future horrors without being offered effective tools that can help to divert these problems. As such, students who care both about other people and the planet around them are left wondering: 'What am I to do?' Fortunately, the practice of sustainability - which balances the needs of people today with those of people in the future - can provide solutions to these challenging problems. With this in mind, a new course for incoming college students was developed and offered in the Fall of 2017 that explored the theoretical concepts supporting the emerging discipline of Sustainability Studies while offering students concrete opportunities for putting these ideas into practice. This session will present the structure, learning goals, and pedagogy of this new course as well as offer reflections on its effectiveness to promote academic and personal growth. In particular, assignments in support of the campus-based group sustainability project will be discussed. Session participants will be invited to consider the logistical elements necessary either to develop a similar course or to integrate a campus sustainability project into existing courses on their respective campuses.
PositionTitle_1: Professor of Geosciences, Faculty Sustainability Coordinator

Presentation Title: High Impact Pedagogical Practices for High Impact Sustainability Learning
Description or Abstract: In the face of a rapidly-changing planet, sustainability is one of the most promising solutions to address social, economic, and environmental problems. Through IUPUI's Themed Learning Community (TLC), 'Sustainability: Thriving Communities, Thriving Planet,' students learned the causes and effects of some of our planet's biggest problems. Utilizing IUPUI's campus as a laboratory for sustainability, the essential question explored during the semester was, 'As a critical thinker, how can I apply sustainable solutions to create thriving communities and a thriving planet?' This question was explored through the hands-on application of sustainability principles, including high impact pedagogical practices such as service learning, reflections, out-of-classroom experiences, active learning strategies, course integration, and applications to the Greening IUPUI Grant. Evidence from student reflections indicates these high impact practices created a more robust learning experience, and all students expressed the value of the TLC in shaping their opinions and behavior to create a more sustainable community. This presentation will explore each high impact pedagogical practice employed and its ability to be transferred to other courses.

Presentation Title: Laudato Si and UNSDGs: An Ignatian Framework for Teaching Human Geography
Description or Abstract: St. Louis University High School created an innovative Human Geography course incorporating the AP Human Geography curriculum with studies of Ignatian values based on Pope Francis' 'Laudato Si: On Care for Our Common Home,' the UNSDGs, and current neuroscience research. These intellectual strands were woven throughout the seven themes of Human Geography: location, population, culture, political organizations, agriculture, industrialization, and urbanization and culminated in independent student research explicitly linking the concept of Throwaway Culture and the UNSDG's. Finally, our students engage with our community through our Passport program, which requires them to visit, interact, and reflect upon a local site and how it connects to course content.
Academic_Discipline_1: Social Sciences (Economics, Geography, Political Science, etc)

Presentation Title: Planning and Implementing a University-Wide Curriculum Disruption to Teach About Climate Justice
Description or Abstract: From February 26-March 2, 2018, The New School will invite all 14,000 faculty, staff, and students to participate in a university-wide curriculum disruption entitled 'Disrupt Climate Injustice.' This means stopping 'business as usual' to turn our attention to climate change, its implications, and its unequal and devastating impacts on vulnerable communities around the globe. This disruption is an opportunity to come together to take concrete action toward fighting climate change and supporting climate justice in an effort led by the university-wide Tishman Environment and Design Center. The curriculum disruption includes special activities occurring in classes, a series of extracurricular workshops and public events on campus, and engagement through social media. Resources prepared for faculty ahead of the disruption include: suggested readings and videos, sample lesson plans and conversation starters, assistance with guest lecture facilitation, and faculty liaisons for each school to address questions or concerns from colleagues who are less familiar with climate change. Attend this session to learn more about the planning and implementation process for disrupting curriculum university-wide in order to foster critical dialogue, learning, and reflection about climate change and its impacts. Emphasis will be on communications, getting buy-in, and coordination with university administrators, faculty, and other university offices like Buildings and Facilities.

Presentation Title: Worry & Hope: Results from a Focus Group Study on Students and Sustainability Curriculum
Description or Abstract: The University of Hawaii used a focus group study across ten campuses to better understand student perspectives on global and local environmental issues, climate change, and sustainability, and how these issues impact their experience in college, their degree choices, their career plans, and their visions of their own productive futures. Over 500 students participated. This session will be the first sharing of the results and preliminary analysis from the study. The researchers will also share the protocol for the study and reflect on their experiences conducting it.
PositionTitle_1: Professor and UH System Sustainability Coordinator at University of Hawaii.

Presentation Title: Academia as a Platform for Student Sustainability Action on Campus and in Your Community
Description or Abstract: Students at the University of Pittsburgh have been driving environmental and sustainability changes on campus and in the Pittsburgh community for more than a decade through classes designed to engage them in the process of advocating for and affecting change. With an emphasis on visioning, team-building, leadership development, power-building, and results-oriented projects, students have used the triple-bottom line to create trust and positive relationships throughout the university. This session will focus on the classes and the process, as well as describe some of the dozens of projects that have resulted in long-term changes at Pitt, including the University of Thriftsburgh, the Green Fund, the Real Food Challenge, Clutter for a Cause, and many others.

Presentation Title: Sustainability in the Visual Arts, Design and Creative Fields
Description or Abstract: Designers make the most beautiful trash. Educators in Design, Visual Arts, and other creative fields are challenged with educating our students on how to create high impact messages with low impact waste. Sustainable design today has gone far beyond simply using recycled plastics and plant based inks, and so must our pedagogy in teaching about sustainability in the visual arts. Using systems thinking and design thinking practices, educators and students alike need to approach production considering materials, behaviors, ethics and lifecycles. As educators, we need to teach our students not to just design more stuff, but instead to design systems, experiences, and interactions to change behavior. This networking session brings together educators working in the Visual Arts, Design, Communication Arts, and other creative fields to share challenges, best practices, and strategies for integrating sustainability into the curriculum. This session also welcomes those who work collaboratively across disciplines with those in creative departments such as Computer Science, Environmental Studies, Engineering, Architecture, Advertising and others.

Presentation Title: Win-Win-Win: Incorporating Authentic Sustainability Learning Into Technical College Courses
Description or Abstract: Incorporating sustainability in the curriculum need not be a one-off or a stretch to fit in any curricula, even those not typically associated with sustainability. Hear one example of how a collaboration between the Western Technical College sustainability department and a graphic design instructor blossomed into an ongoing partnership that helps students learn about core sustainability concepts, advances the awareness of sustainability across the college, and inspires other instructors to take action.

Presentation Title: Achieving SDGs and Engaging Higher Education Using EPA Tools
Description or Abstract: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) provides a suite of freely available, web-based tools that assist diverse audiences, including higher education institutions, in tackling local and regional environmental problems, building capacity, and meeting their sustainability and resilience goals. In this session, attendees will get an overview of a selection of EPA tools related to fostering sustainable and healthy communities while also addressing numerous Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The session will also include an in-depth introduction to one multi-faceted tool, EnviroAtlas, illustrating how this tool can be used in both higher education and beyond the classroom to inform SDGs. EnviroAtlas provides a collection of web-based resources for exploring human health impacts, and environmental and socioeconomic data relevant to the SDGs. EnviroAtlas contains two primary tools: An Interactive Map, which provides access to hundreds of maps at multiple extents and scales for the U.S., and an Eco-Health Relationship Browser, which displays evidence-based research on the linkages between ecosystems services and human health. EnviroAtlas resources are broadly applicable for informing research, decision-making, and education. Higher education and K-12 curricula have been developed using EnviroAtlas tools, and EnviroAtlas has been used in multiple higher education institutions.

Presentation Title: Improving Our Understanding of Sustainability with Bio-Mimicry
Description or Abstract: Some systems are much more sustainable than others, and this is not random. It is because certain key properties are present in more sustainable systems, but absent from unsustainable systems. Because we are in a period of rapid global changes, it may take decades or centuries for us humans to directly identify many of these key properties that promote sustainability. However, within nature, the systems with the most sustainable properties have already had millions of years to displace those with less sustainable properties. The properties within the planet's sustainable natural systems can be interpreted and applied (i.e. bio-mimicry) to an unlimited number of human contexts, such as the UN Sustainable Development Goals. The application of sustainable ecological patterns to human contexts has the potential to greatly speed our progress toward sustainability goals.
PositionTitle_1: Ecologist and Author, The Nature of Sustainability

Presentation Title: Key Competencies in Sustainability: Overview and Next Steps
Description or Abstract: The Panel-discussion is part of a nationwide process to solicit feedback on an initiative with the National Council for Science and the Environment (NCSE). The goal of the initiative is to develop an overview of the landscape of key competencies in sustainability across higher education institutions. Over the last couple of months, members of the NCSE initiative have engaged in listening sessions across the country to learn how higher education institutions employ key competencies in sustainability to develop sustainability curricula on the level of courses/programs and how they arrived at formulating learning outcomes for courses/programs, considering the different groups involved across a school or even university. The panel will report back what they have heard during these listening sessions and offer their initial lessons learned for discussion with the audience. The goal of the discussion with the audience is to solicit feedback on two questions. First, how can key competencies in sustainability help guide curriculum development and administration of sustainability degree programs? Second, how could shared understanding around such competencies-based approaches and learning outcomes help ensure high quality standards across sustainability programs in higher education?

Presentation Title: Applied Learning: Interventions for Sustainability Impacts
Description or Abstract: Applied learning (AL) for sustainability is an umbrella term and encompasses student engagement activities (e.g., internships, courses, research practicums) that deliver exceptional student experiences and a positive outcome for sustainability in the community. AL is exemplified in sustainability projects that are launched in collaboration with community partners (NGOs, cities, businesses). These efforts require the involvement of various entities within the university and in the community - and thus require a thoughtful strategy in order to launch and scale. The purpose of this workshop is to empower and activate staff or faculty who are involved in building or growing AL programs at their institution. We will review interventions for building successful AL programs and then adapt or transfer those concepts in order to design a specific intervention that supports their institution's AL program. The focus can be on initiating an AL program, launching it, growing it, or institutionalizing it. Participants will self-select into their peer-group (Kick-starter, intermediate, and advanced sustainability brokers). Each group will be supported by 1-2 facilitators. Participants will work through a series of five steps to develop their intervention, using the activities and tools presented by the workshop organizers and other participants (peer-learning) to design their intervention.
PositionTitle_3: Campus as a Living Lab Manager
PositionTitle_4: Project Coordinator, Campus as a Learning Lab

Presentation Title: Key Competencies in Sustainability: Curriculum and Program Development
Description or Abstract: Every year, new sustainability degree programs are launched at colleges and universities across the USA joining a global trend of sustainability degree programs offered at higher education institutions worldwide. This raises important questions for the field of sustainability in higher education related to quality and standards, processes of program development and administration, and communicating the skills and abilities sustainability graduates would have to potential employers. In early 2018, the National Council for Science and the Environment (NCSE) launched a process focusing on 'key competencies' in sustainability degree programs in collaboration with the Sustainability Curriculum Consortium (SCC) and NCSE member institutions, including the School of Sustainability at Arizona State University (ASU) and University of Northern Arizona (NAU). The goal of this initiative, through workshops, dialogues and other activities, is to create a 'Consensus Statement' on sustainability competencies. This workshop led by members in this initiative from NCSE, SCC, ASU and NAU, is an opportunity to inform about the initiative's progress to date; to further explore the above questions; and, to invite workshop participants to contribute their experiences and insights to a shared and growing body of knowledge around key competencies in sustainability degree programs.

Presentation Title: So You've Been Told to Teach About Sustainability? Now What?
Description or Abstract: Sustainability curriculum in higher education is increasingly institutionalized; we have moved past the 'early adopters' across the faculty who have been drivers of sustainability across the curriculum. What happens when new faculty, or those with no background in sustainability, are asked to incorporate sustainability subject matter into their classes? Most faculty members' disciplinary training does not include sustainability. Thus, a need exists to articulate and share with faculty the core concepts of sustainability subject-matter and how to include them. This session aims to explore 'what to teach' when tasked with teaching about sustainability. Three perspectives are offered. The first presenter will share findings from an exhaustive literature review about what prior research on teaching about sustainability in higher education identifies as the 'core' sustainability ideas (e.g., climate crises, future generations, resource management, poverty, and environmental justice) Second, from a practice perspective, the co-presenter will share an example of core concepts and key terms used in the University of Hawaii System Sustainability Curriculum (such as sustainable economics, ecosystem services, and equity). Third, the presenters will extrapolate core subject matter ideas from the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (such as climate action, clean water and sanitation, and affordable and clean energy). Weaving these three perspectives together, the session will conclude with an iterative discussion about what the core concepts of sustainability are, and how participants can bring the ideas back to their campuses to support faculty members in more meaningfully incorporate sustainability into their coursework.
PositionTitle_2: Professor and UH System Sustainability Coordinator at University of Hawaii.

Presentation Title: Campus Sustainability Plans as Pedagogical Opportunities for High Impact Student Experiences
Description or Abstract: As universities strive for increased sustainability, there is a growing need for coordinated and comprehensive campus sustainability plans that provide specific action items and clear roadmaps to improved sustainability within key areas like transportation, landscape, food systems, energy, and waste among others. Although many institutions have general campus sustainability plans, the plans often lack more specific and detailed goals, strategies, and tactics for improving sustainability within these sectors. The research and crafting of these more detailed plans present great opportunities for student learning. Sustainability education high impact practices emphasize the importance of project-based, applied learning experiences as well as collaborative learning. Higher education professionals also emphasize the importance of capstone signature experiences. At Furman University, we have combined the need for improved sustainability planning with the student educational experience. Students in our senior capstone sustainability science practicum class work in student teams to address and develop detailed, integrated, and holistic vision and master plans for different sustainability campus sectors including alternative transportation, eco-friendly landscaping, and sustainable food systems. Over the course of a year, teams meet with key stakeholders, review the literature, assess the current state, assemble best practices, and collect data to inform their vision and plans for improving sustainability within each sector. The resulting written report serves as a foundational and guiding document for improving sustainability in each sector and can be used to inform and improve Furman's Sustainability Tracking Assessment and Rating System (STARS) performance. This poster will describe the capstone course and design, and present some results from this latest iteration of the course.
PositionTitle_1: Executive Director, David E. Shi Center for Sustainability

Presentation Title: How Higher Education is approaching its commitment to sustainability through sustainability courses
Description or Abstract: For over a decade, the concepts of education for sustainable development have been recognized by many higher education institutes. A significant number of higher education institutions have signed agreements and declarations to educate students in all disciplines about sustainability. Although several institutions of higher education have signed the sustainability declarations, literature review finds little evidence that their curriculums have been modified to include education for sustainable development. There is obvious and widespread provision for the concept of student education in sustainable education; there is the little implementation of these decelerations at a practical level. In recent years, sustainability focused courses have been established at many higher education institutions. However, such courses lack systematic evaluation to measure the learning outcomes for sustainability within their sustainability courses. This research study has assessed the learning outcomes of these sustainability focused courses through examining the syllabi of these courses and interviewing instructors about how they integrate sustainability in courses. Qualitative responses were examined in light of a learning outcomes of sustainability education proposed American association for advancement of sustainability in higher education (AASHE) and higher education institute. Notable findings were: substantial responses recognized the conceptual understanding of environmental (81%), economic (50%) and social (31%) dimension of sustainability as LO of sustainability focused courses-but just three instructor highlighted all three dimensions. 50% instructors showed that they consider student attitude around concept as main learning outcome of their courses. Environmental stewardship were characterized as learning outcome by 83% instructors, though many of them didn't provide any evidence and details about it.

Presentation Title: Social Environmental Case Study on Mining, Wild Rice and Water Protection in Minnesota
Description or Abstract: This session involves participants in a social environmental synthesis case study, using methods taught by the National Social Environmental Synthesis Center (sesync.org) in Maryland, where this case was developed at a workshop. Case studies offer students a chance to practice mapping complex systems, analyzing tradeoffs and understanding stakeholder perspectives. The case is on a current, contested issue at the intersection of culture, economics and environment in Minnesota - the appropriate way to protect wild rice from impacts of proposed copper sulfate mining and other sources of sulfate. Wild rice, an edible, nutty-flavored grain, grows in shallow waters in Minnesota. Each fall, people harvest wild rice by canoe, using knocking sticks to strike the plants and cause ripe grains to fall. The Ojibwe origin story tells of migration from the east to where 'food grows on water.' American Indian people retain treaty rights to harvest rice. Outside reservations (there are 12 recognized tribal communities in Minnesota), harvest of wild rice is regulated. Minnesota has research-based sulfate level regulation for water where wild rice grows. Sulfate reacts to elements in lake sediment and becomes sulfide, taken up by the plant's stem, and impairing growth. Minnesota's regulation was scarcely enforced until 2010, when new copper-sulfate mines, one called PolyMet, were proposed in a mining region near Minnesota's Boundary Waters. Minnesota's mining area is known as the 'Iron Range' for the taconite ore used in steelmaking. Miners generally support new mines, while environmentalists and American Indian community groups typically oppose them. Participants will make a system map and analyze the stakeholders and their influence in the wild rice case. I hope participants will be inspired to bring the challenge, and complexity, of case studies to their own sustainability classroom. The SESYNC case study library will also be presented.

Presentation Title: Sustainable Justice in Wisconsin: Strategies for Program Growth in Harsh Climates
Description or Abstract: As evidenced by AASHE's recent Keynote presenters--from Julian Agyeman (2010) on 'Just Sustainabilities' to Marsha Chatelain's creation of the #fergusonsyllabus (2016)--AASHE's present and future directions foreground strengthening connections between environmental justice (a grassroots movement of working class people and communities of color) and sustainability (a largely white and middle-class movement for transforming business, industry, and public utilities). How can that transdisciplinary vision be articulated through college campuses that are largely disciplinary-based? Our campus took on that challenge, providing annual Sustainability-Across-the-Curriculum workshops, mentoring faculty to support their decisions to infuse social justice-driven courses with analyses of economics and environment, and to offer cultural diversity trainings to faculty oriented primarily to environmental sciences. Inspired by Agyeman's work, our new Sustainable Justice Minor offers curriculum across all four university colleges, with foundations and capstone courses that are co-taught and bridge university-community bounds. Enlivening both students and faculty through film-and-discussion series, through mindfulness pedagogy, art-based sustainability workshops and pop-ups, and regional sustainability bus tours are some of our tools. We also work with the larger state university system by participating in the all-campus Environmental Programs consortium, that is creating a place-based summer program.
PositionTitle_2: Professor and Coordinator, Sustainable Justice Minor

Presentation Title: Education as the Engine for the Global Goals
Description or Abstract: In 2016, 750 experts from around the world came together in Ahmedabad, India, to drill down into each of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG), or Global Goals, to identify how education is necessary to achieve all of the SDGs. The first group to meet (beyond COP21 in Paris) after the adoption of the SDGs, by the UN member states, in 2015, the ESDG participants highlighted how it isn't enough to just tuck away Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) in Target 4.7. As a 'Driver' for the SDGs, education should be front and center, as it is necessary to educate across all sectors and disciplines, in a variety of formal, nonformal, and informal educational modalities. As the higher education envoy for UN University, AASHE, and the US Partnership for ESD at the ESDG conference, presenter Kim Smith co-authored a list of recommendations for how higher education could help serve as an engine for the SDGs. These recommendations were combined with contributions for all of the SDGs, to offer a document of great worth and guidance for educators, institutions, and leaders to help implement the SDGs across their communities. Come explore how these lessons emerged and how your work helps advance the SDGs.

Presentation Title: Integration of the SDG's as a Targeted Educational Alternative...A Story of Successful Collaboration
Description or Abstract: Join us as we share a Story of Success: UTRGV and Buell Central High School's Transformative integration of SDG's to engage and motivate our most vulnerable and marginalized youth. Buell Central High School is a Disciplinary Alternative Education Program (DAEP) within PSJA-ISD, that has a student population from low socio-economic backgrounds, and out of the juvenile justice system. The majority, approximately 98% of these students live in poverty and violence, and cope with the effects of racism, colonialism, homophobia, neglect, abuse, sexual assault and exploitation, homelessness, mental illness, grief, and undiagnosed learning difficulties. Join us and hear the story behind the school's principle who's past, not much different from his current students, brought him full circle back to the community where he grew up. Come learn how a simple phone call established a relationship (with UTRGV) that helped develop an inclusive and holistic learning framework of Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) through project based learning. Come see how this transformative program offers productive possibilities for social and educational change through the numerous projects the students have completed which address and contribute to SDG's within their own communities. Come experience the transformation in these students as their sense of belonging, self esteem and confidence to succeed is restored through their projects and the invested responsibility to see their communities succeed.

Presentation Title: Backcasting to the Future: SDGs and Graduate Research
Description or Abstract: Preparing sustainability graduate students for the future requires a balance of real-world work and project applications as well as research and publishing experiences and opportunities. It means guiding the challenging transdisciplinary work of exploring issues by connecting a multidisciplinary approach to real life experiences. As emerging sustainability professionals, it is imperative to provide graduate students with the understanding of how theory meets practice, and prepare them to do so in a professional manner. This workshop will outline an instructional design process used in the IU South Bend graduate course SUST-S610 Measuring Sustainability. In the course, students are introduced to the UN Sustainable Development Goals, a range of Sustainability Reporting Tools (SRTs), and local sustainability issues. Students are challenged to research how to meet the needs of a local partner or address a local issue by using the SDGs to place them in a global context. In the course, the result is a publishable and publically useful document analyzing the relationship between measuring sustainability and decision-making in theory and practice,the SDGs, and utilizes at least one SRT. These documents may take the form of a white paper, series of blogs, website, database, or other SRT deliverable. How to introduce issues, theory, context, and transdisciplinary application will be shared. Workshop attendees will gain first hand experience in course design and implementation. Small group work will challenge participants to weave the elements together into a project proposal. Ways to conduct reflection on the process and end result will conclude the session. This session is ideal for undergraduates curious about next steps in a sustainability academic career, for faculty looking for ways to integrate SDGs into courses, and for administrators interested in the larger role that sustainability education can play in preparing students for locally and globally relevant work.

Presentation Title: Nation's First Community-Based Culinary Medicine Garden and Sustainability Curriculum
Description or Abstract: We have the nation's first Culinary Medicine (CM) course pairing community members and Health Sciences (HS) students together to research, design, and implement community-based CM curricula, the inclusion in CM of culturally-appropriate foods, and community-based health, nutrition, and sustainability education and research. Our classes are taught by HS students from the University of Utah (U.), along with community members receiving a stipend from the U. for their research and teaching work. This is a reciprocal learning model, building upon one another's strengths to facilitate programming that develops community capacity, breaks down barriers to health equity and healthy environments, as well as creating pathways to higher education in Health Sciences and Sustainable Nutritional within minority populations. This model is significant as approximately 65,000 refugees from over 30 countries have been resettled in Utah, 99% of whom live in food deserts. There is a general lack of access to fresh fruits and vegetables, and an even more pronounced dearth of foods native to their countries of origin. This is an exigent issue as racial/ethnic minorities are 1.5 to 2 times as likely as whites to develop major chronic diet-related diseases, and enrollment in U.S. Medical schools consist of 58.8% White, 19.8% Asian, 5.7% African-American, 4.6% Latino/Hispanic students, leading to a gap in representation of our communities and their respective needs. Community-led health outreach members collaborating with health service providers have proved beneficial to health outcomes in ethnic and racial minority communities. And, as we are the nation's first school to provide Medical, Nursing, Dentistry, and Pharmacy Students with sustainability curricula within Culinary Medicine, we provide our next generation of diverse health professionals with critical lenses on environmental, cultural, and food justices as requisite aspects of holistic health.

Presentation Title: Greening the Chemistry Research and Teaching Labs: Resources to Increase Safety and Reduce Waste
Description or Abstract: University and college campuses across the United States are pushing the envelope on greening their campus facilities, operations, and processes. However, despite their disproportionate consumption of resources, laboratories are often excluded from sustainability programs. Bringing sustainable practices into research and teaching laboratories can have a significant impact on increasing safety, conserving energy, reducing waste and hazardous chemical usage, amongst other tangible benefits. This presentation will provide attendees with resources that can be readily implemented within the chemistry research and teaching laboratories, spanning from conservation approaches to greener alternative substitutions. Green chemistry in practice has proven to provide a safer working environment for researchers and students, while maintaining a high level of rigor for teaching and excellence in research. In this session, appropriate for faculty, students of all levels, researchers, and EHS personnel, the connection of safety and ethics issues to real-world applications of safer chemical approaches in the laboratory will be made. Examples will be presented from universities who are actively implementing safer, greener laboratory practices across research and teaching divisions. Additionally, resources will be presented to enable participants to engage with their chemistry departments through green chemistry.
Academic_Discipline_1: Physical & Earth Sciences (Chemistry, Geology, Atmospheric Sciences, etc)

Presentation Title: Linking Teaching Practices to Students' Pro-Sustainability Behaviors
Description or Abstract: Broadly integrating sustainability throughout higher education curriculum is a common goal among instructors, scholars, and the AASHE community. But while sustainability knowledge is good in its own right, research has shown that the link between increased knowledge and behaviors required to address many current environmental, economic, and social challenges is tenuous at best. Implementing sustainability into a wide array of courses provides an opportunity for a great new number of instructors and teaching practices to become involved in the conversation. So while the knowledge taught in classrooms may not, in itself, lead to the change we seek, it is possible teachers and certain styles of teaching may. In order to investigate if the way sustainability curriculum is delivered influences students' sustainability behaviors, we analyzed data from two recent surveys of undergraduate students conducted at the beginning and end of the semester. We explored a variety of teaching techniques that research has pointed to as 'good' teaching practices. We found that while all of these methods may be equally good at imparting knowledge, some are better than others in regards to increasing sustainability-related behaviors. For example, we found that when instructors guided students to use what they already know (by tapping their prior knowledge) to help them learn about sustainability, students increased their pro-sustainability behaviors over the course of the semester.

Presentation Title: Teaching Sustainability Through Non-Traditional Learning Methods
Description or Abstract: To address complex global challenges, such as 'climate change, poverty, violent conflicts, and overuse of natural resources' (Brundiers & Wiek, 2011, p. 108) a growing number of institutions of higher education have incorporated the concept of teaching sustainability, which is referred to as sustainability education, to create a more sustainable society with sustainability literate individuals. Sustainability literacy indicates an individual 'having the understanding, skills, attitudes and attributes to take informed action for the benefit of oneself and others, now and into a long-term future' (Diamond & Irwin, 2012, p. 339). It requires an individual's 'ability and disposition to engage in thinking, problem solving, decision making, and actions associated with achieving sustainability' (Nolet, 2009, p. 421). Going further, sustainability education encourages students to participate in problem- and solution-oriented research (Brundiers & Wiek, 2011, p. 108). Instead of lectures, faculty are finding it beneficial to use creative methods to teach the concept of sustainability, because they find the non-traditional teaching and learning methods encourage students' critical thinking and engagement. There are various teaching and learning approaches to teaching the concept of sustainability, such as, case-based instruction, experiential learning, problem-based learning, role-play learning, service learning, and teamwork. Case-based instruction refers to the use of case studies in teaching. Experiential learning refers to learning through experience. Problem-based learning is a focused, experiential learning approach that addresses a specific problem through investigation and explanation often through use of small collaborative groups (Hmelo-Silver, 2004, p. 236). With the role-play learning approach students take on different roles and act out a scenario. Service-learning promotes educational opportunities that students participate in and reflect.

Presentation Title: Preliminary Assessment of the Impact of Changes in Campus Sustainability Efforts on Student Environmental Knowledge and Behaviors
Description or Abstract: At Pittsburg State University, efforts to promote sustainability and environmental awareness has increased substantially since 2012. A formal Recycling Services Department was created, the number of activities by a campus student sustainability group increased, a new sustainability degree program was created, participation in the STARs program expanded the awareness of sustainability in the curriculum for faculty, and sustainability was included as a core value in the updated university strategic plan. While indicators such as the increase in material recycled demonstrate that campus efforts are making a substantial difference, the impact on students in unclear. To explore this, Pittsburg State University began implementing an annual survey in August 2014 to measure environmental literacy and behaviors of incoming freshman. The same survey was then given to the same group/cohort of students in the spring semester of their junior year to see whether there was any significant difference in their environmental knowledge and/or behaviors after five semesters of undergraduate enrollment. The results presented here are the preliminary analysis of two different cohorts of undergraduate students. While it is not possible to demonstrate a direct link between exposure to these campus efforts and a change in knowledge and/or behaviors, it does provide a platform to explore whether an increase in sustainability efforts on campus is having an impact on students. Identifying any trends is important, as PSU is currently expanding their sustainability efforts, both inside and outside the classroom.

Presentation Title: ESRAP: Building Partnerships Across the Globe to Elevate Sustainability Focused Curriculum & Research
Description or Abstract: Educators for Socially Responsible Apparel Practices (ESRAP) is a non-profit that engages and collaborates across the globe to share news, best practices, review sustainability texts, and offer strong platform for student engagement through competitions. This platform also provides an opportunity for faculty to share and document their work related to sustainability. ESRAP would like to expand their network and also provide a successful model for multiple disciplines. This session will be unique as it will provide opportunity for the audience to create models and network to make sustainability mainstream in today's connected world. The session will include ESRAP's work that relates to UN Sustainable Development Goals.

Presentation Title: Infusing Sustainability in Higher Education in Ireland - The Green Curriculum Model (GCM)
Description or Abstract: This session presented by Frida Agbor Besong, a 2018 AASHE Campus Sustainability Research Award winner, will highlight research based on sustainability in the curriculum of Dublin City University (Ireland) The research focuses on a conceptual-design framework for educators to re-orient curricula towards sustainability. It will explore how sustainability could be integrated in higher education, with a particular focus on identifying the key sustainability themes, principles, pedagogic practices and specific competencies that underpin a model for infusing sustainability in higher education. At the same time, it will also investigate how the effectiveness of particular competencies (developed within a sustainability-infusion curriculum process) might be evaluated using a sustainability competencies assessment tool called the Dispositions, Abilities and Behaviors (DAB) Framework for profiling learners' sustainability competencies across higher education faculties, programs and courses.

Presentation Title: Driving Creative Sustainable Solutions Using a Design Thinking Approach in the Engineering Classroom
Description or Abstract: Design for the Environment, an upper-level undergraduate engineering course, is designed for students to develop a working knowledge of sustainable engineering in a way that enables them to apply it to their future career. The course content includes sustainability design frameworks, life cycle thinking, toxicity and risk, designing appropriate technologies within the context of the developing world, and case studies focused on the nexus of water, energy, and agriculture. A mix of lectures, in-class group activities, out-of-class assignments, whole class discussion, and hands-on prototyping are employed to offer students a diverse learning experience. The centerpiece of the course is the development of an engineering solution to a real-world sustainability challenge, the topics of which range from reducing food waste to enhancing sustainability of the built environment. This term-long group project serves as a way for students to apply content learned in the course. Design thinking - a five-stage process that guides students in empathizing with the user's needs, defining the problem, brainstorming solutions, creating simple prototypes, and testing the prototypes, iteratively ideating, prototyping, and testing to reach the best solution - was introduced with the goal of inspiring more innovative solutions. This approach to teaching sustainable design is unique because it allows the students to define the problem themselves and engage in divergent thinking skills, both of which are often missing from engineering courses. This presentation will include the evolution of the course, from inception to implementation, as well as preliminary results from an assessment plan aimed at evaluating students' (i) practice of sustainability in their design solutions, (ii) execution of the design thinking process, (iii) perceptions of active learning and their own creativity, (iv) oral presentation skills, and (v) other developmental outcomes related to their engineering careers.

Presentation Title: Multimodal Texts as a Window to Sustainability
Description or Abstract: Within the four walls of the elementary (K-5) and secondary content area (6-12) classroom, the limited experiential realm of education can be expanded through the strategic use of sustainability texts including rich media in addition to children's and adolescent literature. Teacher candidates engaged in planning and executing lessons utilize best practices in sustainability education by exploring multimodal narratives to enrich and widen student perspectives regarding sustainability issues in the 21st century. A wide range of sustainability topics can be addressed in class discussion, writing and projects. This poster will highlight sustainability multimodal texts within an organizational construct providing ideas for pedagogical application. Resources will include: video, printed text, digital, and visual narratives categorized by theme or topic. Video texts draw the viewer into scenarios tracing sustainability historically, or placing it in future contexts. Genres will include: documentaries, movies, TED talks, animation. Printed text will include: poetry, short stories, science fiction such cli-fi, graphic novels, memoir, magazines and non-fiction. Digital texts will categorize sustainability websites: government, educational, and social platforms. Visual narratives will include environmental art (sculpture, painting, and eco-art), photography, and printmaking. The resources are categorized by theme: agriculture and fisheries, biodiversity, climate change and atmosphere, consumption patterns, desertification and drought, disaster reduction, sanitation, human labor and social rights, lands, soils, forests and mountains, poverty, production patterns, seas and oceans, sustainable development, tourism, transportation, fair trade, energy, gender equity, indigenous people, population growth, land use, protecting and promoting human health. Each resource will be paired with pedagogical applications for use in elementary and content area secondary classrooms.

Presentation Title: Using the U.N. SDGs to Foster Systems Thinking in Incoming First-Year Students
Description or Abstract: The Summer STEM Institute (SSI) is an annual program that engages incoming freshman in STEM research and career pathway exploration in a week long experience. In previous years, SSI students learned a wide variety of STEM-related concepts and careers. Group research and final posters were based on career interests. In 2017, a common theme for all research projects and final posters across all 3 main Valencia College campuses (in Orlando) was used for the first time. The U.N. Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) served as the framework for the group research project and the context to promote learning outcomes in systems thinking, creativity, and complex problem solving (STEM solutions to improve quality of life). The concept of sustainability and the SDGs are specific enough to anchor students to a common STEM related topic, yet broad enough to provide ample freedom in choosing a diverse set of targets and potential solutions. Teams of 4 chose which of 9 SDGs their team would examine and present solutions for by the end of the week at a poster gallery. Each of the four team members represented either Science, Technology, Engineering, or Math (STEM) and were independently responsible to examine their team SDG solution through their specific STEM lens. Orlando's efforts to become one of the most sustainable cities in the country over the next few years provide SSI participants, college faculty and staff, and other local educators a living lab for innovation in sustainability.
Tags: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs),STEM,systems thinking,first year experience

Presentation Title: Teaching Sustainability in the Landscape Architecture Field
Description or Abstract: The purpose of this mixed method study is 1) to describe the current status of sustainability teaching in the landscape architecture programs and 2) to explore landscape architecture faculty perspectives on teaching sustainability. 'As sustainable landscapes are increasingly requested and required' (Dinep & Schwab, 2010), theories, methods and strategies for sustainable landscape practice are widely discussed (Dinep & Schwab, 2010; Calkins, 2011; Beata, 2014; Yokohari, 2016). However, studies focused on sustainable landscape education were insufficient, resulting in a gap in the literature on how sustainable landscape is taught in high education institutions. To fill this gap, we raised the following research questions: 1) How is sustainability reflected in the mission statements, program descriptions, and curriculums of the landscape architecture programs? 2) How do landscape architecture faculty define sustainability? 3) How do faculty teach sustainability? 4) What are the benefits and barriers for teaching sustainability in landscape architecture field? A three-phase mixed methods research design is used to explore the research questions. The research data is collected from the landscape architecture programs accredited by Landscape Architecture Accreditation Board (LAAB) in the USA. In the first phase, mission statements from LAAB-accredited landscape architecture programs are collected and analyzed through content analysis. In the second phase, curriculums LAAB-accredited landscape architecture programs are collected and analyzed through assigning scores using a rubric. In the third phase, a survey is conducted focusing on faculty member's perspective of sustainability teaching in the landscape architecture field. The quantitative and qualitative outcomes come from the three phases will help us better understand how sustainability is taught in the landscape architecture field in the USA.

Presentation Title: Using S Designation to Build an Embedded Certificate and Create Coherence
Description or Abstract: The University of Hawaii 10 campus system uses common criteria and a process of interdiscipinary dialogue to designate sustainability focused courses across all ten campuses. A system-wide minor in sustainability is emerging as an embedded certificate in the general education curriculum. This simple, low-cost strategy provides opportunities for peer-to-peer professional development, builds curricular coherence, and ensures that students understand core concepts of sustainability, the science and impacts of climate change, and a connection to place through personal genealogies and indigenous perspectives.
PositionTitle_1: Professor and UH System Sustainability Coordinator at University of Hawaii.

Presentation Title: Creating Learning, Teaching, and Operational Partnerships Through Campus as a Living Labs
Description or Abstract: In this presentation, three campuses, will share their Campus as a Living Lab projects. The Sustainability Office at UW-Whitewater will describe two collaborations between faculty and the campus sustainability coordinator. Session participants will be given practical examples of how project-based learning was incorporated into a sustainability management course and an environmental policy course including student-led projects such as students using real campus data from AASHE STARS and by having sustainability staff actively involved in the classroom. Sustainability Staff from San Mateo Community College District (SMCCCD) will discuss the opportunities of bridging Facilities with curriculum and students by partnering with faculty to conduct campus as a living lab sustainability projects. Examples include: comprehensive indoor water audit, and zero waste behavior change research. Campus as a living lab provides academic excellence by creating insightful data for Facilities and invaluable sustainability awareness and experience. Finally, the Associate Librarian at San Jose State University's King Library, describes her experience of working with faculty and students in an Art History Design in Society course, to help students learn about sustainable design and features in LEED certified buildings. The presenter will share her experience in designing this module and demonstrate how it serves as a case study for Campus as a Living Lab content embedded into curriculum.

Presentation Title: Enhancing Student Learning and Promoting Sustainability Through Experiential Learning
Description or Abstract: This session includes experiential learning programs in three academic institutions.The programs illustrate how higher education institutions can foster public-private-community partnerships to achieve the SDGs and inform approaches to SDG 17. A short description of each program is given below. New York University(NYU)'s class in the College of Arts and Science aimed to develop real world proposals for green infrastructure projects on NYU's Washington Square campus. Students developed four storm water management projects to keep polluted runoff out of the city's waterways. At the end of the term, proposals were presented to the University leadership that has taken steps to implement the proposals. University of Dayton(UD)'s Dayton Regional Green (DRG) internship program and the River Stewards program exemplify approach to experiential learning at the University. DRG is a local sustainability organization. An internship program was created to support DRG initiatives through experiential learning. The nationally recognized River Stewards program is a three-year transdisciplinary program focused on leadership development and civic engagement. Worcester Polytechnic Institute(WPI) has developed a project-based curriculum with a wide array of programs addressing sustainability at all grade levels. Team experiential learning projects provide integrated technological and social solutions to address sustainability problems and support sponsors both on campus and at global centers.
PositionTitle_1: Manager of Grounds and Waste Management

Presentation Title: Design Thinking and Sustainability
Description or Abstract: This session will review two case studies involving design thinking and sustainability: Grand Valley State University The presentation will reflect on the learning process of students engaged in developing the learning curriculum of a $10 million campaign to expand the DeVos Family Center for Scouting in Grand Rapids, MI. In the Spring of 2018, twenty-four students enrolled in Design Thinking to Meet Real World needs were assigned as their semester long project the task of designing learning opportunities for the education of Sustainability, STEAM, & Leadership in unrepresented, low income, and minority communities. The goal of the course is to have students apply theories observed in the course to a real-life case study, while collaborating with stakeholders in a human centered design. Students research, discuss, analyze, and design a summer enrichment program. University of Pittsburgh Design for the Environment is an undergraduate course in which students develop a working knowledge of and the ability to apply principles of sustainable engineering. An underpinning of the course is the application of the Design Thinking process and content learned in the course to tackle a sustainability challenge. Topics range from reducing food waste to enhancing sustainability of the built environment. This presentation will discuss the foundations of the course and include preliminary results from an assessment plan aimed at evaluating the development of student learning.

Presentation Title: Sustainability Competencies, SDGs & Metacognition: Implementation and Assessment
Description or Abstract: Core learning sustainability competencies have been identified and are guiding course design: system thinking, future/temporal thinking, ethical literacy (values), interpersonal literacy (communication & collaboration), strategic thinking (action), and creativity/imagination. This session shares experience and research on the design, implementation, and assessment of two collaborations: 1. City University of New York, University Centre at Svalbard (UNIS, Norway), Fordham University, and Saint Peter's University; and 2. Leuphana University (Germany), and Arizona State University (ASU/LU double masters degree program in Global Sustainability Science). Faculty development workshop templates employing sustainability competencies are also presented. Curriculum design and assessment approach vary. The photovoice method was applied by the ASU/LU program to enable students to track their own learning processes, promote critical dialogue and assessment of key sustainability competencies, and empower students to become change agents. Advantages, limitations, and gas are identified from the experience of the use of pre- and post- assessment instruments: the legacy New Ecological/Environmental Paradigm - Revised; the emerging Sulitest Sustainability learning self-assessment; and qualitative case studies and reflection essays. Ongoing research of meta-cognition of ecosystem science in practice is referred to for insights. Faculty development workshop template employing above discussed.
PositionTitle_1: EdD Grad Student / Adjunct Asst Prof.

Presentation Title: Crowdcoaching: A Workshop About Workshops
Description or Abstract: Undertaking sustainable practices at colleges and universities requires the convergence of people, resources, and knowledge. Sharing experiences with colleagues at other campuses is an efficient conduit for successful implementation. Crowdcoaching brings people together to address sustainability issues creatively. Crowdcoaching (formerly the BYOP) is a format that provides campus sustainability personnel and facilities managers an opportunity to bring professional challenges to the table for suggestions and idea-sharing. Attendees work as a team to think through pressing issues of campus sustainability today-everyone has experience, knowledge, and perspective to contribute.

Presentation Title: Student Voices as the Key to Sustainability Assessment
Description or Abstract: Sustainability encourages a rich and broad awareness of our selves in the world. Assessment of sustainability learning should reflect the powerful insights and values that we hope sustainability education encourages. Student reflection is a powerful tool for both their learning and our evaluation of their learning. Our panel will offer two perspectives on assessment through student reflection which share the key insight of student voices themselves. Our first presentation will share examples of positive results from high-impact practice as reflected in carefully-designed course-specific and student learning outcomes and assessments. The second presentation will explore assessment through applied projects (the program's capstone) and written reflection (the program's portfolio), with an emphasis on core competences for sustainability. We will provide prompts, rubrics, and other strategies for using reflection in assessment.

Presentation Title: University Workshops Cultivating a Culture of Sustainability on Campus and Beyond
Description or Abstract: Faculty from West Chester University and University of Kentucky will join forces to share with AASHE members models of university workshops that foster a culture of sustainability. Beyond teaching sustainability, the workshops encourage interdisciplinary collaboration, best practices and strategies to align with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and consider ways in which faculty can implement sustainable methods of teaching into their curricula. Our workshops innovate by comprehensively integrating the local and global with the social, economic, and environmental aspects of sustainability. By attending this conference session, AASHE members will learn about: the distinctive qualities of the Brandywine Project (West Chester University) and the Sustain-able Pedagogies Workshop (University of Kentucky); how their institution can create similar workshops to serve their local needs; how to organize campus resources for workshops; and expansion workshops for staff and students. We look forward to extending our workshops' reach by engaging with AASHE members, increasing session participants' ability to grow a culture of sustainability at their universities and beyond.

Presentation Title: China Focus - Middlebury's Global Partnership for Sustainability and University of Minnesota's Environment and Cultural Diversity
Description or Abstract: This session, in a case study format, presents the driving motivations, objectives, current status and challenges of 1) Middelbury's Global Partnerships for Sustainability project in China and 2) the University of Minnesota's faculty-led short-term summer program in Yunnan Province. Providing an equal exchange, rather than an asymmetrical one, of educational goods is an important goal of Middlebury's 17 schools abroad with respect to the countries they operate in. How do such programs assure that they are providing value to the countries that host them at least equal to the value imparted on the schools and the students who study there? Middlebury's Global Partnerships for Sustainability in Kunming, Hangzhou, and Beijing partners with the Nature Conservancy (TNC) of China to provide hands-on learning opportunities for students while advancing TNC's goals of engaging Chinese citizens in their wetland and biodiversity conservation efforts. University of Minnesota's Environmental and Cultural Diversity program reframes students' ideas of sustainability in China, inviting them to see nature, culture and livelihoods holistically. Chinese approaches to environmental protection and support for cultural heritage are markedly different than in the US. Yunnan itself is known for mountains, clean air, spring-like climate, historically preserved cities and diverse ethnic groups. Half of China depends on fresh water flowing through Yunnan's river basins. In cities like Shangrila, nature and culture are commoditized into spectacle. Tourism reaches local communities and landscapes to profoundly change relationships of people, plants and animals. A China-based staff member who worked with both programs may join the panel virtually.

Presentation Title: Why Calculate When I Can Google? Quantitative Tools for Assessing the SDGs
Description or Abstract: AASHE 2018 poses the question: How can higher education institutions align their teaching and research activities around the SDGs? Assessment of countries' progress toward the SDGs requires data analysis and, often, estimations in the absence of complete data. This talk will describe an undergraduate course that helps students develop a quantitative toolbox for assessing environmental problems. The course was taught at both of the speakers' institutions during Spring 2018, and has been offered at one institution since 2003. Specific focus is given to estimation techniques, strategies for making reasonable assumptions, and how to assess the assumptions that may affect the quality of online data. The speakers will discuss both the technical skills in the curriculum and the resistance they face when students would rather google an answer then go through the work of calculating it. The speakers will also share strategies for addressing students' lack of confidence in their quantitative ability.

Presentation Title: Analysis of the Integration of Sustainability in Professional Hospitality Education Curriculum
Description or Abstract: The research presented in this proposal analyzes the education system of hospitality and culinary educational institutions in America. The goal of the research was to evaluate the need for sustainability in the culinary and hospitality industry, the discrepancy (if any) of sustainability education for culinary/hospitality students, and the recommendations of industry and educational professionals for the integration of sustainability in hospitality education. The proposal answers the question 'is there a need for the integration of sustainability education in hospitality/culinary educational institutions, and if so, what is the best way to integrate sustainability into the curricula?' Analysis for the proposal includes both primary and secondary research. Primary research consists of discussions with industry professionals and faculty members regarding their professional viewpoints and experiences. Secondary research includes review of literature covering sustainable education and integrated curriculum. The subject of this proposal has not yet been covered in published literature.
